PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.
Withdrawal of Notice of Motion

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw General Business, Notice of Motion No. 69, standing in my name relating to the consideration of ministerial reports tabled on 11 November 1982.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs aware that the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Everingham, introduced into the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly on Tuesday a motion calling on the Legislative Assembly to endorse the agreement between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory in respect of Aboriginal land in the Northern Territory? Has the Commonwealth Government made a firm agreement with the Northern Territory Government? If so, when was it made and what does it contain?

—Honourable senators know from questions I have answered over the last year or so that when I was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs I started off a series of negotiations which involved, on a tripartite basis, the Commonwealth Government, the Northern Territory Government and land councils in the Northern Territory. The object of those negotiations was to develop a set of agreements that would lead to some amendments of land arrangements in the Northern Territory which would operate to the mutual benefit of all parties. The situation that emerged was that, apart from a couple of remaining sticky points, there was a move towards consensus on most of the matters under discussion. At the time I left the portfolio and Mr Wilson succeeded me those remaining issues were being negotiated. Part of the difficulty was that the processes of the Central Land Council made it really quite difficult for it to present a single consensual view on some of the matters which had different implications for different parts of its membership.
—The behaviour of the Northern Territory Government made it difficult, too.

—I am answering the question in my way. I believe the Northern Territory Government had general agreement with the position that was being reached in the negotiations. Certainly, the Commonwealth was trying to get endorsement of what it thought was the position that had been reached in the negotiations between all parties around the table. I have no knowledge of whether Mr Everingham introduced a motion this week in the terms suggested by Senator Ryan but I have no reason to doubt that she is correct. I do not follow the Northern Territory Hansard. If Mr Everingham wanted to get endorsement of the position which had been developed in these negotiations then I must say that I would find it helpful to know that there was endorsement by the Northern Territory legislature. But I cannot say to Senator Ryan that there has been any agreement. An agreement has been sought between all parties with a view to getting an agreed position that would benefit Aboriginals and Territorians generally. While those negotiations are incomplete, I believe that Mr Wilson, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, will do his best to try to seek consensus among the parties with a view to getting those arrangements agreed and promoted.

—I ask a supplementary question. If the Minister is not aware of the agreement referred to by Mr Everingham in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly this week will he undertake to find out what was being referred to and what the contents of that agreement were?
—I will refer that to the Minister whom I represent.

—The Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs will be aware that, publicly and privately, and for some considerable period, I have been pressing the Australian Government to adopt a code of conduct applicable to Australian companies and individuals engaged in or associated with trading in South Africa, which code would involve the reporting of positive efforts taken to improve the economic and social conditions of non-white employees in South Africa. I ask the Minister whether the inquiries which the Australian Government was making to see whether a code could be developed most suitable to apply to Australian trading activities have now been completed. When will the Australian Government advise the Parliament of what action it intends to take to bring Australia into line with Britain and with European and other countries in demonstrating, in a practical sense, our determination to fight apartheid in South Africa?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The question of a possible introduction of a code of conduct for Australian companies engaged in trading with South Africa remains under consideration by the Government. The Minister regrets that it has not been possible to complete inquiries into the matter. It would be appreciated , I am sure, that the question of introducing a code of conduct for Australian companies raises a number of issues requiring extensive investigation and consultation. The Government remains committed to maintaining its total opposition to apartheid and to considering means by which that system can be peacefully changed. I emphasise that the Government has already instituted a range of measures with practical effect which demonstrates its determination to oppose apartheid in South Africa. I think that it is fair to say that we reject any suggestion that there is a need for Australia to come into line with European countries in this regard.

ANSWER.PARA: Two codes of conduct for foreign companies operating in South Africa have been adopted. These are the code for the European Economic Community and the Sullivan principles drawn up for the United States firms. The EEC code puts emphasis on trade union rights, and the Sullivan code puts emphasis on desegregation. They both, however, call for equal pay for equal work and for the abolition of segregation practices. The codes cannot be enforced and are basically statements of intent. Their major shortcoming is that they operate in isolation from the apartheid structure and their effect on helping to reform the apartheid system is possibly limited. As I said earlier, the matter is still under consideration. The Minister notes Senator Missen's interest in it. Any further information will be given to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I am disappointed to hear such a reply because it is more or less the same reply as I got nearly a year ago. Can we get some clarification as to when the Government expects to be able to make an announcement about this matter? I realise that it will not be in this session , but is there some likelihood of its being brought to fruition?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I shall see whether I can get a likely date for the finality of the discussions and the consideration being undertaken by the Minister for Foreign Affairs. If so, I shall advise Senator Missen. I shall also ask the Minister to note Senator Missen's active interest in this matter.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Is it true, as reported in the Press earlier this week, that the Government has issued an instruction to office managers of the Commonwealth Employment Service in Victoria not to speak to the Press? Is it also true that this instruction was issued on the same day as Sir Phillip Lynch announced his resignation as the member for Flinders? What is the current total of registered unemployed in the electorate of Flinders, and what was it at this time last year? Can the Minister confirm that between January and September this year 4,000 people were placed in work by the Frankston CES Office , but three times that number joined the register of unemployed at Frankston? Did this ratio increase sharply to 6:1 last month?

—I do not have the figures relating to any particular electorate in Australia. I am not sure that they are kept on an electorate basis but I shall check that to see whether the information is available, in response to the Leader of the Opposition. As regards public statements by the CES, my understanding is that statements by local CES officers are currently required to be limited to the local employment conditions and that statements which relate to the State-wide position are to be issued by the head office only. But I shall check the precise requirements on those officers. I think that there has been some variation over recent months of the instructions to CES officers with respect to talking to the Press. I shall get that detail for the Leader of the Opposition.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs seen a report in the Australian Financial Review of 16 November that the People' s Republic of China is reported to have abruptly severed all trade with South Korea? Is the report correct? Does the Government see the decision as related to the attendance by the Chinese Ambassador in Moscow early this month at the Soviet Union's Revolution Day march, the first time the Chinese have officially attended the march in a decade? What does the Government assess as the consequences of these occurrences upon East-West relations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Government is seeking to confirm the substance of the article which has been referred to by Senator Hill. If it is verified the Government will consider any implications for Australian trade in the region. China and the Soviet Union held a series of talks in Peking during October. Further talks may be held shortly in Moscow. Both countries recently reaffirmed their desire to improve relations. There has been little indication from either side of the results of the talks so far. Chinese leaders have told the Press that there was no significant progress on major bilateral issues.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia follows with interest the relationships between China and the Soviet Union. Australia would welcome a reduction in the present level of hostility between the two countries which might contribute to greater stability in the region. However, considerable obstacles remain to a substantial improvement in relations, particularly China's opposition to Soviet strategic policies. China has made it clear that relations can improve only if the Soviet Union changes its policies in Afghanistan and elsewhere.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Education a totally non-party-political question about the drift of children from state schools to independent schools. The Minister would know that since 1976 enrolments in the government school system have declined by one per cent while the level of enrolments in independent schools has increased by a startling 10 per cent. How does the Minister account for this sudden and dramatic change in the confidence of parents in the ability of government schools to provide their children with a good education? As a champion of government schools, may I state some reasons given, upon which I want the Minister to comment, as to why parents are no longer sending their children to state schools: Violence in the playground, teasing and boycotting anyone who departs from the norm, strong peer group pressure to avoid work, belittling of achievement and sidestepping of responsibility.

QUESTION.PARA: I ask whether the Minister can comment on the following reasons given for the drift to independent schools: There is a courtesy between all members of the school community in private schools which is not present in state schools; sound subject teaching by teachers who know their subject; a cheerful, sensible, down to earth attitude to the day to day running of the schools, and a stimulating variety of extra-curricular activities which are not present in state schools. Are any of these matters, in the Minister's experience, relevant to this rather alarming drift away from the state school system to the private school system, an area in which many parents must obviously be spending a great many of their discretionary dollars which they cannot afford? They are making the sacrifice to send their children to private schools when free state school education is available to them.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chipp's question touches on an important matter. I am grateful for the chance to answer it. The first point to make is that the great majority of Australian children, of course, receive their education in government schools. Many of the parents have their children in government schools by choice and by preference. I would not want anyone to lose sight of the fact that the government school system in Australia is extensive and generally is of good quality. In the Australian Capital Territory, in the system which I administer, there is a retention rate of 65 per cent to the end of Year 12, which is the envy of schools around Australia. That is in the government system. The debate has to take place against the background that that is the majority educational milieu for Australian children. It is true that there has been a movement of children to non-government schools.

ANSWER.PARA: Two main factors operate. The first one is demographic change. The number of children of school age is diminishing. Already we are finding that enrolments at the primary level are dropping. Although the previous wave of children is still coming through the secondary system, I imagine that enrolments there will also start to decline in a few years. Demographic change will be reflected in school enrolments. Of course, against that there is the other factor to which Senator Chipp referred; that is, that parents in quite considerable numbers are exercising a choice to move their children to non-government schools.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which hurts them financially.

—Senator Chipp makes an important point. In making that choice the parents are using discretionary income to back up that choice. They are voting not only with their feet but also with their cheque books. The other point to be made is that most of the schools in the non-government system to which parents send their children are within the Catholic system and most of them by any measure are poorer schools. So the great majority of people are taking their children to schools of--
—What about the elite grammar schools you have supported around the country?

—Senator Primmer's interjection is interesting. We have a group of people in Australia who are determined to do away with the non- government school system. I am interested that the President of the Australian Council of State Schools Organisations, who advocates no support for non- government schools, was educated at St Peter's College in Adelaide. One of his vice-presidents from New South Wales was in my class at Sydney Grammar School. Mr Marginson, who works with the Australian Teachers Federation and writes such virulent stuff, was educated at Scotch College. Mr Dawkins, who writes such magnificent stuff, is an old Scotch College boy from Perth. Joan Kirner, who has so much to say about non-government schools, went to a good ladies college in Melbourne. If we add to that the fact that Mr Morrison from another place educated his children at Sydney Grammar School--
—I just asked a simple question.

—I understand. I am answering Senator Primmer's interjection . I am interested in the kind of primeval guilt that some of these people must feel to work against the non-government system. I must also say that some of them are not terribly good advertisements to give one confidence in the non- government system. But to come back to Senator Chipp's point, parental choice must be based on some belief that in the non-government system there are some values or offerings which they like and which they find important.
—I am asking why.

—It relates to a whole lot of things: It relates to some of the matters raised by Senator Chipp; it relates to some of the values taught in those schools; and it relates to a feeling of confidence which parents have in the school environment and in what the school has to offer. I recently made some comments about the undesirability of some teachers federations making formal political allegiance with political parties. One of the things that I was trying to say was that a consequence of that kind of formal political allegiance will be a loss of confidence in the system by parents. Parents want to know that when their children go to school they are going into what is an open and, in political terms, neutral situation. A lot of factors relating to the values taught and the way in which parents perceive the system are leading a number of parents to remove their children from the government system.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said that, I come back to the first point. The numbers of children in non-government schools still represent a minority. The percentage is still less than it was in the early 1960s. Since then there has been a loss of children from non-government schools. It is just catching up. The majority of Australian children are in the government school system. For many of them it offers an excellent, appropriate and valued form of education. I would like to keep the argument in proper perspective and say that while we support parental choice and while we support a universal grant for children in non-government systems we do it against that kind of background and with a desire to help all children in all Australian schools.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Education. I refer the Minister to the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill, particularly the provision which requires that the States advise and seek approval from the Federal Government for expenditure on capital works programs before payments from the Federal Government are authorised. Will the Minister give the Senate an assurance that it is not the intention of the Federal Government to dictate to the State governments how funds for school buildings will be spent, notwithstanding what the Australian Labor Party might do with this legislation in the unlikely event of its being elected to government? I am sure the Minister understands that there is no similar provision in the present legislation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation is really very simple. I believe it is a matter of equity that the Commonwealth should be moving in the way it is proposing. In past years we have been providing up to 30 per cent of all the capital required for the building of government schools around Australia. That money has been provided by the Commonwealth. This year up to 50 per cent of all the capital funds which will be used in the States will be provided by the Commonwealth. In most States there has been absolutely no recognition of the Commonwealth's contribution or of the Commonwealth's role in the funding of the construction of government schools. It seems to us proper that if we are making a major contribution that fact should be made known publicly and should be clear . That is simply a question of equity and proper public accountability.

ANSWER.PARA: The purpose of the approval provision which we are proposing is simply so that we can know which schools are to be built with the money, that proper acknowledgment can be made while those schools are being built that they are joint Commonwealth-State funding efforts and Commonwealth funds are involved, and that if there is an opening ceremony the Commonwealth can in fact at least attend and take part in it. The purpose of seeking approval is to know what those projects will be. The States themselves can select the projects. The only reason we have put in the question of approval is that we would like to make sure that a State does not decide that it will use the Commonwealth funds, say, to upgrade washrooms around the State and build no schools, that in fact a State will put the money into building some of its schools and that it is acknowledged as having been assisted by the Commonwealth. Having said that, we are not out to say to a State that it should build schools here or there; we just want to know what the money is going to be used for. We think that is proper accountability for the use of taxpayers' funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. As an old boy from a school now on the Australian Labor Party's hit list, can the Minister reassure me--
—I would be less worried about the school than myself if I were you.

—If I am on Senator Button's hit list I am pretty safe. Can the Minister reassure me that it is not the intention of the Federal Government to direct in any way on what government schools the money should be spent?
—If the honourable senator reads the Hansard in due course he will get that kind of reassurance.

—I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. When the Government's proposals for a wages freeze or pause was first announced the Acting Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, and the Treasurer, Mr Howard, were very clear in rejecting any sort of control on prices. Further, it was reported that the Cabinet had rejected any sort of job creation scheme. It is now reported that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Macphee, has indicated that the Government would support a form of price surveillance and that the Minister for Transport and Construction, Mr Hunt, is preparing a scheme for job creation involving repair and maintenance of Commonwealth property, roads, railways, et cetera. Can the Leader of the Government explain the Government's firm position on price surveillance and employment creation in the context of the wages freeze proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's position has been totally clear from the outset. The Government has taken the view that the main cause of inflation and of loss of jobs has been the great upsurge in wages throughout Australia-in the order of 17 per cent or 18 per cent in past months-and that what is needed is a restraint on wages. The Government has held the view that the main costs involved are labour costs, that there is very little profitability in the community today and that, therefore, profitability cannot be a major factor in costs. Indeed, the need to take industry out of a loss situation into a profit situation so that it can continue to employ and to expand is vital. The Government has said from the outset that the States have the constitutional power over prices and charges and, if they so desire, they are welcome to use those powers.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has always said that inflating the deficit simply to bring about job creation of the leaf scraping variety will solve nothing, and that inflating the deficit will simply create more inflation and more unemployment. The Government has been looking to ways of expanding its transition from school to work programs, its retraining programs and its practical works programs. I repeat: The Budget contains such significant programs as the Bicentennial Roads Program, the airfields construction program and many others. There is no inconsistency in the statements that have been made. The Ministers concerned are carrying out the ordinary policies that the Government indicated in its Budget. The Treasurer indicated today quite clearly that the proposed wage freeze is strictly in accordance with the economic principles that the Government has pursued and intends to continue to pursue. As each day goes by, more and more the public commentaries are in favour of what the Government is doing. More and more sections of the community, and virtually every responsible newspaper in Australia, are saying that what the Government is doing is right. So there is a growing volume of approval.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which newspaper said that?
—Let me help. Yesterday I drew attention to the editorial of the Australian Financial Review and read extracts from it.
—Read the lot.
—I do not want to waste the time of the Senate, but I have been asked to read it:

ANSWER.PARA: There is no way city populations-and that means everybody, not just the blue collar union members-can continue to increase their real incomes in the face of the situation facing Australia in 1983. One way or another, belt-tightening is inevitable. If it isn't imposed by a Government wages freeze it will be imposed by a collapse in employment as the jobless percentage heads into double figures and wages claims disappear as employees cling with increasing desperation to their existing jobs . . . The need now is to divert sufficient income from the well-off employed majority to those who are unemployed, or about to be so, while maintaining overall demand at levels sufficient to avoid further downward multiplier effects . . .
That is from a responsible newspaper. Let me read what the Age said:

If you place the priority on maintaining the real wage gains of the past as Mr Crean does by default you make the unemployed bear the whole cost of the recession. If you place priority on maintaining jobs and are prepared to let real wages slide for a while, as Mr Halfpenny seems to do, you spread the costs of the recession around and minimise the human tragedy of workers finding themselves unwanted. One man's pay rise is less important than another man's job .

Where have I heard that before? That is from the Age. Newspaper after newspaper now is saying that what we are doing has a fundamental common sense about it. Virtually every newspaper in Australia has said that what Mr Hayden is advocating is disaster. Let me read what the Age newspaper said on this, because I am invited to do so by members of the Labor Party:

And in all the twists and turns that Mr Hayden's economics have undergone since he won esteem as Treasurer in 1975, the one constant appears to be a belief that the voters can be fooled, that the hard options can be fobbed of, and that it is unnecessary for a party preparing for government to have a credible economic policy.
Need I, in fact, read what the Australian Financial Review said of his policy? It states:

This leaves the Labor Party with a fiscal program which promises nothing but unemployment and inflation on a larger scale than we have now, and the prospect of further involuntary devaluations of the Australian dollar as we are locked into a devaluation/inflation spiral.

What we have at this moment is more and more members of the community saying: ' Yes, it is necessary to get wage restraint. We do not want one man's wage rise to be another man's loss of a job. We want to have costs down for the future. We want Australians to move together in a consensus'. It is a tragic thing for Australia that the Labor Party refuses to be part of the consensus, refuses to do the one thing that is now being generally acclaimed. It is now generally acclaimed throughout Australia that we must bear down on wages if we are to succeed in overcoming our problems. It is a tragedy that a party whose own economic policies have been condemned by every major newspaper in Australia--

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on!
—I will come again with more newspaper quotes because I enjoy this. The Adelaide Advertiser of 29 October this year stated:

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Hayden's own recipe for economic survival-by stimulating spending through tax cuts or higher benefits, by increased capital works spending, by freezing State government charges, by capital grants to provide jobs and by maintaining real wages-is unrealistically expansionary in the present climate. There is no knowing where Labor would find the money for such schemes, and no guarantee that Labor could persuade the unions to curb wages.

I repeat: Bit by bit there is an emerging consensus of the community that what the Government is doing is right. The Labor Party, as it did on the tax recoupment legislation, is getting further and further out on the plank and, as with tax recoupment legislation, it will sink itself. The fact is that every responsible commentator in Australia has said that what Labor is offering is as wrong as can be, that it would create more unemployment and more inflation. They are all saying that the Labor Party ought to get behind the aims of ordinary Australians. I make a plea to the Labor Party to put aside its partisanship in this situation. The Labor Party has been as wrong as it can be. It has been condemned. Let it get behind the Government for a change. Let it be really fair dinkum Australian. Let it get behind the fair dinkum Australians in the trade unions who are saying that they are willing to take a cut in wages so that they can keep in employment their colleagues, their mates. Let us have a bit of mateship; let us have a bit of bipartisanship. Then we will be on the job.

TALK.START.PARA: —Go down to Port Kembla and tell them that.
—You weren't very matey to the steel workers when they turned up the other day.

—I can understand the members of the Labor Party. Mr Hayden has said that the fall in the support in the polls has been caused by, amongst other things, an image of serious instability and uncertainty within the Labor Party. That is why the Labor Party is in a tizz today. What a strange irony it is that Mr Hayden noted that, when he lost his voice during the last election, Labor's stocks, in his words, shot up. If we extrapolate that, what really would Labor Party members do if he achieved full silence? In other words, he has condemned his own party, as the newspapers and the commentators of Australia have condemned the Labor Party. Why not let us get together with a bit of bipartisanship?

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Senator Sir John Carrick has taken eight minutes to reply to a question to which he has not given me an answer. I asked a question about the contradictory position being taken by various Ministers in the Government. I particularly want to know, having regard to the fact that five of the State Premiers have suggested that there should be some control on prices, whether in that context the Government is prepared to agree with the views taken by Mr Macphee that there should be some attempt at price control in return for a wage pause.

—Order! Before I ask the Leader of the Government to respond, in all fairness to the chamber and not just to Senator Gietzelt, I say that that supplementary question is really another question. I will not rule the question out of order. I am just passing this comment to the whole of the chamber. I have allowed a lot of latitude in the area of supplementary questions. Yesterday we had a couple of similar examples when supplementary questions should have been ruled to be extra questions. Whilst honourable senators have the right and sometimes the need to ask supplementary questions, I ask that they make sure that the questions are supplementary; otherwise they can deny the right of some other honourable senator to ask a question. I merely pass that comment to everybody in this chamber.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise for the length of the answer. It was due to the fact that the Australian Labor Party invited me to expound upon certain aspects of the question. Senator Gietzelt asked me two things. He asked me whether the comment on price surveillance was a departure from Government policy and whether the comment of Mr Macphee, in terms of jobs, was a departure from Government policy. I answered in both cases: 'No, it was not'. I said that the Government had made its main thrust on wages because of its conviction that they are the major ingredient of costs today; that it has an understanding that constitutionally the States have the powers to co-operate together in price surveillance or control; and that the Commonwealth Government has been looking towards the money which would be saved by the Commonwealth, the States and local government-an amount of about $700m-being directed towards public works which could re-employ people. The billions of dollars saved by a consensus from the general population and from commerce and industry could also steady down unemployment and create re-employment. There is no inconsistency whatsoever in the policies. They are the same policies as we announced before. I simply repeat that it is of considerable gratification to the Government that day by day there is a growing consensus outside this chamber.

—The Opposition is being demolished in the hole of its own digging. My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. I refer to the drought in Australia-the worst in 25 years-and to the serious economic and social consequences of it. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the Government's approach to preserving and enhancing this continent's most valuable and scarce resource, water?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Teague's question is a vital one in the face of the fact that Australia, particularly the two eastern States of Victoria and New South Wales, is facing a drought which is potentially the worst on record. Very comprehensive temporary measures are being advanced by the Commonwealth Government, which are being criticised by the Australian Labor Party, to mitigate the effects of the drought and to preserve stocks, particularly the breeding stocks. Those measures are being taken in the short term. In the longer term, of course, it is necessary to ensure that all water in this most arid continent should be used to its best advantage. I announced several days ago the formation of the National Water Research Council, a body which has been approved and recommended by the Australian Water Resources Council, which is the Council of Ministers of the States and the Commonwealth. I announced its formation and its composition of some very well-equipped Australians to undertake a task similar to that which is undertaken in the energy field by the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council. That has been widely acclaimed as a major step forward.

ANSWER.PARA: I announced the co-ordination of work between the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, my own Department, the Bureau of Mineral Resources, Geology and Geophysics, the Australian Atomic Energy Commission and the Bureau of Meteorology to pull together within the Commonwealth sphere, under the scrutiny of a secretariat of my Department, the Australian expertise and technology in this field. I announced that the study on the water perspective of Australia for the year 2000 was progressing speedily and I hoped a report would be available in April. In addition, in the last Budget there was an increase of some 28 per cent in the money put aside for national water resources by the Commonwealth, in conjunction with the States on a dollar for dollar basis. We regard water conservation-the control of water both in terms of quality and quantity-as the major resource issue in Australia today. We will continue so to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. We have had a constant call from Government members for wage restraint and a wage freeze. I ask: Is it not reasonable for wage earners to ask for increases to meet the escalating prices of essential goods and services-brought about in many cases, I might add, by higher sales taxes imposed by this Government? Further, will doctors, lawyers, dentists and other professional and business enterprises also be asked to freeze their fees? Since last year the cost of full family cover in a medical fund has risen by an average of $150. How can average breadwinners afford such extra costs unless they receive adequate compensation for the only thing they can offer; that is, their labour?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the latter part of the question, it is the intention of the Government to seek a wage freeze in all sections of the community. That means that throughout the community, including its various service areas, the Government will pursue restraint in the upward movement of charges. Firstly, we must get agreement between the Commonwealth, the States and local government as to areas of responsibility. Secondly, we must reach outwards -as we are already doing-to commerce and industry and ask for co-operation. We will be looking everywhere for that kind of restraint. That will apply to professional people who make charges. There is always in this place a tendency to cite doctors as evil. The fact is that the great majority of them render a very dedicated, skilled and often selfless service to the community at large. Honourable senators may be interested to know that in recent years the average real earnings of the medical profession have fallen.
—That is because they have been dodging tax.

—It is easy to sneer and say that they are dodging tax. The fact is that in this place one can knock anybody. Under the privilege of parliament one can attempt to cripple the reputation of people outside, as the Australian Labor Party has sought to do in the tax issue. I repeat that the great bulk of the professional people of Australia are highly--
—You are full of wind.

—'Full of wind' is a very good description of the Labor lawyers, although they are somewhat deflated at the moment. Of course, the Government appreciates that the upward pressure of prices will affect the wage earner. In the recent Budget we brought down a package of relief by way of tax cuts, increased family allowance, interest subsidy on homes and a whole range of other actions. These measures represent, in a net sense after tax, a gain in real wages of some $17 to $20 a week. That is our recognition that the wage earners have extra burdens to bear. It is our recognition that a bearing down on prices will not be achieved until there is wage restraint. That is now becoming the consensus throughout Australia.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce to the Petroleum Products Freight Subsidy Scheme which at present ensures that the maximum wholesale price in country areas is not more than one cent above capital city prices. I also refer to the review currently being conducted. The Minister would appreciate the sensitivity with which people in the more isolated areas view the price of fuel because of distances between regional centres, large numbers of remote communities and their dependence on road and sea transport as their lifeline. Will the Minister ensure that the special problems of the more remote areas are given full consideration during the review and that we are not faced with a further increase in the margin?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Petroleum Products Freight Subsidy Scheme is, as its name describes, a subsidy on freight costs of petroleum products. It is a fact that there has been a recent change to the system which means that freight costs are now subsidised to a differential of one cent instead of 0.44c per litre, as was the case previously. So there has been a reduction in the degree of subsidisation with the differential now standing at one cent instead of 0.44c. That review was undertaken by the Government because the scheme was proving to be ever more costly. There was a cost last year of $147m as against a Budget estimate of $129m and there were also certain problems of abuse in the system. It is clear from the experience all of us have had around Australia-this reflects the interjections made during the course of the question-that despite that freight subsidy scheme variations do exist between the retail prices of petroleum products in various localities. That is because the subsidy is one on freight. That does not affect other differentials, including different prices, different discounts and so on. So the scheme does not impose a uniform cost or price for petroleum products. The scheme reduces the cost of freighting petroleum products to the more distant parts of Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: With respect to the Northern Territory, which is, of course, remote from the large centres of population, it is clearly understood by the Government that the freight subsidy is of particular interest and concern. I understand Senator Kilgariff's concern to maintain some element of subsidisation because of the difficulties suffered by the Northern Territory. I am sure that those are the sorts of considerations which will very much influence the Government in its consideration of the future of this scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs whether the Government is committed to a settled policy of supporting regimes in South East Asia which are corrupt and dictatorial and which have a well- established record of using military force to keep their own people in a state of misery and poverty. I refer in particular to the Republic of the Philippines. Is the Government aware of the appalling conditions in the rural areas of the Philippines which are the background for the arrest and projected trial next month of Father Brian Gore? Further, having tolerated the murder of six Australian journalists in Timor to appease the Indonesian Government, does this Government now propose to sacrifice Father Gore to appease the Philippines Government? If not, will the Government make an early and definite statement dissociating this country from the ugly and blatant oppression of the ordinary people in the Philippines by their Government and exert immediate and effective pressure on that Government to see that the interests of Father Gore are not cynically betrayed? Will the Minister also consider seriously suggesting to the Government that it should be made clear that Australian aid to the Philippines is contingent on a better record of human rights in that country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The matter of aid to the Philippines has been raised by a number of honourable senators in recent days. Comments and claims by the honourable senators concerned have been referred to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and I have not yet had his response on that matter. I think the more general matter of South East Asia opens a very big subject for a response. Whether the Minister chooses to treat that matter in a general way or to be more specific would depend on any further information that Senator Mason may wish to seek in respect of the general subject of South East Asian regimes.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as Father Gore is concerned, I have made some comments on this matter from time to time on behalf of the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The Minister has advised me that we are continuing to watch developments in this case. There was a hearing of the charge against Father Gore on 10 November. This matter has been adjourned to 6 December. The Minister for Defence Support, Mr Viner, said that while in Manila he had sought and received an assurance from the Philippines Defence Minister that the proper processes of law would be available to Father Gore and that the Australian Embassy would have access to him and to the courts when any hearing was listed. I will draw the other parts of the question to the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Am I to take it from that answer that the Government has decided to abandon Father Gore to the tender mercies of Filipino law?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not know what Senator Mason is capable of taking from anything. I have indicated from time to time the interest of the Government of Australia in respect of the charges against Father Gore. I have now said that the Australian Embassy would have access to him and the courts when any hearing was listed. That assurance was received recently in Manila by the Minister for Defence Support. What can be taken from that other than the fact that the proper processes of law will be available to Father Gore, as assured by the Philippines Defence Minister, and that the Embassy will be given access to him and to the courts? There is very active concern and interest by our Embassy in this matter, as there would be for Australians who faced similar charges or who were in similar circumstances to those in this case. If Senator Mason wishes to make some assumptions, as he puts it, I have to leave that to him. I can only reiterate that there will be access to the courts and to the processes that I have outlined, as advised to me by the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TAX EXEMPT STATUS: RIGHT TO LIFE ORGANISATION

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle either in her capacity as Minister for Finance or as the Minister representing the Treasurer. Under what conditions do associations obtain tax exempt status for donations to their funds? Has there been an application by the organisation known as Right to Life for such status? If so, what was the result? Did that organisation have reason to believe that donations to its funds were in the course of being approved as a tax deduction, as indicated in a fund raising letter to Sydney lawyers dated 7 October 1982?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — In general, tax exempt status is granted to organisations as a result of a decision of the Government. The organisations are listed and donations to them are tax deductible. The general approach is that they are non-profit organisations and that they operate in accordance with the provisions of the legislation. From time to time the names of organisations are added to the list. I am not aware of the status of the Right to Life Association . I do not know whether any application has been made by that organisation or whether it had any reason to claim, as suggested by Senator Giles, that tax exemption status was imminent. I would need to refer that to the Treasurer and get advice from him on the particular organisation that has been mentioned by Senator Giles.

—The Senate will be interested to know that I wish to ask a question which seeks information. My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory, concerns the future of this building. Has the Minister seen the plans in the part under King's Hall which indicate that when the new Parliament House is completed this building will remain in the foreground? On the other hand, has he had drawn to his attention, as I have had drawn to my attention, plans prepared by the National Capital Development Commission which show the new Parliament House in existence and this building removed? I ask: What is the future of this building, who owns the building and who will decide its future? Will it be left in the hands of that infamous statutory authority, the NCDC?

—Mr President, I have a feeling that you probably know more of the answer to this question than I do. I believe that the ownership of this Parliament House resides in the Commonwealth of Australia and that the Parliament is responsible for its management. Consequently that would come under the direction of the Presiding Officers and through the various committees of the House. Therefore I would say that any decision that might be taken as to the future use of Parliament House would depend on the agreement of the Parliament and the Presiding Officers. As I see it, the NCDC, although it would certainly have a power in respect of providing advice on the building's future, to the various committees of the Parliament and to the Government, would certainly have no say in the final determination as to what happens to this building.
—I direct a supplementary question to you, Mr President. What are you going to do with this building?

—Senator Lewis asked me what I am going to do with this building. I shall respond very quickly by saying that it is not my responsibility. The future of this building will rest with the Parliament itself and the people of Australia, if I can put it on that basis. I shall go one step further. Reference was made to the National Capital Development Commission. I remind all honourable senators that some years ago the then Senator Wright introduced a Bill into this place to give the Parliament total control-I emphasise total control-of the Parliamentary Triangle from Capital Hill right down to the lake. Let there be no fear that anything can be done to this building other than by a decision that would be made, if necessary, by the Parliament and the people.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. In 1981-82, Australian Paper Manufacturers Ltd, according to the annual company report, made a profit of $63. 3m, an increase of $8m on the previous year's profit. However, this company closed down its Tasmanian operation at Geeveston causing approximately 350 workers to be thrown on the scrap heap, at the same time investing $160m in the Maryvale plant in Victoria. Despite increased profits this company has reduced jobs in Tasmania. If the Government proposes a freeze on wages, how will it guarantee that companies and industries will use their increased profits to provide more jobs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not possible for me to comment on the thousands of individual decisions which are made by companies with respect to employment. One thing which is self-evident and which ought to be evident to all honourable senators is that the employment of people by private industry is possible only if that employment gives rise to a profit. If it does not, there is no basis for the investment and, of course, the employment must in time come to an end. I will ask the Minister whom I represent in this place to examine the facts which have been put forward by the honourable senator in her question. I am not clear, however, that there could be any finding other than that in the particular circumstances the profitability or lack of profitability of particular parts of the enterprise was such that it was not possible to continue with them.

ANSWER.PARA: I think the question is an important one and warrants further examination and a considered reply. I do not believe that it is helpful, in Australia's current circumstances, to produce a resentment about profits in the context of discussions which are aimed at increasing employment opportunities. It is a fact that it is only when industry is profitable that employment will be created. Whilst it is true that a substantial part of the work force in Australia is employed by bodies which do not have to make a profit, namely, the Commonwealth and State public services and statutory authorities, although many of the statutory authorities have some commercial sanctions on them, those jobs can be financed only by taxation. That taxation can accrue only from the general profitability and enterprise of the community. We are in a situation in which I believe all sides of politics should try to accept that it would be in the interests of all Australians and in particular in the interests of those Australians currently in employment and those seeking employment to maintain profitability of enterprise because, without that, the position must worsen.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. I refer to the recent report from the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia on the investigation into the establishment of an Australian uranium enrichment industry. I ask: Why did the Group not consider current research being done in the world in relation to laser enrichment technology for uranium? Is the Minister aware that the United States Government has been spending hundreds of millions of dollars annually for most of the last decade, looking into laser enrichment technology?

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Minister aware that the centrifuge and gaseous diffusion technology involves vast capital expenditures on the plants and that it also requires vast amounts of electrical energy? Is he aware that, by comparison, laser enrichment technology holds the promise of being a whole magnitude less in capital cost and uses something like one-5,000th of the amount of electrical energy to process it? In view of that, will the Minister assure the Senate that the Government will not be compromised into supporting any outdated technology such as the gaseous diffusion process and that of the Urenco-Centec type as outlined in the report, without first looking intelligently at what research is going on in the world?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Both UEGA and the Government have been looking at four different technologies. As Senator MacGibbon said, the gaseous diffusion technology, which is very much the French technology, uses vast amounts of electricity. In fact, some four nuclear power plants support the gaseous diffusion plant. UEGA reached the conclusion that on that premise alone gaseous diffusion would be too costly in terms of electric power. The Group looked at two other methods prior to coming to its conclusion on the centrifuge process. It looked at chemical exchange or Chemex. That in itself is a fascinating technology. It is a device which, by a chemical process, aims to change uranium to the enriched isotope U235. The belief is that that technology is still essentially in the laboratory stage. It has prospects. Its commercial possibilities are probably a decade ahead, but in any case it can be added as a modular increment to any plant that is built before that time.

ANSWER.PARA: UEGA has been looking also at laser and has reached the same conclusions on it ; that is, that it is still in very much the experimental stage and that should it in fact prove capable of being a commercial venture it can be developed in the future as an addition. The advantages of centrifuge are: That it is a known and proven technology; that its costs are known; that all the details can be known about it now; that it uses very little electric power compared with other technologies; that it can be built in a relatively small segment first-say, one million separative work units or SWUs, as they are called-and, if necessary, one can add new technologies to it in the future. The Government will certainly , with UEGA, be looking to any breakthrough. Of course, it would be willing to take such information into account for the future. I am grateful for the question. It is very much under study by UEGA and the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today Senator Ryan asked me a question relating to the Northern Territory. I sought from the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Wilson, any further information that he might have. He advised me that the only agreement which exists between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory Government regarding proposals to amend legislation affecting Aboriginals is that which the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs announced on 2 June 1982. In that announcement the Minister indicated that the Commonwealth Government intended, in parallel with the Northern Territory Government, to introduce legislation designed to give effect to a package of proposals which had been the subject of lengthy negotiations to which I referred in my earlier answer. It is the Minister's understanding that the reference made by the Chief Minister to an agreement between the Northern Territory Government and the Commonwealth refers to the intention of both governments to enact legislation to give effect to that package of proposals as was outlined in the Minister's public announcement of 2 June 1982. We know of no other agreement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in Question Time Senator Button asked me a question about unemployment figures in Frankston. He asked me further about an instruction to the Commonwealth Employment Service about talking to the Press. The question arose, apparently, out of a report in the Age of 16 November. I am able now to give the Senate a little more advice on the latter part of the question. Apparently there was an instruction to zone managers and employment office managers concerning the procedures to be followed when dealing with the media. In brief, it instructed managers that they should not talk to State-wide media without first obtaining permission from the regional office. That instruction reinforced a longstanding policy that local managers of the CES were not to comment to the Press on labour market matters or CES business levels without first obtaining the permission of the regional office. However, it is thought there is some inconsistency in the instruction as it now applies in view of the recent decision to publish, on a regular basis, details of CES business transactions.

ANSWER.PARA: I am told that it is now proposed to advise regional directors that employment office managers will be permitted to make comments on their local labour market area to any branch of the media which may approach them. It will still be necessary for any comments relating to the labour market for the State as a whole to be made from the regional office. That latter part of the further information I have given is consistent with the position I expressed in the answer which I gave without the benefit of this advice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation about articles which appeared in the Australian Associated Press and a news item. Before coming to Parliament House this morning I turned on my television set to watch the National Today Show. In the course of that show a news reader stated that a Bill had passed the Senate last night with the support of six Government senators of whom I happened to be one. He went on to say that the Senate had passed a Bill which would take away the powers of the Senate to block Supply and that there would never again be another 1975. Upon arriving at Parliament House I went to the Library to see whether I could get a transcript of that report. I was given a report by AAP which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate has passed a Labor Party Bill to lessen its power to bring down governments by blocking or threatening to block Supply.
It went on to state:
The Bill's passage was ensured last night when six Government Senators crossed the floor to support the Bill.
I believe that that statement is incorrect. If one looks at page 2018 of the Senate Hansard of 28 October, one will see that part of what I said that evening was:

I will not support anything that would weaken the powers of this chamber, which is the House of review and which is responsible to the States. I represent Queensland and I want to ensure that whatever is done in this place is right, proper and appropriate for the constituents I represent. I would not want to do anything that would weaken the power of the Senate. Therefore, I will not support clause 8 or clause 9.
Both of those clauses were taken out of the Bill. Therefore, I believe that the statement made on the news this morning and in the AAP report are totally incorrect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented, and I wish to make a statement on the same subject. I did not hear the news report to which Senator Bonner referred and which was broadcast this morning. However, I have a copy of an Australian Associated Press version of what happened when we voted in the Senate last night on the private member's Bill brought in by Senate Evans. I too, in debate on that Bill, indicated that in voting for the second reading I was voting for the Bill to go into Committee. I did not endorse all the things that were in that Bill in its then state, and I indicated that my subsequent vote on the Bill would depend on whether it was suitably amended in Committee, particularly in relation to the Senate's powers. This news release suggests that my vote last night endorsed a move to lessen the power of the Senate, but that is certainly not what I had indicated.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also mention another section of the release. It says:

The original Bill provided that an extraordinary double dissolution could only be ordered by the Governor-General because of a motion of no confidence being carried against the Government in the House of Representatives or if the Government chose to break a sustained deadlock between the two Houses with an election. But Senator Martin last week successfully moved an amendment to delete a provision directly removing the Senate's Supply blocking power.

That section muddles two issues. I moved an amendment relating to the Governor- General's powers. I moved an amendment which took off a limitation on the Governor-General's powers, which was one section of the Bill with which I was not happy. I certainly voted for an amendment which deleted the provisions directly removing the Senate's Supply blocking power. I supported that that should not be part of the Bill and that the Senate should retain its power in relation to Supply. However, I did not move the amendment. I mention that to clarify what is a bit garbled. I am only sorry that it is possible that this news release, which has a number of facts quite muddled, might lead to adverse comment and misunderstanding as to what my views were on what were really three quite separate issues in the Bill: First, the question of fixed term parliaments ; secondly, the question of the Senate's power on Supply; and, thirdly, the powers of the Governor-General.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a statement on the same subject. I join with my two colleagues in expressing objection to the slovenly reportage which has obviously occurred overnight by the media of this country-it happens too often these days-of what has happened in this Senate. It has been constantly the case in regard to this Bill. It can lead only to confusion in the minds of people in the various States as to what has happened. Clearly, the report which has been made, and of which I now have a copy in my hands, is so inconsistent in itself; it talks about the lessening of powers for blocking Supply and also about Senator Martin moving an amendment, which she did not do. But the provisions on Supply blocking came out of the Bill. It will probably lead people only to confusion.

SPEECH.PARA: These matters do not make me particularly uptight except they mean, therefore, that the public has a very unclear understanding of what was done by the Senate last night-namely, to pass, purely and simply, a fixed term Bill with the complete deletion from it of any provisions which would have reduced Supply powers or anything of that sort, or any changes in the Governor-General's powers . Those were gone. The Bill was pruned down to the single issue only. I want to express the fact that I deplore the slovenliness of the media of this country which do not bother to ask anyone about what has happened and, therefore, do not get an accurate idea of the result of the deliberations of this Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation . I have been misreported by the Canberra Times, and therefore I claim to have been misrepresented. It is reported in an article in today's edition of the Canberra Times, under the heading 'Carrick labled ''jargon freak'' ', that during Question Time yesterday the Leader of the Government in the Senate ( Senator Sir John Carrick), in reply to a question, had stated that the conditions of the 1930s were very different from today's recession. I shall quote directly from the article. It continues:

SPEECH.PARA: In those days,-
That is, the 1930s-
the Senator reminisced-
and Senator Sir John Carrick was quoted as saying: ''there was in fact negative interest rate and negative inflation''. The article continued:
''What's negative inflation?'' yelled Senator Walsh . . . in exasperation . . .

What I, in fact, said was: 'What are negative interest rates?' It is possible, of course, to have negative inflation. Indeed in the 1930s there was negative inflation for a couple of years. It is possible to have negative real interest rates at a time of positive inflation. It is not possible to have negative interest rates at a time of negative inflation. In the last couple of days, Senator Sir John Carrick has displayed a wide knowledge of economic theories--

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the honourable senator to come back to his personal explanation which is about misrepresentation in the Press and not to debate the issue.

—I am reported to have asked: 'What is negative inflation?' I understand perfectly what negative inflation is. I have no idea in the wide world what negative interest rates, accompanied by negative inflation, are. Indeed I believe that it is not possible. Perhaps Senator Sir John Carrick might care to explain what negative inflation is.
—Order! The honourable senator will not debate the issue.
—And what negative interest rates are. I am sure that we would grant him leave to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I wish to make a personal explanation relating to an Australian Associated Press report on the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill 1981. An AAP report on this matter suggests that:

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate has passed an Australian Labor Party Bill to lessen its power to bring down governments by blocking or threatening to block Supply.
The report goes on to state:
. . . six Liberal Party senators voted with the ALP, the Australian Democrats and Independent Senator Brian Harradine to pass the Bill which aims to set fixed -term parliaments.
The report then continues with some other considerations.

Frankly, I must have been at the wrong meeting because what is suggested as having occurred did not, in fact, occur in this place. I make it perfectly clear that I understood the original purposes of the Bill. It dealt with the questions of power of the Senate, fixed terms of parliament and the powers of the Governor -General. What we ended up with was a true fixed term parliaments Bill. I felt quite happy to vote for that measure. Everybody knows that I am on record as standing for the full powers of the Senate. I thank the Senate for allowing me to make this personal explanation.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a short personal explanation on the same subject. It is a matter of great importance when a Press report such as this entirely misrepresents what the vote of the Senate was. However I do not necessarily, as Senator Missen said, blame it on to the reporters. I think it is possibly more likely that it was a mischievous Press release from Senator Evans. Last week he suggested in a Press release that--
—Order! The honourable senator is straying a little wide of making a personal explanation.

—Yes. The Bill that the Australian Democrats voted for was not the basis of report under the Australian Associated Press dateline today. I moved an amendment to increase the powers of the Senate on Supply. That amendment was not carried by the Senate but it shows our position. We voted solely in favour of fixed terms for Parliaments. The Senate will recall that we even changed the name of the Bill to make sure that it related only to fixed terms and had nothing whatsoever to do with Supply. I am quite sure that Senator Haines, Senator Siddons, Senator Chipp and Senator Mason would not at any stage have voted for any Bill which had such a clause in it.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Resolution Concerning Polish Workers

That, notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders and the sessional order relating to the consideration of Government papers, Government papers tabled on 9 November 1982 (General Business, Orders of the Day Nos. 202- 205) and the papers tabled on 11 November 1982 by the Minister for Finance be now considered pursuant to sessional order in the order indicated on the list distributed to honourable senators and that such papers take precedence over other Government papers tabled this day.
