DEBATE.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF NATIONAL DEVELOPMENT AND ENERGY

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1981-82
Debate resumed from 9 November, on motion by Senator Robertson:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise three matters on the report of the Department of National Development and Energy, if I can do so in the absurdly short time of 10 minutes given to honourable senators to comment on these important documents. The first matter relates to the heading 'Legislative Matters' under the general title 'Uranium' in Chapter 7 of the report. In that chapter one finds this sentence:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government announced in June 1981 its intention to establish a new legal base for the development, regulation and control of nuclear activities in Australia.

In that short sentence one has evidence of 16 months of dithering and procrastination in relation to one aspect of the development of the mining of uranium which is absolutely fundamental and of grave concern to many members of the community; that is, the legislative framework within which the industry is to be conducted, if it is to be conducted at all. The policy of the Australian Labor Party is, of course, well known. It is that there will be a phasing out of existing mines and that in the meantime their activities will be subject to the most stringent conditions particularly in relation to policies on overseas purchases. But in that phasing out, that transition period, there is obviously a need for a legislative structure to guide their operation.

For that transition period it is intolerable that the Government still has not produced for the Parliament a legislative framework different from the 1950s framework which still governs the industry generally. That framework was, of course, evolved at a time when Australian uranium was used to fuel the nuclear armaments programs of our allies-one thinks of the Rum Jungle deposits and so on . Therefore, they are framed in a way that is most deleterious in its impact on civil liberties. There have been debates in this chamber on that matter. I have not time to review them all. What I am saying very clearly is that the Labor Party is dismayed that after 16 months there is still no evidence from the Government of a legislative framework more conducive to operations for peaceful purposes as it is alleged-for commercial profit, as it is said-of mining activities in Australia.

Of course, insofar as the sentence that I have quoted talks about the development, regulation and control of nuclear activities in Australia, I make it extremely clear that as far as the Australian Labor Party is concerned that could be a much wasted effort. I quote from the policy adopted at our National Conference in July, which stated:
The Labor Party will not permit the treatment, storage or enrichment of nuclear materials in Australia nor domestic use of nuclear power.

Therefore, as we see it, there is not the need for a regulatory framework dealing with those matters so to preoccupy the Government that it is unable to bring with reasonable speed to the Parliament a new legislative framework to deal with mining during the transitional period of which I have spoken. There is no doubt in the community's mind that a strong national legislative framework is required. Insofar as the paragraph in the report of the Department of National Development and Energy speaks of developing this legislative framework in consultation with the States and the Northern Territory, I say once again that it is intolerable to think that the States, the Northern Territory or any other section of the Australian community could in any way hinder, retard or control-a term which is perhaps extremely strong and not so intended-the industry. But at all times it is essential that the national Government retain through its export controls complete, utter and inalienable legislative and governmental control of this industry. That must always be the objective.

I raise briefly two other matters referred to in chapter 13 of the report, headed 'Management-Review of Commonwealth Functions'. In other words, it concerns the implementation of the razor gang report in this Department. One finds this sentence:
The Soil Conservation Program to be transferred to the States.

That fairly innocuous sentence obscures the fact that in relation to the greatest threat to Australian agriculture, namely soil degradation, that great threat to half our export income, or 8 per cent of our national product, the national Government has declared that it no longer will be responsible for a soil conservation policy but rather will transfer such programs to the States. As recently as Friday 29 October an article by Geoff Sorby, under the headline ' Soil conservation policy is still blowing in the wind', appeared in the 'Rural Review' published in the Australian. The article stated:
It can be argued that Australia is blowing away and nobody, particularly the Federal Government, appears to care a damn.

He points out that for every tonne of grain produced the concomitant effect is that 13 tonnes of topsoil can be lost. On the famous Darling Downs in Queensland soil losses have reached 50 tonnes a hectare in some places. In Victoria alone there are about 100,000 hectares of land affected by salinity. It is the same story of wind and water ravage throughout the continent. The land has also been ravaged by bad farm management practices. The Government, having announced a much vaunted soil conservation program just prior to the 1980 election, has washed its hands of that program and has pretended to transfer that responsibility to the States. I can say, without prejudging or pre-empting the recommendations of a current Senate Committee into the matter, that when some six senators looked into this matter, they were utterly dismayed that the national Government should abdicate this responsibility. As Mr Kerin, the shadow Minister for Primary Industry, has said:
It is the Commonwealth's function to provide leadership and provide the support for a national program. Land degradation is a national problem.

The Australian Labor Party has stated that in co-operation with State governments it will promote and fund a national soil conservation program. It will restore Commonwealth involvement by providing $4m to the States for approved programs in the first year, rising to $20m after four years. It is essential that that national involvement take place because the States piecemeal , the rural industry research funds piecemeal, cannot solve this tremendous problem facing Australian agriculture. The rural industry research funds, for example, direct their efforts to the commodities with which they deal. This is a multi-disciplinary problem and it needs all the resources and leadership which a national Government ought to bring to it. The Labor Party will do that and I hope that farmers and farm organisations take note of that fact.
Finally, and briefly, in the razor gang report one reads:
Commonwealth to withdraw from regional development activities. Regional Development Program and Decentralisation Advisory Board to be abolished.

That has been carried out, once again in the teeth of a Senate committee report. In the report of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources entitled ' The Development of Bauxite, Alumina and Aluminium Industries' which reviewed the impact on regional Australia of these great projects using our great natural resources, it was concluded that the Commonwealth had a very real obligation to provide for regional adjustment. This is particularly so in regard to the social infrastructure of regions which are unduly burdened by the migration of workers and the siting of these tremendous resource projects, communities which cannot bear either the social infrastructure or geneal disruption that occurs, whether it is in relation to housing, education, health facilities or mere social and recreational amenities. Those regional support schemes, which are so essential if the vision of a decentralised regionally robust Australia is to be achieved, need to be put forward and funded by a national Government which cares about the regions of Australia. Once again, the Labor Party will do that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a brief moment of the Senate's time to respond to matters raised by Senator Tate. He raised three matters. The first one related to the legislative framework for nuclear energy in Australia. I have to inform the Senate that in fact two measures will come before the Parliament in the autumn session. One measure will deal with the international situation-the non- proliferation situation-and the other will deal with the domestic situation, being a new kind of legislative framework for the Australian Atomic Energy Commission and the work it performs. The Government has recognised over the years, as has previous governments, that the previous Act was more a defence Act and should be brought up to date. Other governments did not do so. This Government will do so by the autumn session. The Senate, therefore, will have the advantage of being able to study the measure.

SPEECH.PARA: What has happened during the time this Government has been in office is that the essential recommendations of the Fox Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry have been carried out. A wide range of activities have been undertaken to implement the recommendations of that inquiry. This Senate has had the benefit of that literature. Codes have been established in Australia. We have, firstly, a mining code relating to radioactive materials and, secondly, a code for the handling of radioactive materials, both minor and major, throughout Australia. All this has been done. All this consensus has been reached. Therefore, a great deal of progress has been made in recent years and is continuing to be made.

It is not easy to put together the kind of legislation that is contemplated. Senator Tate referred to a delay of 15 months. Interdepartmental committees have been working on this matter. Honourable senators should bear in mind also that we have a Commonwealth Constitution and we have States. Therefore, we have to put together legislation which is constitutional and sustainable in the High Court and which will work. We are doing this. Senator Tate has said that we ought to enforce our export controls. We have shown-this was evident by our action in relation to Fraser Island-that we are prepared to do those kinds of things. We have found no necessity whatsoever to do so in terms of uranium mining and milling and of prospective enrichment because the States and the Territories concerned have agreed to co-operate to the fullest extent. I repeat that the standards of safeguards adopted in Australia are of the highest level. The recent agreement between the States and the Commonwealth Government fully implements the decision of the International Atomic Energy Agency and other international bodies regarding radioactive materials. We have advanced an enormous distance in that regard.

I find it very hard indeed to reconcile the unqualified statement of Senator Tate about the Australian Labor Party's policy-Senator Tate said that the Australian Labor Party was opposed totally to the treatment, storage or enrichment of uranium-with the fact that during the South Australian election campaign the Labor Party deliberately said and represented to the Australian people that the elements of uranium at Roxby Downs would be part of a compact which would be proceeded with by an incoming Labor government. This is a new factor. There is no doubt in the world that the headlines in the newspapers were meant to intimate that Roxby Downs, which depends upon the conjunctive development of minerals, such as copper, and uranium would in fact proceed under a Labor government. It is quite clear from what Senator Tate has said that that will not be so, that Roxby Downs cannot be considered to be a project that had been agreed upon by governments beforehand. The Labor Party has been completely ambiguous about this matter. I am sorry that that should be so. Indeed, it is of immense importance to the people of Australia to know what the Labor Party means . Does it mean, for example, that it would oppose the construction of uranium enrichment plants in Australia?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—Do I see Senator Tate nodding? Am I able to say that the Labor Party would oppose any enrichment plant in Australia unequivocally and , therefore, that it would be futile for the Bannon Labor Government in South Australia to have any discussions with the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia ? Am I able to say to UEGA that the Labor Party would be opposing that plant and , therefore that UEGA should not have discussions with the Bannon Labor Government? Is this what is being said today? It is very important indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: I move to the second question. Senator Tate intimated that the full thrust of soil conservation was a Commonwealth matter under the Constitution and that somehow it had been buckpassed to the States with no benefit to the States. Nothing could be further from the truth. The fact is that the constitutional responsibility for soil conservation is wholly with the States. The States over the years have always accepted it totally. Most of the States have developed first class departments with first class technology. My Government offered, as a supplement, $3m a year for additional work on soil conservation. Senator Tate's intimation was that that had disappeared. That is completely untrue. That $3m was added to and absorbed in the tax revenue disbursements; so each year the States are getting that money. All that has happened is that the Commonwealth, instead of administering the money itself, has passed it to the States. I repeat : It is true that sovereignty over soil conservation lies totally with the States. It is not true that the Commonwealth had that responsibility. It is true that there was a peripheral supplement and that that money has been transferred.

Mention was made of regional development and of the movement away from it. Regional development within a State is wholly a State matter. What has not been said is that the funds for regional development have been increased enormously by the Commonwealth. Seven years ago the amount of money passed by the then Labor Government to the States by way of Grants Commission local government disbursements was $79.9m. It is six times that amount today-in excess of $400m. The Commonwealth has introduced a scheme whereby 2 per cent of revenue goes to local government. That is a huge amount of additional funds for regional development and has been one of the most important factors for local government.

This is not a report of no progress on the three matters mentioned. Rather the Government has acted very vigorously and successfully on legislation for the controls of nuclear and radioactive materials. It has transferred the money for soil conservation, and the States have gained by that money and absorbed it. With respect to regional development, it is no bad thing that local government should today be getting six times the amount it got seven years ago. Even allowing for inflation, that is a tremendously larger amount than it got previously.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -The report from the Education Research and Development Committee is an unfortunate report. It is unfortunate because it is the last report of that Committee. I read from the general comments made at the beginning of the report:

SPEECH.PARA: On 30 April 1981 the Prime Minister announced, as a result of the Government's decisions following the Review of Commonwealth Functions, that the Education Research and Development Committee (ERDC) would be abolished and its programs terminated.
Effective abolition of the Committee was accomplished on 5 June 1981 when its members were formally advised that their appointments ceased from that date.

The report goes on in the general comments under 'Policy', in relation to principles and procedures, to note that the Committee was advised and, of course , had to take account of the fact that it was ceasing operations. It attempted to terminate in its last year of office the various educational, research and development projects that it had in train. The report itself says:
The Government, in deciding to terminate ERDC programs, determined that established commitments and immediate ongoing obligations should be discharged.

Some of those projects were taken up through the Australian Education Council and some were funded directly by the Government in other ways. However, it remains the case that the body in Australia which had been established to co- ordinate research development in this area has now been abolished. Yet we find a member of the Government saying in this place, in response to another item, that the Government, in fact very much supports the notion of co-ordination of educational research. One finds it rather intriguing that the Government can abolish the Committee which was undertaking that and at the same time say that it is intent on fostering co-operation.

The Education Research and Development Committee was an extremely important committee in educational research terms. It had had a number of distinguished chairmen and on its board had gathered together from all States representatives of various education groups. The Committee, because of that wide representation, was able to look at applications from the education establishment in Australia and to fund those projects which it believed would have a practical ongoing effect. Interestingly enough, recently the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) talked about, and even criticised, education researchers for not having done enough of that. If one has a look at the last guidelines of the ERDC one finds that, in fact, that is precisely what the ERDC's guidelines were attempting to do. The ERDC was attempting to disseminate information and to generate research which was of a practical kind to the practitioner in the classroom. It is very interesting that the Minister for Education, who is newly arrived in his portfolio, could make those types of criticisms having presided over the abolition of the one body which was doing what he was advocating. It, indeed, is a pity when one goes through the various types of research which were described in this last report to see, in fact, that no longer will we have that co-ordinating, expert body. It was not a body of Ministers of Education, most of whom presumably have had no professional or research training in that area to deliberate on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is absolutely inaccurate, Senator.

—Nor was it a group of directors-general of education, who also are not the type of people to be deliberating on this matter. The fact is that the Government established, supported and continued to support the Committee over so many years. If Senator Baume is interested he might like to have a look at the record of the debate on this report last year, when the Government made glowing references to the Committee that it was about to abolish.
—Your comments about Ministers are quite gratuitous and inaccurate.

—Mr Deputy President, perhaps the Minister would like to speak afterwards. This Committee has been of extreme use in this area. It is a pity now that it will not continue. The role of research in Australia has taken a severe battering, not only in education but in all other areas.
—We cannot afford it.

—The usefulness of research has, of course, often been debated. It is only recently that the universities have felt an obligation to speak more to the community about the usefulness of the types of research that they have been engaged in. One now sees from various universities, colleges of advanced education and technical and further education colleges an endeavour to communicate to the community in general the usefulness of their research tasks.
—Self-perpetuating oligarchies.

—I believe that if we do not look into the excessive rundown of our research establishments we could very well find ourselves in a very short time without the technological base that would be necessary to go into the year 2000. Senator Martyr interrupts with the old worn out cliches that I would have hoped somebody in this place would not again mouth. The fact is that research is an extremely important underpinning to any technological society such as ours. One needs only to look at areas such as technology, bio-technology and communications to see that if we do not vastly increase the funds to research establishments around Australia we will be not only behind but so far behind that it would be impossible for us to catch up to those societies which have looked at this matter, such as West Germany, Japan, Switzerland and the United States of America, and which have heavily increased their research budgets in recent years. They know where to invest money. Investing in research is not a cost, it is an investment. It is a pity that the abolition of the Education Research and Development Committee was not connected with a more general type of proposition on the part of the Government as to what it saw as necessary in terms of the promotion of research in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe the time has now come to seek to bring together the various research funding bodies to form an Australian research foundation. This particular body would, I believe, be capable of not only taking money from governments but also seeking money from private enterprise. The usefulness of that operation would be seen if one were to look at the vast problems with tied grants which are currently arising in American universities. For example, there is the ethical problem of a professor teaching a technology course while he is the principal owner and operator of a technology development company, and setting his post- graduate students various tasks within the area that he may be able to profit from in his private capacity. Those ethical problems have exercised the minds of administrations and researchers in universities in Australia. I believe it is now time to seek the establishment of an intermediate body which will be able to receive either tied or open grants from private enterprise and to make arms length agreements with researchers to provide them with the ability to undertake that research without the ensuing ethical problems of tied grants.

I believe unless we look closely at this point in a very short time we will find ourselves entering into a range of very deleterious and extremely vicious debates within the higher education area about the notion of taking money from a variety of groups. Senator Martyr might remember the debates in the 1960s and early 1970s about funds which went from the Department of Defence to universities and of the enormous heartache and concern that that caused. I urge the Minister for Education to look at this matter. I hope that shortly he will announce the Government's initiatives in this area and that we will again be able to discuss a report from an education committee that has as part of its brief educational research and development.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in response to Senator Macklin's comments. To put Senator Macklin's comments into context, I want to set out just how extensive the role of the Department of Education and the portfolio of education is in supporting research. I start by saying that I am attracted by his idea that we should do in a flexible way the maximum amount we can for research, but I am not attracted by the comments he made quite gratuitously about Ministers for Education. I say to the honourable senator that it really is a vanity to assume that he is the only educated person around or the only person who may have had a background in research. He knows that what he said about the Ministers for Education is not true. I cannot imagine why he turned to a personal comment of that kind.

SPEECH.PARA: The total identifiable research expenditure which has been made available for universities in the six States actually increased from $82m in 1977 to $106m in 1981. Both figures are expressed in the same kinds of dollars to allow for inflation and to set out the magnitude of the increase in real terms of what has become available for research. That money is provided to the universities, much of it through my portfolio. If I wanted to look at Commonwealth support relating to educational research, I could do so under two broad categories: I could look at research performed in or commissioned by the portfolio and I could look at research carried out by external organisations where there is a portfolio contribution of money, guidance or advice. It is necessary to do this because Senator Macklin's comments went to research applied in the educational area generally. I have to set into perspective what the effects are likely to be of the wind down of the Education Research and Development Committee.

In the Department of Education-within the portfolio structure and including what is now known as the Curriculum Development Centre-there are now almost 30 current or proposed projects examining issues and schemes in the education field . The great majority of those enlist educational researchers from Australian universities and colleges of advanced education with the administrative assistance of liaison committees which are maintained through departmental resources. The Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, which is another part of my portfolio, has almost 50 projects in hand or contemplated. Most of these are evaluatory studies or reviews. The Commonwealth Schools Commission, which is another part of my portfolio, has about 15 further projects. In addition, about 42 further projects are still current from the Commonwealth's commitment under the ERDC, the matter which we are discussing this morning.

The departmental research and development work includes undertakings of long term dimensions, especially in producing materials for teaching English as a second language and in multicultural areas. Over several years analysis has been carried forward of issues involved in progress towards a national language policy. That is other research activity within my portfolio area. Projects which have been proposed by the Curriculum Development Centre include those for teaching mathematics to Aborigines, values and attitudes in a multicultural society and the attitudes of the Australian education community. Among the many projects of the Tertiary Education Commission is a study of the participation of young Australians in tertiary education, the attrition that occurs in education and manpower studies that are also important for planning and tertiary education . The work of the Schools Commission includes studies such as those of resource allocation within government school systems and of target recurrent resource standards for schools in the 1980s.

I observe that the research was carried out within the portfolio and some of it was extended beyond the portfolio with our support. If we look at that research extended beyond the portfolio commitments, the Department also participates in studies which are decided on by the Australian Education Council which consists of Commonwealth and State Ministers for Education about whom Senator Macklin chose to speak so disparagingly. I should cite the portfolio's involvement in Australian Studies in Student Performance and the Australian Co-operative Assessment Project. That involves a school focused achievement testing program. The Commonwealth is also represented on the Australian Education Council Committee on School Statistics. That Committee was set up in 1979. The Commonwealth is represented on the Steering Committee for Co-operative Study of School Enrolment Patterns which the AEC established in 1981. Further, the portfolio has taken part in the study which commenced in 1979 of issues relating to resources allocation in the government schools system of the six Australian States, the Australian Capital Territory, the Northern Territory and New Zealand . The Department has also participated in the work of the Commonwealth Aboriginal Studies Working Group which reported to the AEC in March this year.

The Commonwealth has also committed itself to providing half the cost of the Technical and Further Education National Centre for Research and Development Ltd . That commitment extends over a five-year period and up to a maximum Commonwealth contribution which is quite considerable-almost one-third of a million dollars a year. But that is another contribution to an ongoing research activity. The core program of research performed by the Australian Council for Educational Research is normally supported too by the Commonwealth and by the States in equal amount. In the present financial year, the Commonwealth is providing as its share almost $400,000. Of course, as I have said, that amount will be supplemented by an equal amount provided by the States.

The Commonwealth will also provide an expected $1.5m during the initial development period of the Australian Children's Television Foundation, whose purpose is to work for improvement in the quality and quantity of children's programs on Australian television-another area of development and research. Further, the Government announced in the last Budget that $100,000 would be made available in the current financial year to go towards research in the use of communications technology in Australia. We have established a Commonwealth-State advisory committee to try to get that under way. The importance of that is that with the development of satellite technology and the opportunities that that will present, for example, for distance education, we need to have that kind of research activity going ahead.

We should also remember the support given through the transition education program to evaluative studies at national and State levels and to the Australian National University clearing-house on transition education. By the end of 1982 the Commonwealth will have paid almost $300,000 to tertiary institutions for evaluation of the program and for research into transition education. More is provided this year. Senator Macklin is quite correct when he deplores the fact that the facility of the ERDC is no longer present. I have tried to set out the fact that a very considerable amount of research activity continues.

I have a table, which I have not yet shown to other honourable senators, which sets out in tabular form portfolio directed expenditure on education research. In view of the concerns of Senator Macklin and perhaps allowing for those who may wish to vet the table, I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It only remains for me to put on record my acknowledgment of Senator Macklin's expertise in university and educational matters and my desire that he should continue to contribute to this kind of debate. I value the kinds of comments he makes. I ask him to acknowledge that there are others in the Parliament and others who take part in the public debate who may share some of the same skills and who may wish to make the same kinds of contributions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Today we must be aware that cultural identity depends in large part on language retention . Whilst it is essential that migrants and their decendants acquire some degree of written and spoken proficiency with English-our nation's primary language-it is equally essential that multilingualism be encouraged. The Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) will remember that he and I had the privilege of sharing a platform when addressing multicultural groups on this matter. I must say-I am not trying to score points-that the remarks of the Minister for Education were closer to those I made on behalf of the Australian Democrats than I think were the remarks of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hodges). I am hopeful that Senator Baume's persuasiveness will prevail eventually and that the Government's policies will become closer to his views than to those expressed by either the Department or the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs on the question of a national language policy, which the Democrats support very strongly.

SPEECH.PARA: Since our very beginnings, the Australian Democrats have recognised the need for non-English speaking children, upon their entry into the school system, to be taught first in their dominant language with a gradual transfer to the second language after basic literary skills are mastered. It was evident from what was said at the conference that Australians are probably the worst in the world in terms of being equipped with two languages. It is almost pathetic how few Australians are bilingual or multilingual compared with the people of almost every other nation. While we still force mind-bending subjects such as algebra and trigonometry compulsorily on our children at an advanced age, the wisdom of which sometimes escapes me, we have a largely untapped national resource in that nearly two million Australians are bilingual. Our schools and other institutions must build upon that resource so that we can have a truly multilingual Australia in which at least a second language is accepted as an integral part of the learning of every Australian.
Honourable senators will recall recommendation 14 of the Review of Post-arrival Programs and Services to Migrants Committee-the Galbally Committee-which states:
. . . the language learning efforts of isolated individuals or even groups is not capable of sustaining a policy of multilingualism or of changing established practices of monolingualism.

Although I have praised the Government for many of its efforts in promoting multiculturalism-its efforts are worthy of praise-I must register the caveat that far too many of the Government's language planning efforts are proceeding on an ad hoc, hit and miss basis. We need a considered policy commitment from our Federal Government charting just where we are going with our multilingualism and co-ordinating the many branches of a language policy-the education system, international trade, translator and interpreter services, community language programs, the arts and international communications development.

The efforts of an individual solicitor, nurse, politician or business person to master a second language in order better to serve the community are not to be discounted, but without a national language policy to provide a direction and a framework for such individual efforts our nation will not overcome the cautionary dictum of Galbally recommendation 14. In a time of difficult economic fortunes, it is perhaps appropriate to remind the Government that multilingualism is not a luxury, stealing scarce resources from other areas of public life. Rather, multilingualism goes to the core of Australia and its destiny. It is as fundamental to our nation as health care and housing, defence and commerce. I trust that the singular opportunity offered by the National Language Policy Conference is not lost by our Government or our people.

Too often discussions of multiculturalism or multilingualism boil down to what 'they' will have to do to get along in 'our' society, or what 'we' can do to help 'them'-the 'us and them' syndrome. We are proud to dwell on the many advantages Australia has to offer as an incentive to migration and tend to think that adjustment to our way of life is a price to be paid by the migrant in order to get all these benefits. But in the 1980s we must complete the task of discarding our monocultural myopia and recognise the enormous benefits-tangible and intangible-which people from different backgrounds have brought to Australia . In doing so, we will find immense joys in discovering the rich mosaic of cultures and languages which are now available in Australia. I thank the Senate for its indulgence.
