SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I make a contribution in relation to the report of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs I wish to express my concern that already we have seen a period of 20 minutes taken by Ministers in our consideration of papers for which we are allowed a total of 90 minutes.
—Senators too.

—No, 20 minutes were taken by Ministers. First we had a dissertation for 10 minutes by Senator Carrick, followed by a dissertation for 10 minutes by Senator Peter Baume, in relation to queries raised and comments made by members on the Opposition side of the chamber. Effectively we have had 20 minutes taken out of our time already. I do not want a response to what I am going to say about the Department of Aboriginal Affairs report. If the Minister wants to comment on it-
—Senator, the paper before the chair is the report of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs for 1981-82.

—Thank you for your assistance, Mr Deputy President. I just say that I do not request an immediate response to my comments on the report of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. If the Minister wishes to comment he may do so by correspondence at some later stage. I wish to refer particularly to-
—Senator, I suggest that in the first instance you move that the Senate take note of the paper.
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I refer to page 18 under the general heading 'Medical Services' and draw to the attention of the Senate some of the statements made therein, in relation particularly to the expansion of medical services in a number of States including Western Australia. A few weeks ago I had brought to my attention the 1981-82 report of the Perth Aboriginal Medical Service. I wish to express my concern that in the report of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs I could find no specific mention of the work of the Community Nurse Practitioner, which receives a fair amount of attention in the Perth Aboriginal Medical Service report. I wish firstly to make it quite clear that I am concerned that because of limited government funding it is not possible for these facilities to be improved, in the Perth AMS particularly, although this practitioner is the first point of contact at the AMS for many whose situations are extreme, to say the least. The Community Nurse Practitioner, in her report, says:

Since settling into our new premises the main problem which comes up time and time again is lack of finances to carry out our daily work schedules. As we have many more people coming to seek assistance the radius becomes larger consequently it is impossible to conceive that one community nurse is able to adequately cover an area stretching from Armadale to West Swan, North Beach, Lockridge, Fremantle and the Perth metropolitan area. As two or three families may need intensive follow-up others are being neglected. Although submissions have been made for another community nurse to cover the specific needs of Aboriginal families it has fallen on the deaf ears of the funding body in Canberra.
The avalanche of new patients registered seems to be directly related to the introduction of the Government's new medical scheme introduced last September.
That is, September 1981. The report continues:
Large accounts for medical services from hospitals and laboratories tend to confuse and send many of the supporting mothers into a panic.

A lot of our time has been spent sorting out these accounts and confering with the relevant bodies. It has become increasingly more expensive to become ill under this new system. While women on supporting mothers benefits and other pensioners get allowances for prescriptions, others like the unemployed and low income earners do not get this benefit. The $3.50 and soon to be $4 for a script can mean the difference between bread, milk etc. for a meal or medications for the sick person concerned. Many opt for the food and so the prescription remains in the pocket and they go without medicines.

At the A.M.S. we endeavour to give these people lotions, dressings or medications from our stock cupboard. The money budgeted for medical stocks became depleted a month before the end of the financial year and in some instances the first aid kits which are supplied to Lockridge and Saunders Street had to be doled out in a frugal manner to enable us to eke out our stocks till the end of the month.

In the last 12 months many of the Aboriginal families in the low socio-economic group have faced severe hardships, trying to feed, clothe and generally care for their families. Rising costs have eroded their meagre allowances to such an extent that life has become a continuous struggle against the poverty forced upon them.

Welfare agencies which once were a ready source of help, now have their backs to the wall helping the ever growing number of people seeking assistance for food, clothing and help with electricity bills.

As these conditions prevail the children and small babies are the first to suffer a breakdown in health. Many families visited have not had one scrap of food in their houses for days at a time while they are waiting for their next benefits cheque. This is a criminal state of affairs in a country as rich as Australia.
After expressing concern about what is happening in some areas in the north of the State, at Meekatharra and places of that nature, the report goes on to say:

Another area of concern is the families at Saunders Street where pressure is being put upon the people to leave their premises to give way to a wild flower industry. No one seems to know or care where these people are to go-there are approximately 15 small babies and children and about 30 adults who would be affected if this programme is allowed to be proceeded with.
I first reported in a paper written in 1977 of the vast improvement in health of the children when these people first moved into these houses at Saunders Street.

I might add that at that time those houses were not what I would consider to be houses but they were certainly shelter, something to which the people of Saunders Street had not been accustomed. The report continues:

There is still the on going problem of homeless Aborigines around East Perth. Gradually every shelter they have found has been bulldozed down. From the Bull Paddock they now camp about 20 yards within the shadow of the new Education Department Building. Ironically to me this pathetic situation depicts the futile position of the Aboriginal people in Australia today.

Working with the new medical system has caused much confusion among the general public as well as the professionals. We were asked to sort out problems arising when patients from country areas had to come to Perth for medical appointments. Apparently when the first referral is made this is quite straight forward, but subsequent appointments are creating problems in the area of travel refunds. This breakdown is causing considerable hardship to the elderly and ante-natals. It is unbelievable that there can be so little communication between the departments dealing with people's health problems. As most recipients are unaware of the assistance for travel, they are put under great hardships trying to raise the money for fares between country areas and Perth.

Because of the downturn in the economy many aspects of health needs has tended to be overlooked in catering for the lower socio-economic bracket. This has put the A.M.S. under a greater strain acting on behalf of the Aboriginal people.

The thing that disturbs me is that because we have never recognised-there is almost a refusal on the part of governments to recognise-that Aboriginals are people, we have never upgraded the services to make sure that the health needs of Aboriginal people are brought up to a standard which would apply in a normal white community. We have constantly set up organisations. We have totally under- funded them to the extent that statements such as that made by the general nurse practitioner at the Perth Aboriginal Medical Service have to be made time and again and are still totally ignored by the Government. The situation in Perth for many years was that we had a very old building. It contained the original Aboriginal Medical Service. I think that in the period 1981 to 1982 the Service moved into new premises which are much more substantial and it provides a larger range of medical services. But the funding for the Service has still not increased to the extent that it has even kept pace with the rate of inflation. It is a tragedy that it takes the total day of one working person to get through just two or three disadvantaged families, purely and simply because of confusion and the lack of communication that exists in our community. This is not new amongst the Aborigines. The situation will never be satisfactory. But I would maintain that now is the time to establish a line of communication to be followed if in actual fact we are serious in our intent to promote the health, welfare and education of the Aboriginal people in our community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to respond in particular to the matters raised by Senator Coleman, notwithstanding the fact that she raises matters of concern to both the Department for which I had responsibility and the Aboriginal Medical Service, with which I have had close contact. I rise merely to make the point that there can be no force in the suggestion that where matters which are raised by honourable senators in this place contain allegations which are critical of the Government the Government ought to be in a position to respond and has an entitlement to respond. As honourable senators know, there would be a deal of anger in this place if Ministers were to refuse to respond to the matters which are raised. We have a tradition, even in the adjournment debate, of Ministers endeavouring to address themselves to the points which have been raised by honourable senators on behalf of constituents or organisations. Whilst I can appreciate the desire of honourable senators who are not Ministers to have the opportunity to address these matters of considerable public interest I would simply say on behalf of the Government that in those cases where the matters raised are critical of the Government, and in those cases in particular, we would certainly reserve the right to respond to put the record straight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-It was not my intention to prevent any answers being given. I objected to the fact that this morning we have been subjected to two 10-minute speeches by Ministers.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: UNITED NATIONS SPECIAL SESSION ON DISARMAMENT

PROCTEXT.PARA: Reports of Australian Delegation

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly, given the time constraints on ordinary senators, merely to record how exciting and excellent it is to see, right around Australia, the involvement of so many community groups in the broad world-wide movement relating to peace and disarmament issues. I read the report of the Australian delegation to the United Nations General Assembly's Special Session devoted to disarmament with interest. Given its complexity and the range of papers contained in the report it is possible to give only the scantest attention to them all. I will take one or two points out of the speech of the Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Honourable Tony Street, as a basis for a couple of remarks. Amongst other things, Mr Street said to the General Assembly:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there is a risk that by their popular appeal, mass peace movements may divert attention from real arms control and disarmament measures.

I believe that those words of the Foreign Minister reveal not only that there is a misunderstanding in that they imply that those involved in the peace movement around the world are not interested in real, concrete proposals for disarmament but also a typical politician's fear, I think, of mass movements, of really popular, widespread, genuine expressions of opinion by people who, perhaps, cannot be pigeonholed too easily and cannot be controlled by the political process. In this regard, rather than being fearful of it, politicians need to respond creatively to the lead which has been taken by ordinary people, because we are faced with the expression of a very deep-seated aspiration of mankind for peace. It is being expressed, as I say, in the activities of many people and community organisations throughout Australia. I have said before that one is reminded forcibly of the quotation of the prophet Isaiah, who was one of the great Jewish prophets, when he said:
. . . they shall beat their swords into plowshares, and their spears into pruning-hooks: nation shall not lift up sword against nation, neither shall they learn war any more.

That aspiration, given voice by the Jewish tradition, is shared, I believe, by all people around the world. It is up to politicians to respond. Mr Street was correct in stating that the peace movement in free countries should find a way of 'joining its voice with similar expressions of opinion which are struggling to make themselves heard from within closed societies'. It is a fact, I believe, that we who are privileged to take part in these demonstrations in democratic societies should give voice not only to our concerns and fears but also to the fears of those who are not permitted to express themselves in some other countries. Could it be denied that the mothers and fathers of Leningrad and of Moscow share the same fears about the future of their children as do the mothers and fathers of Melbourne or Sydney? We have to give voice to their fears, with our own, otherwise if the catastrophe which hangs over our heads comes to pass they may haunt us forever.

As I say, a sea change has been taking place in perceptions around the world, not only as to the imminence of nuclear destruction which we face but also as to the very real fact that with the diversion of so many billions of dollars into the armaments program of countries right around the world, particularly those gobbled up by the super-powers, there is less money available to meet the real social and practical needs of humanity. For example, if the nuclear arsenals of the super-powers were reduced by half, some $50 billion could be saved to be put to good use. For example, the six diseases measles, poliomyelitis, tuberculosis, diphtheria, whooping cough and tetanus are child killers. The World Health Organisation estimates that every minute 10 children may die as a result of those diseases. Vaccines have existed for decades, yet only 10 per cent of the 80 million children born yearly in the developing world are immunised. The cost of immunisation would be $3 per head. Surely that is where the resources of mankind should be placed, rather than in the ever-growing arsenals of destruction.

Finally, in Australia we need to take concrete practical steps. Without anticipating any debate on a notice of motion that I have given, let me say that it is a fact that the Senate will be called upon to discuss supporting the creation of an Australian Peace and Development Research Institute as an independent authority of international standing to undertake research and stimulate public awareness of peace and development issues; and further, the Senate will be debating the creation of such a mechanism as a Ministry of Peace, as advocated by the United Nations Association of Australia, in order to ensure that at the top levels of decision making, in government, at Cabinet level, the very perspectives and points of view of the peace movement can be put in order to counter and balance the point of view put by those who see foreign affairs and defence in the traditional terms. With those remarks, I leave the way open for other senators to contribute.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: -I am sure that like others in this chamber, I admire the enthusiasm with which Senator Tate puts forward his ideas about world peace. However, I think that his enthusiasm sometimes runs him into a kind of naivete which one would not expect of someone who has the intelligence that he has. He does not make it clear at all who is responsible for world tension. Everybody knows that it is not the United States of America. Everybody knows that it is the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics that is entirely responsible for the present state of world tension. Like many others in this chamber, I take strong objection when people do not make it clear that it is the USSR that is responsible for this world tension. Further, I do not like it at all when assertions are made that the basic values of the United States and the USSR are the same. They are not the same. Those of the USSR proceed from an entirely different basis from those of the United States of America. I will not have it that the United States is responsible in any way for the present state of world tension. There is no doubt that it is the USSR. If the USSR withdrew from the positions that it has taken in Europe and in Asia, there would be no comparative tension in the world at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to see that Senator Gietzelt is once again defending the land beyond the Danube. I see that he is defending again the USSR. He did it in a debate earlier, when we were trying to say something sensible about the Polish situation. When the USSR is properly attacked in this place for causing world tensions Senator Gietzelt always wants to defend it. Senator Tate' s ideas are certainly worthy of respect in his desire to bring about a lessening of world tension and eventual world peace. But it will not be brought about in the naive way that Senator Tate suggested. Honourable senators in this chamber and people in this country must be absolutely clear that the real cause of world tension is the USSR. Let it withdraw, let it show sincerity and that will create a climate in which world peace may begin to flourish.
—I did not intend to participate in this discussion but I-
—You cannot resist, can you?
—Undoubtedly the honourable senator successfully baited me, which is probably what he was trying to do.
—I'm wrong, am I?
—Yes.
—The USSR is good, wonderful!

—No. What I try to avoid, if I can in this sort of discussion, in this the senior chamber of the Commonwealth Parliament, is mindless discussion. Senator Martyr has just contributed a mindless speech of an Orwellian quality, if I might say so-four legs good, two legs bad. That is Senator Martyr's world. It is not as simple as that. As long as we go on making these simple assertions this Parliament will not be regarded seriously. Senator Martyr said that Senator Tate was naive in suggesting that people who live in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics have concerns about their families and children, just as people who live in the United States of America have those concerns. I find that an impeccably sensible proposition. In attacking that proposition Senator Martyr went on to say that the USSR was responsible for all world tension and the United States was, ergo, responsible for none. That is not a proposition which could seriously be debated in the Senate. I think there is a lot of uniformity of view in the Senate about the undesirability of the Soviet regime.
—El Salvador.

—I am getting a lot of assistance now. I think there would be a unanimous view in the Senate about the undesirability and the repressive nature of the Soviet regime and in some ways there would be considerable admiration for the freeness-if I can call it that-of United States society, even though many of us do not agree with many aspects of its system. But to say that the USSR is responsible for all world tensions and the United States for none is ridiculous.
—Give us an example.

—I will give some examples, examples to which Senator Martyr contributed. Is he suggesting seriously in 1982, with the wisdom of hindsight, that the USSR was responsible for the tension in Vietnam and-
—It financed and supplied the whole thing. You know that.
—I do not know that and I do not think that anybody who is well informed about the matter knows that either.
—There's plenty of literature about it.
—Senator Martyr says there is plenty of literature about it. I suggest that he bring it in and let us see it. I thought his view would have been that China financed a lot of the Vietnam war.
—The USSR three-quarters, China the other quarter.

—The fact of the matter is that, despite Senator Martyr's best efforts over 10 years as an apologist for what went on in Vietnam, he could not prove Soviet involvement in the sense that the United States was involved in Vietnam, supporting corrupt regimes. It was with Senator Martyr's acquiescence that Australia and the United States withdrew from Vietnam.
—How do you know that?
—Oh, yes, it was. Senator Martyr was here at the time.
—I couldn't do anything about it.

—Senator Martyr can do it now. He could have gone to Vietnam himself if he was so enthusiastic, but he was not. The United States and Australia withdrew from Vietnam with his acquiescence. We did not hear much more about it from Senator Martyr's colleagues after that happened. It was generally recognised as a fiasco and American commentators then and since have consistently referred to the desirability of the United States intervening in a military way on the mainland of Asia. It was America's intervention that was being talked about when those comments were made. Of course if one looks at other places in the world it can be said, on documented evidence of statements by United States leaders and Presidents, that the United States has played a role, a significant interventionist role-I do not make any moral judgment about it-in Central and Southern America. I do have personal views about the desirability of that in terms of the integrity of those societies and their capacity to develop as democracies, if that is not too naive a belief. There is no doubt at all that the United States has had an interventionist policy so described in relation to Central America and a number of South American republics. They are interventionists and are responsible for tension in those areas. I will give other examples. It was not the USSR that tried to put a helicopter force into Iran; it was the United States of America.
—But their people were locked up in Tehran as hostages.

—There are all sorts of reasons and explanations for it, but to say that these things make no contribution to world tension is just ridiculous, just as it was ridiculous for the United States to adopt a policy on the Soviet Western Europe pipeline which it has now abandoned at the instigation of its Western European allies. These sorts of things contribute to world tension and every country in Western Europe recognises them as contributing to world tension . Numerous statements have been made by Western European leaders about undesirable aspects of United States policy which tend to cause tension. I must say that Senator Martyr is almost an heroic lone voice in trying to advance the sorts of propositions which he advanced earlier today in the Senate.
—I am not deterred by being alone. I never have been.

—I know and understand that. Courage is an inestimable virtue but if it is coupled with stupidity it is sometimes not the most desirable form of conduct. That is what I am suggesting. I think that debate in this place would be much better informed and much better conducted in the interests of this Parliament if there were no propositions. I do not want to provoke Senator Martyr into inflicting his boy scout morality on the Senate. That is probably what I am doing, but what I am asking for is a serious contribution to a discussion of this very important report of the Australian Delegation on the United Nations General Assembly Special Session on Disarmament. It should not be done on the basis of black and white sloganeering.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to speak for any length of time. Honourable senators may recall that prior to the Second Special Session of the United Nations devoted to disarmament I gave a fairly lengthy speech in this place stressing the importance of that Second Session. At that time I reminded honourable senators that I had attended the First Session. I rise today because of the importance that the report of the Australian Delegation on the United Nations General Assembly Special Session on Disarmanent places on non-governmental organisations, those institutes of peace that Senator Martyr seems to think would be a waste of time-
—Absolute bunkum.

—Senator Martyr has had a lot of harsh things to say about the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and Senator Button, to a certain extent, has responded. If one really wants to nit pick one could talk about El Salvador, Chile, Argentina, Ecuador and Vietnam until the cows come home. It would not change the honourable senator's opinion of the USSR. I am not critical of the United States of America any more than I am of the USSR. I am saying that both of those countries and others are responsible for the tension in the world today . It is a very uneasy feeling that we have. I do not care who is responsible, quite frankly. I want to do something about it.
—That would not be very sensible if you did not know who was responsible.

—That is the sort of stupid, trite remark that I would expect from an academic of Senator Hamer's quality. I was saying that I would like to feel that I could do something about it. I would like to feel that this Parliament could do something about it. Prior to the Second Session I felt that we could have done something about the United Nations if we had accorded it the importance to which it is entitled. We recognise that the United Nations does not have the backbone that it needs. I said in my speech in this place that if it was as important to us as I thought it was, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) would have represented this country, not the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street), to give it the importance due to it. Whether he would have made a contribution and raised the status of the United Nations is something else again. But it may have put it on that government to government level which is lacking in the United Nations. The United Nations does not have a policy; it does not have a ready-made solution to all these things. The lines of communication have broken down because of the tier, the hierarchy, that exists in the United Nations. It has become ineffective and it has become ineffective because we have anticipated that it is like a world government. We have expected great things of it. We have not made a contribution to it. I am not talking about a financial contribution; I know our terms of reference there. I am talking about the contribution that we as citizens of the world could have made during all these years.

SPEECH.PARA: When have our delegations to the United Nations done anything constructive? When have we demanded that we have a chair of peace at every one of our universities so that we can do something constructive about peace? When have we supported Senator Tate's notice of motion for an institute of peace and research development? Senator Martyr today knocked his proposal because he does not have the courage to go for peace. He is the type of person who was behind the Vietnam War. He is the type of person who sat on his backside and did nothing. That is what he will do again, except that he will not have a second chance because I believe that there will be only one more opportunity for the world to get together and to determine that we will have peace. Otherwise, the only thing that we will have will be the destruction of mankind. I would support at any time any move to set up those lines of communications which I see as lacking in the United Nations at the moment. It would set up lines of communication in our own area, such as between Australia and Indonesia. There are a lot of people in Australia who are fearful of Indonesia, as there are a lot of people in China who are fearful of the USSR. A lot of people in neighbouring countries are fearful of others. Surely it is possible, surely we are enlightened enough, to sit down and talk about lines of communication.

TALK.START.PARA: —Follow Gough Whitlam's lead on Indonesia.

—I am not discussing personalities. I am discussing lines of communication. We can set up lines of communication. Senator MacGibbon is so biased and expresses his attitude so well that the people who are listening to this debate recognise that on the Government side there are senators who are completely ignorant of the needs of the world. They recognise that Government senators have vested interests in promoting war rather than peace.
—Come off it. Name people in this chamber who want war. Nobody wants war.
—Senator Martyr comes pretty close to it. I have suggested that we should all actively support the cause of peace. He is the one who has said-
—Why don't you tell the USSR that?

—As a member of the Government, Senator Martyr has more opportunity to tell the United Nations what to do than I have as a mere Opposition back bencher. I am simply saying that, at the time that the establishment of a chair of peace was proposed for Murdoch University in Western Australia, I did not hear Senator Martyr come out and support it.
—I was against it.

—Of course Senator Martyr was. He was against peace back in those days and he is against peace now because he cannot recognise that there is a need to do something today. If we do not do something today there may not be a tomorrow. The United Nations Special Session on Disarmament really did not achieve a great deal. I have explained why it did not; it is because it is not a world government. It comprises a number of governments that come together, but it has no clear lines of action in the resolution of conflict. There is no way that it can say: 'You are not going to do this' or 'You are going to do that'. We have not given it that authority. Until such time as we do we have to look at alternative methods. One of those methods is being called for now by leading academics, lawyers, concerned citizens-even me as an ordinary senator. I am calling for it. I want to see the establishment of an institute of peace and research development. I believe it will make the greatest contribution of this country to world peace and perhaps give a lead to others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Labor Party's position has been stated many times by its spokesman on foreign affairs, Mr Lionel Bowen. He has spoken about the need for the world to move into a more peaceful position . I think the holding several months ago of the United Nations General Assembly Special Session on Disarmament, and the report of the Australian delegation to that conference which is before the Senate today, is an indication of some maturing of attitudes on this very vital and important question of disarmament. It is clear that we cannot continue on the path that the world has taken. We cannot continue to accept a position in which the super-powers, namely the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, determine what course of action should be taken in respect of the issues of world peace and disarmament. As the Labor Party speakers in this debate today have indicated , the issues go far beyond ideology. They go far beyond the right of two major countries in the world to determine the fate of humanity and to determine whether we can find the path by which sensible people and sensible governments can live together despite their differences, whether they be ideological, religious, racial or other differences.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that the United Nations has taken the step of having a specific conference called to discuss disarmament is an indication of that maturing which I believe ought to be encouraged-not denigrated as Senator Martyr did today. Of course, people on both sides of this important international question have blind spots. Obviously Senator Martyr is one who sees the issue of disarmament in the context of black and white. He does not accept that it takes two to tango; that it takes two to get into a conflict; and that on both sides there are fears about the intentions and motivations of those who claim to speak on behalf of the East and the West. What he does not understand, and what obviously members of the Government parties do not understand, is that those of us who as Senator Tate has suggested have been active in the quest for peace, in the pursuance of a peaceful resolution of the world's differences, accept the fact that there is a genuine fear in the United States about the intentions of the Soviet Union as indeed there are genuine fears in the Soviet Union about the intentions of the United States. There is abundant evidence to show that those fears are based genuinely in the minds of people and perhaps even in the minds of governments.

But one cannot suggest that all of the world's tensions can be placed at the door of one particular country or even one of the super-powers. I can understand -Senator Martyr obviously cannot-the concern in the Soviet Union about world war . It is a country that had one-third of its territory-villages, towns and communities-overrun during World War II, when some 20 million people lost their lives. They had more of a vested interest in establishing a world of peace than we did in Australia. A few bombs were dropped on Darwin and there were a few explosions in the eastern suburbs of Sydney. They were the only effects felt by the general population of Australia.

It would be futile to suggest that the Russians were the main force in the Korean war or, indeed, in the war in Vietnam. It is just as futile to suggest that the liberation of many countries in Africa can be placed at the door of the Soviet Union any more than it can be placed at the door of the United States of America. It was the right of the people in those countries, along with the United Nations, to determine their own affairs. Yet, they were traduced and criticised-they were called terrorists-whether they were in Kenya or Zimbabwe. These sorts of connotations and descriptions of attempting to write off people's attitudes were made just because we did not understand the forces that were operating in those particular areas.

What Senator Martyr and obviously some members of the Government-I believe there has been some slight improvement in the attitude of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) about this conference and the question of disarmament-failed to appreciate was the growing number of men in the military machines of the East and West, particularly the West, who have, in more recent times, warned about the dangers of nuclear war and of allowing the arms race to continue. The Chief of the General Staff of the United Kingdom and North Atlantic Treaty Organisation generals in Europe and in West Germany itself have become active in the peace movement. This movement no longer accepts the view that everything is the fault of the United States of America.

When I was elected a member of the Australian Senate I was asked to become a member of the World Peace Council. I accepted that position in the belief that I could make an impact at that level and that I could help achieve some balance on this matter. I reject entirely the simplistic and erroneous conclusions that Senator Martyr drew because I allowed my membership to lapse. I do not go along with the view, indeed neither does the Australian Labor Party nor substantial sections of the peace movement, that the fault with respect to the current problems of nuclear weapons lies on one side. There is an understanding that concessions need to be made, concessions of the type that began with the Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty-SALT I and SALT II-agreements. It is a matter of regret that such is the suspicion that exists that these talks between the super-powers have been stalled in more recent times.

Surely what we have to do is not to suggest, as some people do, that everything the Americans do is wrong or everything the Russians put forward is wrong; some concessions have to be made in the minds of the people of the world, the people who will rise above governments. I point out to Senator Martyr that the overwhelming sentiment of the people of the Soviet Union would be towards a peaceful solution of world tension. I concede that the same desire exists amongst the people of the United States and among the people of Australia. To suggest that governments, in the long run, can ignore the views of their own citizens in these matters is to ignore the reality of the way in which public opinion can play its part. The United Nations conference on disarmament was about harnessing world opinion. It encouraged people to put aside their beliefs that prejudices are more important than finding a consensus approach to the problems facing the world today. To achieve that, we have to accept that good will can be found in both the United States' position and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics' position. Therefore, we have to get out of the area--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time having expired for the consideration of papers, pursuant to sessional order I now proceed to the next item of business.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Honey Legislation: Government Response-Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement and to have it incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

I wish to make a statement on behalf of the Minister for Primary Industry outlining the Government's response to the report from the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations into the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Bill 1982. Senator Rae, Chairman of the Committee, tabled the report on 19 May 1982. The committee's review arose in the context of a Review of Commonwealth Functions' decision that the Government's policy of recovering approximately half of the total costs of export inspection be extended to several industries, including honey, from 1 July 1982.

The committee's principal recommendations are, in summary, that current honey inspection procedures be abandoned and replaced by a system of limited random sampling and testing of honey by the Department of Primary Industry; that the system of export control through export permits be abandoned; that exporters be required to bear the responsibility for sampling and cost of analysis where a ' Certificate in Respect of Honey' is required; and that the department continue its role in relation to inspecting premises for registration as export establishments. The committee also recommended that charging not be proceeded with and that the size and role of the Australian Honey Board be reviewed when new stabilization arrangements for the industry come under government consideration.

The Committee's views were based on submitted evidence of only a very limited incidence of malpractice in the Honey Export Industry, and on the basis that commercial contract and Australian Honey Board controls based on the colour classification of honey should themselves assure adequate control through the operation of market forces. Since receipt of the Committee's report, evidence has come to hand indicating that possible adulteration of export honey has been taking place. New methodology developed and introduced by the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories earlier this year has shown evidence indicative of adulteration of Australian export honey by the addition of glucose syrup in twelve samples drawn from export honey consignments. Such addition can lighten the colour and taste of honey and also improve the bulk of honey otherwise substandard due to excess moisture. Further investigations are proceeding.

The Government is concerned to investigate and control all instances indicative of malpractice and fraud in the export food industry. These were fundamental aims when inspection was first introduced and have not changed. The Government's response to the Committee's report has been conditioned by this consideration. Importantly, the Government recognises the need to continue basic export inspection monitoring of honey to safeguard against malpractice and to ensure continued acceptability of the product on world markets. The major area relating to inspection in which follow-up action is proposed concerns the sampling and analysis of export honey where overseas authorities require analysis and related certification as a condition of importation. It is appropriate that the responsibility for obtaining such analysis should rest with the exporter rather than the Department of Primary Industry. Arrangements will be phased in requiring exporters to arrange for sampling and analysis at their cost rather than as a cost to revenue. Such sampling would be in accordance with recognised standards. The Department of Primary Industry would monitor sampling activity by industry and also maintain some basic analysis to ensure that samples are representative of export shipments.

Aside from this, the scope for savings is limited. Honey inspection already substantially takes the form of a limited sampling and monitoring operation. It forms part of the activities of dairy inspection staff located Australia-wide. The effort in total involves the equivalent of only three people. Cuts would not achieve substantial savings but could seriously compromise the effectiveness of control. In the light of recent events the Government is not prepared to do this . The Committee's recommendations that export permits be abolished and that the Department continue to inspect premises for registration as export establishments raise questions of the method in which control over export shipments of honey is to be maintained in the future. The export permit system is a central and important feature of the inspection operation both in honey and in other commodities subject to control. The Government is aware, however, that there is some overlap between it and the Australian Honey Board's certification procedures. The question of possible better co-ordination of requirements in these areas is being pursued in the context of a broader review of export inspection activities.

The question of introducing charges for honey export inspection will also be reassessed as part of this broader review. It is essential that costs involved in exporting should as far as possible be contained, and the Government is concerned in this regard that inspection arrangements should be both cost- effective and at the minimum levels necessary for effective basic control. Until these matters are resolved on a broader basis, for products such as fresh, dried and processed fruits and vegetables, fish and dairy foods, it would be inappropriate to reconsider charges for honey. The Government will also act on the Committee's recommendation that the size and role of the Australian Honey Board be reviewed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement is not very clearly worded in my view but the Government seems to have rejected the recommendation of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations partly because since the Committee's report was received evidence has come to hand indicating the adulteration of honey with glucose syrup. If the Government is hanging its case largely on that peg it does not seem to me to be a very solid peg on which to hang it because if such adulteration has taken place it has taken place under the previous system under which all export consignments were sampled and tested. It may not have been possible in the past to test accurately for the forms of adulteration which it is believed have been discovered now. The procedures which have been followed in the past have demonstrably failed to prevent that malpractice if indeed such malpractice existed.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has rejected the principal recommendation of the Committee which was that sampling be done on a random basis rather than on an across the board basis and that quite heavy penalties be imposed for the failure to maintain the required standards or for attempts to adulterate the product. I believe that still would have been the best course to follow because the sampling procedures used in the past, according to evidence given before the Committee, were largely of an honour system nature in any case-that is, the samples were usually, if not usually then frequently, drawn by the exporters themselves and handed to the inspectors of the Department of Primary Industry. The samples were not, at least in some cases and apparently in most cases, actually drawn off by the DPI inspectors. The Government has accepted the recommendation of the Committee that , for those few markets where certification and analysis are required, the quite substantial costs of doing that fairly exhaustive analysis should be borne by the exporters to those few markets rather than be a generalised charge on exports as a whole. The Government has decided to defer the final consideration of the Committee recommendation that export permits be abolished. The evidence given to the Committee stated that export permits were very rarely required by the overseas customers.

While I welcome the Government's acceptance of the Committee recommendation-and I was a member of the Committee-that the exporters bear the cost of a fairly comprehensive analysis for the minority markets which require it, I do not believe the Government has presented an adequate case for continuing the practice of across-the-board sampling which appears to be what the Government intends. The fact that malpractice under the pre-existing system has been detected certainly does not justify the continuation of that system. Unless the Department of Primary Industry is to tighten up very considerably the sampling procedures that were explained to the Committee, there seems to be absolutely no point in continuing to sample in the way in which it has been done in the past, that is, of all consignments. I still believe that the Committee's recommendation was the sounder, that is, that random checks be made and that quite significant penalties be applied to exporters who are detected by those random checks to have failed to maintain the required standards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My remarks are similar to those made by Senator Walsh. I believe that the recommendation of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations would have given a far better basis for proceeding in this area. It seems to me that the Government's response is based somewhat on the possible attempts of the Department of Primary Industry to justify itself after the event, when one reads on page 2 of the Government's response about possible adulteration of honey by glucose. Of course, glucose occurs naturally in honey. I understand that often the natural content can be as high as 35 per cent. The tests referred to in the Government's response were made in Western Australia. As I understand the situation, those tests were inconclusive as to whether glucose was of natural origin or had been added. It seems to me rather odd that it has been the practice extending back some 30 years for glucose to be added to export honey to generate a range of products. Of course, the product then is not able to be sold as pure Australian honey.

SPEECH.PARA: When this possible adulteration was raised, almost immediately after the Government had moved to discharge the Honey (Export Charges) Bill from the Notice Paper the reply came from the industry that this was an attempt to show why the very reasonable recommendations of the Senate Committee with respect to the costs and the ability to control the export of honey should not be proceeded with. Of course, the Department in seeking to justify its previously rather odd position sought to bring this point forward. It seems also rather odd that no further points have been raised since that time about the possible adulteration of honey. It is now quite a few months since that adulteration in Western Australia was announced. I would have thought that, rather than a comment that further investigations are proceeding, we might have been able at this stage to have a more definitive comment in relation to the Western Australian analysis.

I believe that the Senate Committee brought forward a very reasonable report. It was welcomed by the industry as not imposing undue charges on a very tenuous export industry. I believe that the Government may be better advised to look at that again, particularly in these extremely difficult times for the maintenance of exports when we should avoid at all costs imposing on producers additional charges which they can ill afford to pay.

DEBATE.TITLE: DRIED FRUITS EXPORT CHARGES AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 November, on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick:
That the Bill be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I use this first reading debate to speak about the deterioration of Australia's manufacturing industries. In particular, I want to highlight the Temporary Assistance Authority report on air conditioning machines and parts. I believe this report highlights the problems being caused by the massive influx of imports into Australia. I believe its recommendations, which were subsequently adopted by the Government, are fraught with danger and will certainly not go far enough to prevent yet more retrenchments at the Kelvinator Australia Ltd plant in Adelaide. The report shows quite clearly how imports have come to dominate the room air conditioning market in Australia in recent years. Table 3.1 on page 7 of the report shows that while local production actually fell by 2,000 units between 1979-80 and 1981-82 imports skyrocketed from 84,000 units to 203,000 units-an increase of something like 142 per cent. I seek leave to have the table incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —The market share held by locally produced air conditioners has fallen from 42 per cent in 1979-80 to just 23 per cent in 1981-82. I think this situation is fairly indicative of what has been happening to many of our manufacturing industries in Australia in recent years. Kelvinator pointed out during the inquiry that the increasing level of imports was clearly to blame for the fall in employment in this area of its operations from 546 in 1980 to 458 in June 1982. The report makes the point that imports have not only a price advantage but also certain design advantages. For example, the Kelvinator units are based on a 1972 design while importers claim that their units have undergone major redesign since then and Kelvinator uses more expensive piston type compressors whereas imported models use cheaper rotary compressors. I make the point here that there is no indication whatsoever that wages in Australia are the cause of this price differential. In fact, the tables on page 5 show that the number of air conditioners produced at Kelvinator per employee rose from 101 .1 in 1980-81 to 129.6 in 1981-82-in other words, productivity in this area increased by something like 28 per cent in that 12-month period while real average weekly earnings increased last year by just 6 per cent. This proves quite clearly that price disadvantage is a result of design and technical considerations rather than labour costs.

SPEECH.PARA: Another point I want to make concerns an answer given to a question I put to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) on Tuesday last week. He said:
In other words, the imported summer stocks with which Kelvinator will be competing for this summer's trade are already imported.

Unfortunately, he was incorrect-only 70 per cent of imports expected in 1982-83, or about 160,000 units had landed by the end of October, according to this report. In other words, another 70,000 units are still to be imported to this country for this summer's trade. Yet the estimated sales of room air conditioners in Australia in 1982-83 are expected to be only around 190,000 units, according to Kelvinator. It is most unlikely that sales will be higher than this in the present economic climate. The Temporary Assistance Authority said that it makes no sense to apply quotas at this stage. Instead, Kelvinator should be given a bounty so that the price disadvantage can be eliminated. My main worry with this proposal is that there is still no guarantee that people will buy Kelvinator air conditioners because people take other things into account, such as design factors, as I mentioned earlier. On the other hand, if we immediately stopped further imports, that is, if a quota were applied in such a way as to prevent another 70,000 models being imported, Kelvinator would automatically have a potential market of 60,000 units. With the Temporary Assistance Authority's recommendations potential local production is practically zero, especially given the surplus stock of imports. What Kelvinator is asking for-this is shown in Appendix D of the report-is surely not unreasonable because it would give it the breathing space it requires until its proposed investment plans are completed. I seek leave to incorporate Appendix D in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —The way out chosen by the Government will not guarantee Kelvinator a reasonable market share. I am afraid that it will not guarantee the jobs of the workers. A bounty system in conjunction with a form of quota protection would have been a more sensible compromise in the circumstances. Those measures, combined with a vigorous media campaign to convince people to buy Australian made goods, would have a greater chance of success than the Temporary Assistance Authority's recommendations which have been adopted by the Government. Unless we start vigorously promoting Australian made products and develop a greater awareness in the community that buying locally produced goods will actually save jobs in Australia the current problems will remain with us.
—Senator, do you think it is important that they also should produce something that the locals want?

—That would be helpful as well. In my experience, that has been happening quite often over the last five to 10 years. Very few countries are able to manufacture goods as efficiently as Japan is. Australia is no exception. It comes as no surprise that Japan has an unemployment rate of 2.3 per cent-well below the average for the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development . I believe we must move now to protect Australia's industries against the onslaught from Japan and other Asian countries; otherwise even more jobs will be threatened and our dole queues will get longer and longer.

SPEECH.PARA: This week the Statistics Group of the Parliamentary Library released its monthly economic and social indicators. The figures on trade show quite clearly what has been happening. These figures were mentioned yesterday by Senator Evans when he was attempting to give the Leader of the Government in the Senate ( Senator Sir John Carrick) a lesson on economics. Table 4.1 on page 18 of the Statistics Group's document shows quite clearly how imports have risen over the last few years. I think that table was incorporated in Hansard yesterday so I do not seek leave to have it incorporated today. It shows that in 1981-82 imports rose by 17 per cent over the previous year from $19,188m to $22,451m. This was on top of a 21 per cent increase in the previous year. If we look at the figures on retail sales in table 5.1 on page 22 of the Statistics Group's document we see that in 1981-82 sales rose by 12.4 per cent over the previous year. TALK.START.PARA: —If we look at these figures and compare them with the import figures I have just mentioned it is fairly clear that imports are rising at a much higher rate than retail sales. There was a 21 per cent increase in imports in 1980-81 compared with a 14 per cent increase in sales and a 17 per cent increase in imports last financial year compared with a 12 per cent increase in sales. Therefore, quite clearly, imports are assuming a greater share of the market. I believe that this is a problem that the Government refuses to acknowledge and come to grips with. With retail sales beginning to fall in real terms the problem will become even more acute unless the Government acts now to restrict the flow of imports. Even the Australian Industries Development Association recently complained about the unprecedented increase in dumping by overseas countries. Apparently many overseas companies, in an attempt to remain viable in the current depressed economic world climate, are dumping goods on the Australian market at prices well below actual production costs. Unfortunately the Federal Government's action to deal with this has been largely ineffective. The Australian Industries Development Association has now called on the Government to change the import procedures. For instance, as the position stands , the burden of proof so far as dumping is concerned is on local producers, whereas it should really be on importers. Unless this Government changes its attitude and realises the damage that is being done to our manufacturing industries, the situation can only get worse.

SPEECH.PARA: We all know that Cabinet is reluctant to increase protection levels from fear of a back bench revolt. In other words Cabinet is putting the interests of the Liberal-National Party coalition before the interests of the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is based on all the economic advice that it can possibly receive from its experts, Senator.
—That may be so.
—Look at all the written reports it has received from economists.

—All this Government has advanced as a remedy for ailing manufacturing industries is the wage freeze that has just been announced. That surely is an admission of failure or helplessness. The Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Sir John Carrick, is always talking about lower wages in other countries. What he omits to say is that unemployment in those countries is well into double figures, which goes to show just how effective is a reduction in real wages in bringing about a fall in unemployment-it does not work. The fact is that the only glimmer of hope for the Australian economy in 1981-82 was the improvement in the level of retail sales, which came about as a direct result of the increase in real wages. If this had not occurred in 1981-82, unemployment would have been even higher than it is at present and our manufacturing industries would have been in an even worse position.

SPEECH.PARA: What the Government is now proposing is so simplistic and ill thought out that it will lead to a complete collapse of consumer confidence. If real wages fall, real retail sales will fall also and even more will become unemployed. This is totally unacceptable to the Australian Labor Party and I am sure to the vast majority of Australians also. Unless this Government moves now to protect Australia's industries from highly efficient producers, such as Japan, and assists in the restructuring and revitalising of our industries, employment levels will continue to fall. This Government is totally devoid of constructive policies to help the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to use the opportunity afforded by this debate to pay recognition to a great Liberal. It would be most remiss of me, in what is perhaps the second last week of the session, to allow an opportunity to pass without giving an adequate recognition following the resignation of Sir Phillip Lynch from the Federal Parliament. He made a consistent and conscientious contribution to the Liberal Party from the time he was first elected as Member for Flinders in 1966. It is indeed to be regretted that ill health forced his decision to step down from parliamentary life.

SPEECH.PARA: Phillip Lynch's success was brought about by hard work. It was stated in the Age newspaper that he would 'stick his hand in a fire for the Party, emerge uncomplaining and return to another 18-hour day in his office'. His rise within the Liberal Party was all the more meritorious in that he did not come from the establishment. Qualifying as a teacher from Melbourne University with a Bachelor of Arts and a Diploma in Education he went on to become a management consultant and national president of the Jaycee movement. In my student days, when studying political science, I recall a tutor saying that it would be almost impossible for a Roman Catholic to become President of the United States of America. In subsequent years John F. Kennedy resoundingly squashed that theory, but I must admit that sort of thinking from that tutor was still around in conservative circles in Australia when the then Phillip Lynch was making his mark in Liberal Party politics.

Sir Phillip made an exceptionally distinguished contribution to Australia through his parliamentary service. He joined the Ministry in 1968 under Sir John Gorton as Minister for the Army. This was followed by appointments as Minister for Immigration, Minister assisting the Treasurer and Minister for Labour and National Service. He was then shadow Treasurer, prior to becoming Treasurer when the Liberal Party was returned to office in 1975. His portfolios since have included Minister for Finance and, until 11 October this year, Minister for Industry and Commerce. Sir Phillip was also Acting Prime Minister on two occasions. As Treasurer and Minister for Industry and Commerce, Sir Phillip Lynch has been involved in decisions which affected all Australians. He is to be admired for his hard work and ability, particularly in restraining inflation an in restoring sanity and sound economic mangement when following the Whitlam years he became Treasurer. For 10 years he was Deputy Leader of the Federal Liberal Parliamentary Party. He made a magnificent contribution in this capacity largely as a team coach, as a fix-it person and as an anchorman. He also engendered loyalty and stability within the party.

Most great men are remembered by their last major activity. Richard Nixon's great achievement was in establishing a rapprochement with China but this generation unfortunately remembers him for Watergate. Regrettably, Sir Phillip Lynch's achievements have been overshadowed by his chairmanship of the razor gang. His ability and his presence in this Parliament will be greatly missed. But Sir Phillip Lynch must feel content in the knowledge that he has served this country well. Our Liberal Party must continue to attract the sons of blue collar workers and, indeed, the blue collar workers themselves. We must be seen to be a party which has amongst its numbers people from all sectors of society. Phillip Lynch, I thank you for your contribution. You have indeed given great service to the Liberal Party and to Australia. I salute you. (Quorum formed).
