SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I take advantage of the first reading of the Dried Fruits Export Charges Amendment Bill-the stage at which we can make comments which are not necessarily relevant to the Bill-to make some comment about television programs which are broadcast during the Christmas-New Year period. We are now fast approaching the Christmas-New Year period. For many people this gives them a chance to relax, put up their feet and enjoy the simple pleasures of life for which we usually do not have time. One of those simple pleasures of life is watching television. I admit that during the festive season we tend to relax and, therefore, may be less inclined to be critical. However, there is a limit to human endurance. I suggest that many television stations and programmers are pushing us to the very edge of those limits of endurance.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year during the Christmas period I was utterly appalled at the fare which was offered to metropolitan television viewers, not only in my own State of Queensland but also in other States. In Brisbane, the capital of the State which I represent, viewers have a choice of three commercial stations. During the last Christmas-New Year period this boiled down to a choice between old programs, inferior programs and repeats. As a rule television viewers do not have a profound knowledge of the broadcasting industry but they realise that what happens over the Christmas-New Year period is more than coincidence or bad luck. What happens is summed up in one word-the word that strikes fear and obedience into the hearts of television executives all over Australia-that is, ratings. At Christmas time, ratings surveys, like many Australians, take holidays. Unfortunately, so do the broadcasting stations. Because there are no all- important ratings surveys television programmers feel free to dish up inferior programs secure in the knowledge that it will not be reflected in the ratings and thus their advertising revenue will not be affected.

Last Christmas I was not alone in thinking that what was offered to television viewers was not good enough. After many people spoke to me I made a public statement about the dreadful programs that were being foisted upon viewers. I suggested that the Government could undertake official ratings surveys during the Christmas-New Year period and publish the results of these surveys to keep the television stations on their toes. I must admit that television executives were less than enthusiastic about my comments and suggestions. In fact, some of them contacted me and were quite pointed in their remarks, saying that I was not giving them the justice which they deserved. On the other hand, I was overwhelmed with positive responses from disgusted and disgruntled viewers. At the suggestion of some of them I was prompted, on their behalf, to distribute a petition on the matter. Thousands of Queenslanders were sufficiently motivated to sign a petition saying:

Some television stations throughout Australia are taking advantage of the absence of ratings surveys during the Christmas-New Year period holiday season to broadcast inferior quality programs and innumerable repeats.

The petition called upon the Government to 'undertake and publish the results of ratings surveys during holiday periods to encourage the broadcasting of quality TV programs at those times'. I add that my comments were directed principally towards metropolitan stations. To be fair, I must say that there were some bright spots on TV programming, but they were few and far between. From my observations and from comments made to me it seemed that provincial stations in Queensland made every effort to maintain viewing standards in the holiday season . I congratulate those stations for this. I take this opportunity of warning TV stations, especially the producers and programmers in the State which I represent, that the public trusts that they have taken note of the view of a large number of Queenslanders that they deserve better during our Christmas-New Year holiday period. I trust that some of the stations will not insult viewers' intelligence with some of the mindless drivel to which we were subjected this time last year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity presented to me by the first reading stage of the Dried Fruits Export Charges Amendment Bill to make some comments on behalf of the Opposition about the current crisis in the Australian film industry. It is a matter of great concern to the Australian Labor Party. It is certainly a matter of great concern to people working in the industry. I believe it is increasingly a matter of concern to the public, particularly the film-going public, that our film industry, of which we have justifiably been so proud in recent years, is currently in a state of severe crisis. The reason for this is not that we have any lack of talent among directors, actors, writers, technicians or camera persons. It would seem that we have an abundance of talented people and ideas. The reason is that private investment in the local film industry has virtually dried up. This has come about largely as a result of the Government's negligence with regard to one particular tax concession scheme and its incompetence insofar as its own film tax concession scheme is concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: The crisis has been brought on by a number of factors, but the most crippling is the channelling of Australian investment moneys into overseas film production through a particular use of section 51 (1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act. There are problems with the Government's own film tax concessions scheme which operates under Division 10BA of the taxation Act. These include the one-year completion regulation and the inadequacy of the Australian content requirement. But the most important problem which the Government has failed to address throughout this year is the use of section 51 (1). As film financing schemes using section 51 (1) have flourished, investment for Australian films has dried up. A significant number of local projects has been shelved. The number of Australian feature films produced has gone from over 30 in the last financial year to about only six in production now. As I have said before in this place, the main company involved in marketing this scheme under section 51 (1) is United Artists (Australasia) Pty Ltd, although there are other companies involved in this, including a company called Transpacific Media Productions.

Our major objection to this scheme-we have many-is that it encourages Australian investment in overseas films. If one invests one's money in a film which is marketed through this scheme one is offered a 375 per cent tax concession on the money one invests and there is no requirement at all that the film be an Australian film. In comparison, the concession offered under the Government's scheme-a 150 per cent tax concession-is not attracting investors. The Australian Labor Party has many criticisms of the Government's scheme, but the one thing about it that the Labor Party supports is that it is an attempt to help the local industry. In order to qualify for a tax concession under the Government's scheme a film project has to be certified as Australian by the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. At least that means that the bulk of the assistance going via this scheme goes to Australian productions. In the case of the section 51 (1) scheme there is no such requirement.

Of course, the Australian taxpayer is subsidising both of these schemes. I think it is very important to point out to the general public particularly that the operation of a tax concession scheme to assist an industry is, in terms of revenue forgone as far as the taxpayer is concerned, equivalent to a direct grant or a direct form of assistance. What happens is that taxpayers have their tax bill reduced by a certain amount of money. That money, therefore, is not available to the Government to spend on services and other things. The effect is the same as if the Government had the money and allocated it to the industry. So we are talking about the use of Australian taxpayers' money in both of these schemes.

In 1980-81 the loss to revenue through deductions claimed in respect of section 51 (1) film tax schemes was actually greater than the loss to revenue through the Government's Division 10BA scheme. That is, it appears that taxpayers paid more in 1980-81 to support foreign films than they did to support our own film industry. I have evidence to support this assertion. This matter was pursued on my behalf by my colleague Senator McLaren at Senate Estimates Committee C. In response to questions asked by Senator McLaren, the Second Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Black, stated that in 1980-81 the loss to tax revenue attributable to the Government's Division 10BA scheme to support Australian films was $13m. Mr Black went on to say that the amount of tax lost through film schemes using section 51 (1) of the tax Act was $16m in 1980-81. That is very clear evidence that the scheme operated by UAA and others, which encourages investment in foreign films, is actually a greater drain on our revenue than the scheme which is intended to help the local industry. As I think there will be a fair amount of interest in these figures, at this point I seek leave to table the letter from the Commissioner of Taxation which gave this information.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Whilst the figures for 1981-82 might be slightly better than last year's figures because of the large number of Australian films made in that year, it is certain that the 1982-83 figures will show that section 51 (1) schemes have taken out almost all of the investment and tax concessions available to the industry. What I want to ask now and what I have asked previously on more than one occasion in this place is: Why does the Government tolerate this draining of funds, this haemorrhaging of film investment funds, from our industry to overseas? The Government has been aware of the problem for a long time but has failed to take effective action.

SPEECH.PARA: As early as June 1981 this matter was raised in the Senate. Former Senator Puplick actually raised the activities of UAA in his speech on the introduction of the Government's tax incentive scheme for films. I have raised the problems created by section 51 (1) schemes on a number of occasions-in a fairly complete way in a speech to the Senate on 26 May this year and in subsequent question and Press releases. The media has widely publicised the effects of the section 51 (1 ) schemes. Australian Business carried a substantial article on the activities of UAA in February this year. Subsequently, the issue has been canvassed by all the financial Press and also in a number of television programs. I think Four Corners had a long item on this matter.

Numerous delegations from various sections of the film industry have come to Canberra to bring their concerns about this matter to the attention of the Government. Opposition members have met with them on many occasions. When the Government had still done nothing the industry got together in Sydney in October at the Theatre Royal to develop its strategies as an industry to deal with the problem. I was at that meeting, which was attended by over 700 people. At this stage I would like to read part of the resolution that was passed at that meeting. The resolution reads:
We express abhorrence at the rise of new film financing schemes operating under section 51 (1) of the Tax Act.
The next effect of such schemes is to:
1. Have the Australian taxpayers fund overseas produced, and controlled, films. This is highlighted in UAA's involvement in the films Arthur and Superman III.
2. Sabotage the efforts of Australian producers raising funds for genuinely Australian films since the section 51 (1) tax advantages more than double the tax concessions available in 10BA.
3. These schemes escape the requirements of 10BA arrangements which insist on concessions being granted to genuine Australian films only.
The resolution went on to state:

We call on the Federal Government to take immediate action to close this threat to the industry by including a strong anti-gearing provision for film expenditure under section 51 (1), in order to halt the activities of companies such as Trans-Pacific Media and UAA.

The response of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) has been too little and too late. After some weak-kneed statements he has finally set up a working party of industry representatives to develop procedures for overcoming the investment crisis. When the Australian film industry, which has brought so much to this country in terms of our international reputation and our cultural development and which has provided much needed jobs for the local work force, is on the brink of collapse, I think the decision of the Treasurer merely to set up a working party can hardly be regarded as adequate.

What should the Treasurer do? In the view of the Australian Labor Party the Treasurer should do what it will do as soon as it gets into government-that is, to make it clear to the public and to investors that section 51 (1) was not intended to operate in the way it is currently being used for film investment schemes and to announce that this loophole will be closed. I acknowledge that there may be technical problems in closing the loophole. Some time may elapse between the making of the statement and the closing of the loophole. But it ought to be clear, once the Treasurer announces his intention to do so, that the loophole will be closed. Presumably, sensible investors would not continue to invest in such schemes.

The other major task to which the Treasurer should address himself is ironing out the defects in the Government's Division 10BA film tax incentive scheme. First amongst these defects is the provision in that scheme which requires producers to mount, shoot, edit and release a film all within the one financial year in order to secure effective tax concessions for their investors. The Labor Party warned at the outset of what the consequences of this provision would be and, indeed, those warnings have turned out to be very well founded. What happens under this scheme is that there is an encouragement of tax avoidance. There is a bunching of productions because all the films have to be made within the same period and the amount of time is too short to make films properly. The quality of Australian films is suffering quite seriously as a result. This has already been noticed by international film critics and the reputation of Australian films overseas, which has been so high, is starting to suffer because of that.

The film industry has come up with some detailed proposals which would have the effect of allowing the films to be made, edited and marketed over a period of 24 months. We believe the Treasurer ought to give urgent and sympathetic attention to that recommendation. It is certainly the view of the Labor Party that it will , when in office, review the level of the concession-150 per cent-because it seems to it to be too high, but we believe the scheme should operate in such a way as to provide stability and permanence for the industry. At this stage we would co-operate with the Treasurer to get rid of this bunching effect and this unrealistically short timetable.

The last thing the Treasurer needs to do-I see my time is running out and I want to emphasise this point-to repair the damage that Government policies, or lack of effective Government policies, have caused to the Australian film industry is to tighten the Australian content requirements of a 10BA film. In particular, money paid as salaries to overseas film personnel should not attract the 150 per cent tax concession. This would avoid any repetition of productions such as Pirate Movie, which had two American lead actors plus an American director, art director and executive producer but somehow got its certificate as an Australian film and attracted tax concessions from the Australian taxpayers for all of the wage bills. My questions of the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) as Minister representing the Treasurer as to how this film managed to qualify for tax concessions under the Australian scheme have remained on the Notice Paper unanswered for many months. I think that in itself is a sign of the negligence of the Government with respect to this urgent matter .

The Australian film industry has in the past received strong bipartisan support from this Parliament. That the Government has allowed the film industry to reach its current desperate state is, as I have said, an act of negligence. That it fails to take decisive action at this stage I think is inexcusable. I hope that my remarks today, which I will convey to the Treasurer and to the Government, will cause the Government to act quickly and urgently to address what is a very serious problem. I hope that we can return very soon to a position where the whole of the Parliament is acting in a co-operative way to ensure a stable, successful and flourishing Australian film industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I want to take advantage of the few minutes that are available to refer again to the problems of East Timor and to repudiate the statements that were made by Mr Whitlam, a former Australian Prime Minister, at the recent United Nations discussion on decolonisation. I want to refer to the problems that have resulted from the aggressive action of the Indonesian Government in invading East Timor in December 1975 and the subsequent process of a so-called act of self- determination.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to remind the Senate that following World War II a number of important declarations were made, including the Atlantic Charter, the United Nations Declaration of Human Rights and the United Nations' own charter. These declarations established some very important fundamental principles including not only the principle of freedom of expression in political and religious matters but also the principle of self-determination. We have seen changes of tremendous magnitude in the last 30 years. A total of 64 nations were present at the foundation of the United Nations. The fact that this number now has crept up to almost 150 indicates the degree to which the act of self-determination has taken place-sometimes peacefully and sometimes not so peacefully. Nevertheless, the pious hopes expressed and the declarations made at the end of World War II have slowly but surely been put into effect.

We now have a world community of nations in which the principles of self- determination have been established for indigenous people. I do not believe that one can have different attitudes on this matter. I think either one supports the principles of self-determination or one does not. I support them unequivocally. I believe that the principles of self-determination have equal validity in respect of Afghanistan, Zimbabwe, Namibia and East Timor. Therefore, I completely and utterly repudiate the stand that was taken by Mr Whitlam at the United Nations, where he was grilled for a considerable number of hours about his attempts to defend the annexation by the Indonesians of a country that admittedly has a population of only 600,000. Many of the members of the United Nations and many of the nations in our Asian-Pacific region have populations of fewer than 600,000. Therefore, one cannot say that a different policy or different principle should apply because of the size of the nation. One can only accept that the principle of self-determination applies universally, unilaterally and indivisibly.

I want to go on the public record as supporting the courageous and, in my view, correct position that was taken by Senator McIntosh in a private capacity at the meeting that Mr Whitlam attended. Mr Whitlam tried to suggest that although Portuguese Timor, commonly known as East Timor, had been colonised by the Portuguese some 400 years ago the Portuguese had abdicated their responsibilities at the time of the overthrow of the right wing dictatorship in Portugal in 1974 by not taking a much more determined position in respect of East Timor, something which they did in respect of a number of territories which were part of the old Portuguese empire in the African continent. I do not disagree with that. However, I think that Mr Whitlam's suggestion that there is some indigenous ethnic link between the people of Timor and the people of Indonesia belies the fact that they are different races of people. Thus the former colony was entitled to self-determination, and the United Nations and surrounding countries had a responsibility to assist in that process.

Part of Mr Whitlam's argument was that the independent movement in East Timor really had no claim to legal government after the abdication of power by Portugal because it had not carried on a war of liberation against the Portuguese authority. What Mr Whitlam ignored, of course, was that the Army officers in Portuguese Timor, who were part of a junior officer movement in Portugal proper that overthrew the right wing dictatorship in that country, advised the people of Timor not to wage a war of liberation which they could not win because they did not have outside support. These officers, who belonged to a group which overthrew the dictatorship in Portugal and established a democratic state there, told the Timorese that they should bide their time until there took place in Portugal events which would enable a peaceful transfer of power from the old colonial regime to the indigenous people of Timor. I think that was the correct advice. Surely we would all support and encourage advice aimed at winning independence and establishing self-determination without bloodshed.

I give credit to the officers, some of whom I met when I visited Timor in early 1975 and subsequently met again when I went to Portugal some years ago, for giving the people that sort of advice. But Mr Whitlam has suggested that the people of East Timor, having taken that sort of advice, are not entitled to determine their own affairs and ought to be annexed by a major power in the region. Mr Whitlam went on to say that he had no knowledge of the situation. I remind Mr Whitlam that at a meeting of the National Executive of our party he admitted to me in a discussion about Timor that Australia knew everything that was going on in the region. I can only say that I accepted that statement because if our intelligence organisations did not know about the arms build-up on the borders of Timor there would have been something wrong with them. I would have thought that the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation would have had sufficient evidence at its disposal to advise the Australian Government.

In the light of discussions that Labor Ministers Moss Cass and Gordon Bryant and I, as a back bench member who had been to Timor, had with former Senator Willesee, who was then the Minister for Foreign Affairs, I can only say that Mr Whitlam's memory is very faded. Only a week or two before the Whitlam Government was removed from office as a result of the actions of former Governor-General Kerr, at one o'clock one morning when we were having a discussion about what we could do in respect of the problem that obviously existed in Timor, Senator Willesee indicated that his Department had knowledge of the Indonesian build-up in that area. So Mr Whitlam's memory of events is certainly faded and belies the facts conclusively.

I refer to an article that Peter Hastings wrote for the Sydney Morning Herald of 12 June 1975 as a result of my representations to Mr Whitlam following my first visit to East Timor. A simple request was made of Prime Minister Whitlam at that time about which Peter Hastings, strangely enough, having regard to his current attitude, made the point that there was a major advantage in Australia's having a consulate operating in East Timor. If we had opened a consulate there the whole course of events and the position today may well have been different. I cannot understand why Peter Hastings's attitude has changed, except that there is the school of thought in the Australian Department of Foreign Affairs, I suppose in some sections of the media and in the Australian public that at all costs we have to maintain a friendly and subservient attitude towards Indonesia. I do not accept that position if in observance of it people's rights are trampled upon. The people's rights in East Timor have been trampled upon.

I was fortunate enough to go back to East Timor in September of that year, again as a member of a parliamentary delegation, and to see the tremendous amount of support amongst ordinary people in Timor for the act of self- determination. There were large public rallies. We spoke to a Catholic bishop, nuns, church dignitories, shopkeepers, villagers and a whole range of people. What we were told was sufficient to indicate to us that the people of that small country-600,000 of them-and their representatives, the opinion makers in that country, were keen to have the right to determine their affairs. They did not want to be annexed by Indonesia. The Apodeti Party, which was the pro-Indonesia party, had very little support in East Timor.

I find it hard to understand how a person such as Mr Whitlam, who has stood for the realities of life in respect of foreign affairs, has succumbed to the pressures from Indonesia in the belief that it is more important to protect the interests of that country, which has many problems of its own, than it is to protect the interests of the people in Timor.

It is interesting that Senator McIntosh was able to bring back statements signed by substantial numbers of the United States House of Representatives and the United States Senate in respect of the problems in East Timor. Opinions were taken from across the whole political spectrum, as was the case in this place. Prominent members of both of the major political parties in the United States, the Democratic Party and the Republican Party, have written to the United States President and to the chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee in that country in support of Portugal-as indeed the United States did at the United Nations in proposing the motion that it did-which country has asserted that it has the right to determine the future of East Timor. The resolution that was finally adopted recognised that right. Substantial numbers of members of both Houses of the United States Parliament have signified to the American President their support of those important principles. I can only hope that sooner or later the people of East Timor will have the opportunity, as we demand in our country and is demanded in every other country, to determine their own affairs, to have self -determination. I hope that that country will not be annexed by a power that believes that it has the right to have influence in the whole region. If we give away that position, it seems to me that we will stand the risk of Indonesia saying sooner or later, that it has the right to be interested in Papua New Guinea and in parts of Melanesia. That is an objective which I think ought to be repudiated at this stage by any right-thinking person. I therefore deplore the views expressed by Mr Whitlam at the United Nations decolonisation discussions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the eight minutes remaining in this segment of the Senate's activities I wish to present some thoughts relating to some key features of the Australian Labor Party's national housing policy. I think it needs to be said at the outset that in having a national housing policy the Labor Party is immediately distinguished from the Liberal Party of Australia which, in seven years of neglect of this very important social and employment- generating aspect of our society, has seen housing stocks diminished to an intolerable degree and which at the same time has seen interest rates-coupled with diminishing real incomes, cause very real hardship to many Australians and their families. The fact is that the national Government needs to develop a policy in order to provide simple shelter for Australians, an increasing number of people, that is the key issue. For example, many hundreds of thousands of Australians dwell in caravan parks around the country, not out of choice but out of necessity. One can imagine the sort of living conditions that such a situation provides for bringing up a young family.

SPEECH.PARA: One also thinks beyond the issue of basic shelter to that of sheer fairness and equity within a rich society. Affluent people like Mrs Susan Sangster are paying some $6m for a waterfront home in Sydney saving, of course, another $1m in order to redecorate it. At the same time, millions of other Australians are struggling to fulfil their dream of purchasing a home at a manageable cost over a period of years, are facing public housing lists of such dimensions that it seems pointless to put one's name down, or are caught in the private rental market in which one out of every five Australians finds himself or herself. It is not often understood that 20 per cent of Australians depend on the private rental market in order to ensure their accommodation.

We are facing a crisis. There is no doubt about that. In late September churches right around Australia devoted a weekend to highlighting the crisis in housing. In recent days the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace has issued a report entitled 'House and Home.' I commend it to all those who want a clear and compassionate summary of the housing situation in Australia, with some very tough-minded suggestions as to some solutions. But the fact is that those churches and, indeed, other community groups have condemned the Government for not having a national housing policy. The Government does not have a national housing policy, as symbolised by the fact that there is now no federal Minister responsible for housing. In May 1982, that part of the ministry for housing and construction relating to housing was abolished. I think that is an indictment of the present Government. Certainly the Australian Labor Party, when it assumes office, will re-establish the Department of Urban and Regional Development as the means by which responsibility will be accepted by an incoming national Labor government for the provision of circumstances in which Australians can house themselves decently and at manageable cost.

In the five minutes now available to me I have time to talk only about the fact that in relation to public housing, for example, State governments are now getting only one-seventh of the finance they received from the Commonwealth seven years ago. One can imagine the social consequences of this for individual Australians. It was Canon Hollingworth, who, in a letter to the Australian some weeks ago, condemned the present Federal Government for the grave restriction on funds moving into the public housing sector over which it has presided during its term of office. The incoming ALP government will certainly renegotiate the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. It will make available an extra $170m in the first year for public housing construction and public rental accommodation. It will make available an extra $10m for community amenities in public housing estates. We see the provision of housing as being much more than the provision of a mere shelter. Community amenities are part of the provision of a full social context for the bringing up of young Australians in particular. We say that some $15m ought to be made available for use by local government in areas of high housing priority.

The public housing program needs to be reinvigorated, not only, as I say, for the provision of housing opportunities to those who are squeezed at the moment in the private rental market-some one in 20 Australians find themselves in that sector-but also in order to stimulate the construction industry. Governments can put money into public housing but, of course, governments do not own the brick kilns, the timber mills, the carpet factories, the window glazing factories and so on. All of this money will flow into the community via the stimulus which undoubtedly housing construction provides. It will also, of course, provide opportunities for the utilising of the skills of Australians which are at present not used at all because of the failure of so many firms in the construction industry and the consequent putting aside, throwing into redundancy , of many skilled tradesmen and apprentices. In other words, a stimulus to public housing construction will not merely serve a real social need in the community but will provide that stimulus to the construction industry which will provide benefits right throughout the economy. That is understood, I believe, by every Australian. Every Australian would understand that this is not just throwing money away on some centralist scheme; it is providing money for distribution in as effective a way as is possible throughout the community.

In relation to those in the private sector rental market, many low income households find themselves paying sometimes in excess of half of their weekly income in rent. They find themselves caught in the pincer movement between higher rents and diminishing real incomes as either household income is reduced because of fewer working days by members of that household or even, of course, because of the catastrophe of unemployment. As more private rental accommodation is purchased as an investment by unscrupulous persons who keep on escalating rents month by month, without any regard for the tenants, one finds an intolerable situation. A Labor government will extent supplementary assistance of $10 a week to all social security beneficiaries and adults receiving unemployment benefits for six weeks or longer and who pay rent or lodging charges to private landlords. That is the least we can do as a compassionate, caring society, to help those who find themselves in the intolerable situation of being reduced to a budgetary situation in which they can barely put aside enough money for food and other necessities of life, and who find themselves without sufficient money to pay rent to their private landlord. The Labor Party will try to remedy that situation, along with public housing, in order to provide justice and national leadership in the provision of housing to all Australians.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a first time.
Motion (by Senator Messner) agreed to:
That the second reading of the Bill be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —A request was made for a copy of the advice of the Department of Primary Industry dates 19 May regarding breaches by certain manufacturers of the conditions applying to advances made by the Australian Dairy Corporation to manufacturers of prescribed dairy produce. It is the Government's policy to provide copies of documents for parliamentary committees whenever possible. However, the departmental minute requested by the Committee contains information on the commercial operations of certain manufacturers, the public release of which potentially could damage unreasonably the operations of the companies involved. An Estimates committee has no power to receive evidence in a camera. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) also believes that this commercial information would be exempt from disclosure under the Freedom of Information Act, were that Act to apply. However , a copy of the Department's minute of 19 May is made available herewith, with such information deleted. It is a two-page minute. I seek leave to incorporate the minute in Hansard, although, as I say, there are deletions of those matters which require commercial confidentiality.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
MINUTE PAPER
The Minister,
ADVANCES MADE BY THE AUSTRALIAN DAIRY CORPORATION TO MANUFACUTURERS OF PRESCRIBED DAIRY PRODUCTS
Purpose
To advise you of apparent abuses of the Australian Dairy Corporation (ADC) system of making advances against prescribed dairy products held in store by manufacturers.
Background
Under section 17 of the Dairy Produce Act 1924, as amended, the ADC is authorised to make advanced to owners of dairy produce which has been placed under its control.
Advances are made at a rate approved by yourself from borrowings made by the ADC from the Rural Credits Department of the Reserve Bank under Commonwealth guarantee.
A condition of all advances is that they must be repaid before the product to which they relate is withdrawn from store.
A further provision is that such advances must be repaid no later than six months after the end of the production period in which the product was manufactured.
For the 1980/81 season, however, the ADC Board agreed that repayment could be deferred until 31 March 1982 with a commercial rate of interest being applied during the period of the loan extension.
Recent Investigations
The ADC has recently conducted spot checks of some factories to ensure that advances are secured by stock on hand.
Further Investigations

Because of the situation pertaining in the Companies already checked, and the fact that some other Companies have subsequently made substantial repayments of advances, the ADC is widening the scope of its investigations and checks will be made on further factories in the Eastern States over this and next week.
Future Action
ADC management is currently developing new procedures for the granting of advances and the policing of Company undertakings to ensure a similar situation does not develop in the future.
The Department has requested a full report from the ADC including details of any breaches of Regulations and/or false completion of returns.
Necessary Action

It is not considered necessary for you to take any action at this time but I will keep you advised of the outcome of the ADC's further investigations and of action taken to tighten control over ADC advances.
A. E. WALLACE First Assistant Secretary Dairy and Intensive Livestock Division

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I have a copy, too, straight away?

—Yes. The Committee also seeks certain information relating to PT Indomilk. The sale of the ADC's shares in PT Indomilk is still the subject of legal proceedings both in Australia and in Indonesia. It would be improper for me to comment on matters that are now in issue before the courts. I can, however, provide the Committee with some comments that may be of assistance. The first comment concerns the role of the Minister for Primary Industry in approving of any proposed sale. Section 25 of the Dairy Produce Act requires the approval of the Minister before the ADC enters into a contract-not being a contract for the acquisition or disposal of dairy produce-under which the Corporation is to receive an amount exceeding $100,000. Any sale of the ADC' s shares must take place under the laws and regulations of Indonesia. Provided that a proposed sale has all the authorisations necessary under Indonesian law the Minister has indicated that he is prepared to agree to it. I can confirm that the Department of Primary Industry has been advised that PT Indomilk is currently experiencing difficult trading conditions. No link with the matter of the sale of the ADC's shares should be inferred from this simple statement of fact.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Finance ( Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) for the information. The first matter related to the departmental minute dated 19 May. In spite of the Senate inquiry and what is generally known as the Asia Dairy Industry scandal, if that minute of 19 May is the only record on file, it is clear that the Department of Primary Industry is still tardy in notifying the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) of irregularities within authorities under his control. The irregularities were disclosed at the board meeting on 4 and 5 May at which a departmental representative was present. Yet, according to what we have been told today and according to the minute paper that has been tabled, the Minister was not notified for another 14 days. I suggest that that is a longer time lag than was justified.

SPEECH.PARA: On the second point-that is, the sale of the Australian Dairy Corporation's equity in PT Indomilk-the Minister is stating, if I heard him correctly, is that he has no objection to the sale or that he would approve the sale, one or the other. The Minister, over the last 12 months, has been all over the place on this question. The heads of agreement which were signed just over a year ago were conditional upon the approval of the Indonesian authorities and the Australian Minister, whose approval is required under section 25, I think, of the Dairy Produce Act. The Minister wrote to the Corporation on 16 November. He said:
I would not approve of the proposed sale unless I had an assurance that the Indonesian Government, under whose laws and regulations the sale must take place , would give its approval.

The first point I make is that the Minister chose gratuitously to intervene in the sale. If the Indonesian Government chose not to approve of the sale that is an action which the Indonesian Government is entitled to take and a decision it would have to live with. No valid reason whatsoever has been given for the pre- emptive intervention of the Australian Minister under which his approval would not be given unless there was an assurance that the Indonesian Government would also approve. Quite gratuitously and for whatever reason the Australian Minister chose to save the Indonesian Government from taking a decision which may have been embarrassing to it. It was believed, of course, that the Indonesian Government would not approve the sale although, as far as I am aware, no official statement has ever been issued by the Indonesian Government to that effect. A copy of a telex dated 9 December 1981 to Mr Nixon from Mr Vawser, the Chairman of the Dairy Corporation, cast serious doubts upon whether the Indonesian Government did, in fact, object to the sale anyway. Included in this telex is an extract from the Indonesian Times dated 4 December which states:
Minister Sumarlin-
That is the relevant Indonesian Minister-

assured reporters that no Indonesian Government official had ever exerted any sort of pressure on the ADC or Australian officials to prevent the smooth transfer of the ADC holdings in P.T. Indomilk to P.T. Kebun Bunga . . . Business circles here view Minister Sumarlin's statement as the clearance that the sale of ADC shareholdings will proceed in accordance with the Indonesian laws.

That is the end of the quotation from the Indonesian Times. So, in addition to the serious questions, to say the least, which one could raise about the pre- emptive and gratuitous intervention by the Australian Minister in the sale, serious doubts are cast upon the accuracy of the premise upon which he apparently acted. In a further letter dated 2 June this year to Mr Vawser, Mr Nixon said, inter alia:
. . . I clearly indicated to you-
That is, Mr Vawser-
and Messrs J. P. Bennett and B. A. Norwood that the Australian Government was not standing in the way of a sale to P.T. Kebun Bunga.
That cannot be reconciled with the statement in the Minister's letter of 16 November in which he said:
. . . I would not approve the proposed sale unless I had an assurance that the Indonesian Government . . . would give its approval.
In the letter of 2 June the Minister continued:

You will also recall that I mentioned during our meeting that should the Indonesian Government change its attitude and permit the sale of the ADC shareholding to P.T. Kebun Bunga, I would be prepared to agree to such a sale.

Within one letter an ambivalent position is expressed. The Minister, on the one hand, asserted that he never has frustrated and never would frustrate the sale of the Dairy Corporation's equity and two paragraphs later he adds the condition that he would do so only if there were an assurance that the Indonesian Government would agree to it. As far as I know, the only item on the public record, at least on the attitude of the Indonesian Government, is the quotation from the Indonesian Times which I have already read and in which the relevant Minister in Indonesia is quoted as saying that the Indonesian Government will not intervene. Incidentally, I do not accept as valid the Minister's excuse that some of these matters being now before the courts is an adequate reason for refusing to tell the Committee whether Mr Vawser warned him that PT Indomilk could drift into insolvency. But as a result of the Minister's intervention, the $10m equity which just over a year ago the Corporation had in PT Indomilk, might well be lost entirely. The Corporation could have had the $10m a year ago. It was not allowed to take the $10m because the Australian Minister took pre- emptive action, apparently based on an assumption that the Indonesian Government would intervene to block the sale. That was an assumption for which there is no evidence-no evidence of which I am aware, anyway-and the accuracy of which must be seriously doubted because there is on public record evidence to the contrary and, even if the Indonesian Government would have been likely to object, there was no reason for the Australian Minister to intervene before the Indonesian Government had made a decision.

As a result of that negligence or incompetence, or whatever it was, by the Australian Minister, the dairy industry stabilisation fund does not have $10m which it could have had. The joint venture company, PT Indomilk, on the last report given to me, was operating at a loss in excess of $2 1/2m a year. Kebun Bunga has taken the Austrlian Dairy Corporation to court because of its failure to proceed with the sale, and there is a grave danger-whether this will be officially confirmed as comming out of the mouth of Mr Vawser-that the company will go into liquidation and that the equity will be lost entirely. There is one further point. I understand that PT Indomilk owes the Corporation $7 1/2m for products supplied to it, and that must also to some extent be at risk.

I cannot understand why the Minister acted in the way that he did, but there is no doubt that, as a result of that precipitate and gratuitous action, the Australian dairy industry will lose a considerable amount of money, an amount which could ultimately be as high as $15m. I think that the Minister's treatment of the Senate on this matter has been far from satisfactory. He has treated the Senate with contempt by his failure to give any adequate explanation for his actions or for the changes of position which are revealed in the correspondence from which I have quoted and in other correspondence from which I have not quoted. If the Minister for Finance has any response to the dairy industry matters which I have raised, naturally I would be grateful to hear it.

I have another question to put to the Minister, or the officers, regarding drought relief. At the time of the Estimates Committee H hearing in mid- September, it was stated that farmers in drought declared areas would, subject to some other qualifications, qualify for the interest and fodder subsidies. I am advised that in South Australia there is no such thing as a drought declared area. What procedures have been devised by the Department to cope with that situation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no further comments to make on the two matters raised earlier. With regard to drought relief, the arrangements are that the State governments declare the drought areas, and there are requirements for the State to incur its level of expenditure and then there is the participation by the Commonwealth Government in the drought relief programs. If the South Australian Government does not declare drought areas, there is no participation by the farmers in the drought relief measures that have been announced. The core measures that relate to State governments in the whole program of drought relief are applied. It is within the States that the measures have their validity because of the declaration of drought areas.

—Perhaps I could ask a more specific question. We all know that there was a change of government in South Australia recently. I think that the election was on 6 November. The measures were announced more than two months prior to 6 November. Did the previous South Australian Government declare any areas of South Australia to be drought affected? If not, has the present Government declared any areas in the couple of weeks that it has been in office?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that in South Australia no areas were declared but that farms have been declared in that State. Where a farm is declared by the State Government, it becomes eligible to attract the Commonwealth drought relief.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Finance ( Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) for that reply. On the same subject, the cost estimates provided in the second reading speech that accompanied the legislation were that the interest subsidy would cost $36m this financial year and that the fodder subsidy would cost $320m this financial year. My first question is whether there has been any revision of that cost estimate, because it would have been made on the basis of very limited information at the time, and particularly , having been made at the time when it was, it could not have been known with any degree of certainty that the wheat crop in much of New South Wales and Victoria would fail. We now know that the wheat crop has almost failed in most of New South Wales and Victoria. Therefore, with present knowledge, one would expect that the drought is more widespread and more severe than would probably have been assumed when those estimates were drawn up. Has there been a revision of those cost figures? If so, what is the revised figure? The second question is : Whether or not there is a revised figure, what was the general assumption about the duration of the drought incorporated into an original or a revised estimate?

SPEECH.PARA: Just in case that is not clearly understood, the sort of information for which I am looking is whether it was assumed that the growing season would start before the end of April in 80 per cent of Victoria, or whether it was assumed that the growing season would commence, say, before the end of May in 80 per cent of Victoria? I am asking about the assumptions about the time at which normal seasonal rains could be anticipated in the drought affected areas of southern New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia. In northern New South Wales where there is a summer rainfall belt, or at least a belt of substantial summer rain, was it assumed when the estimates were drawn up that the summer rainfall in those areas that have a summer growing season would be normal?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to the drought relief, this was a special appropriation. The Bill included the sums mentioned by Senator Walsh. That was the estimate that would be required for this financial year. Built into that estimate was some inclusion of funds in the belief that there would be a worsening drought and, bearing in mind that it was to cover the whole year, to the end of the financial year, on the best estimate of all factors that could be taken in account, this was the sum believed to be required. There has been no revision of the cost estimate. The Bill that was introduced for the $350m-odd is the estimate. At this stage there has been no revised estimate.
—Have agreements been signed with any of the States pursuant to that legislation? If not, are the officers or the Minister able to give any indication of when the agreements might be signed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that all the agreements have been signed by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon). I think the New South Wales agreement is either ready for signature or has already been signed. The agreements for the other States are receiving the attention of the State Ministers but I cannot give any estimate as to when these matters will be finalised.
-I did not hear the Minister's response exactly. Did she say that New South Wales has signed the agreement and the other States have not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The advice available is that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) was informed that New South Wales, I think yesterday, signed the agreement with the Commonwealth. I am not able to give a proposed date on which the signatures of the other States are expected to be received.
—The Committee will now proceed to a consideration of the estimates for the Department of Trade and Resources.

-Mr Chairman, I have just one query. I understand that there is a plan to transfer the Overseas Trade Publicity Committee from Melbourne to Canberra. Does that plan still exist? If so, what is the likely date on which the transfer will take place?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the plan is still proposed but no likely date as to when that transfer may take place is available at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed expenditures agreed to.
Schedule agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported without requests; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) proposed:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had thought that having forewarned that I would be speaking at the third reading stage of the Appropriation Bill ( No. 1) and having asked a series of questions the answers to those questions would have been made available to me today before I spoke. However, as they have not been made available I will have to repeat the questions and hope that answers will be forthcoming before the Parliament rises or I will have to seek some other means of endeavouring to get the answers. I wish to deal with two departments, firstly, the Department of the Capital Territory regarding Mr Anthony's home loan and, secondly, the Department of Administrative Services. It appears from reading today's Age that the Government has backed away from some of the statements that Ministers made earlier in response to my questions last week about travelling allowances for three Ministers. Yesterday I asked a series of questions dealing with Mr Anthony's home loan. I asked whether in 1964 when Mr Anthony and other people availed themselves of Commonwealth home loans they were given an added incentive to purchase their homes at a 10 per cent discount on the purchase price as well as paying the low interest rate. I further asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Has there always been a requirement that a person must be a resident of Canberra?
That is, to qualify for the home loan. I also asked:
what is the definition of 'resident'? For the purposes of travelling allowances, what were declared as the home bases of Mr Anthony and Mr Sinclair for each month of 1981?
I went on to say:
I will be asking that question at the third reading stage of the debate.
As the answers have not been forthcoming I now have to put those questions again into the record in the hope that some answers will be given.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have the answers.

—The Minister said that she has the answers. I am now in the delicate position that if I resume my seat I will not be able to rise again and continue my remarks at the third reading stage of this Bill. That puts me in a difficult situation. However I will--
—Seek leave to make a statement.

—I will not be able even to look at the answers so I will continue with my remarks, particularly about what has arisen from the travelling allowance issue. I will not need to say any more about the home loan except that this morning in the mail I received a letter from a public servant in Canberra who signed himself B. G. Brent. I looked up the electoral roll and noticed that he is a public servant. It is the only letter that I have received which supports Mr Anthony and I am now wondering whether a crank has written the letter and used Mr Brent's name. I have not had time to contact this person but if the letter was written by Mr Brent he is not a very capable public servant. He says in the letter that he heard only the tail end of my speech yesterday on the radio. Yet he went into a diatribe in his letter about what I had to say. He would not have had time to read Hansard because the letter was posted at, I think, the central mail exchange at 11 p.m. last night. He hastily wrote the letter and drew his own conclusions as to what I was talking about. I will correspond with this person and send him the Hansard. It may well be that someone is sending him up by writing that letter and signing his name on it. It has the correct address. A person named B. G. Brent does live at 6 Prior Place, Farrer. The author of the letter says that he fully supports Mr Anthony. I have had literally hundreds of communications discussing Mr Anthony's home loan since I first raised the matter 12 months ago.
—And petitions.

—Thousands of people have signed petitions. They were all protesting against this cheap home loan. As I said, this is the first person who has contacted me who supports Mr Anthony having a cheap home loan for 45 years, and paying off only $395.06 in the last 11 months at an interest rate of 4 3/4 per cent. As I said the other day, families in desperate situations, particularly in my State, are unable to maintain their home payments and they live in fear that their homes will be sold over their heads.
—Does Mr Anthony get a reasonable salary?

—Mr Anthony, as we all know, gets a very high salary. He is presently the Acting Prime Minister of this country and would be one of the highest paid persons in the land today. But he must have very heavy financial commitments on other things as he can afford to pay only $395.06 off a home loan in 11 months.
—He is not advocating a freeze on Ministers' travelling allowances, is he?

—As my colleague Senator Bolkus reminds me, Mr Anthony's plea that restraint be exercised by the work force in regard to wages has not been accompanied by any advocacy of a freeze on Ministers' travelling allowances, whether for travel in Australia or overseas. As we read from the documents that were tabled the other day by the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle), Mr Anthony's overseas travel has cost the Australian taxpayer an enormous amount of money. From a quick look at the figures for 1981, we find that the amount claimed by the Minister for Trade and Resources, Mr Anthony, and his spouse, for overseas travel, accommodation, meals and incidental expenses was $468,336. For his staff the amount was $54,576. That is what Mr Anthony alone has cost the taxpayer. One could comment on the figures for quite a few of the other Ministers, but the cost to the taxpayer of Mr Anthony's travel is about two thirds that of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser)-the greatest traveller and tourist at taxpayer expense that this country has ever witnessed. Mr Anthony puts himself in a very awkward position when he continually appears on television and radio, as he has done in the last week, particularly, talking about a wage freeze and asking the work force, especially the lower paid workers , who are in desperate financial trouble, to exercise wage restraint. People outside can judge for themselves what type of person we have at present as Acting Prime Minister. I am concerned-I mentioned this the other day about Mr Anthony's remarks about home bases. An article in the Canberra Times reports that he said that he wanted to have a home base at Murwillumbah and that he stated further:

SPEECH.PARA: I've had one base, which is Canberra, for working, and my own home in Murwillumbah . . . It has been that way ever since I was a minister.
The article continues:
He reiterated that Murwillumbah was his principal base and always had been.

He is also on record as having said that in other places and as being supported in that statement by his party colleague, Mr Sinclair. Mr Sinclair is reported in the Sydney Morning Herald of 5 November as stating through a spokesman-he has not denied it-that:
. . . the home base for the purposes of travelling allowance was his property Bendemeer, near Tamworth, in his electorate. His home base had always been Bendemeer.

An exercise on the figures that were given shows that if we add to the days in 1981 on which Mr Sinclair was entitled to domestic travelling allowance-286 in number-the days on which he was out of the country on overseas business, only 57 days were available to him to be in his own electorate. We read in the paper yesterday that despite the time that Mr Sinclair has been in office in the Federal Parliament he has only recently opened an office in his electorate to service the people. He has had his office in his State capital city as have a couple of Government members from South Australia-I refer to the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) and the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Giles) -have never had an electoral office in the electorates they represent, yet are entitled to an extra allowance because they represent large electorates. They neither have an electorate office in their electorates nor live there. They live in the suburban area of Adelaide. Country people who want to see them must visit them at the Commonwealth Office Building, 1 King William Street, Adelaide. Members of the Liberal Government speak with two tongues, one which suits them and one with which they damn the work force of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sinclair is worried that Laurie Daly will win his seat.

—My colleague Senator Sibraa has just reminded me that Mr Sinclair is worried that Mr Fred Daly's son, Laurie, will win the seat that he represents. That is why he has opened an office there. He will certainly need to spend more than 57 nights in that electorate between now and the next election if he is to retain that seat.

SPEECH.PARA: Another interesting thing that emerges from a study of these documents which were tabled in the Parliament the other day, is that if we add Mr Sinclair's tax -free travelling allowance in Australia which amounted to $21,314 for 1981 to his tax-free electoral allowance of $20,300, we find that Mr Sinclair received from the taxpayers last year a total of $41,614 tax tree. If we divide that figure by 52 we find that in addition to all the other perks of office he received $800 a week tax free. One can also add to that his base salary of $38, 500, which all honourable members receive, and his ministerial allowance of $8, 000. Thus he is obliged to pay tax on $46,500 but receives $46,614 on which he is not obliged to pay tax. These are the people who day after day, on television , on radio and in the newspapers, call for wage restraint by the work force. Of course they can call for wage restraint when they receive that amount of money. How many workers in Australia today would like to receive $800 a week tax free and on the side, have such a base salary and ministerial allowance, plus the allowance that Mr Anthony, for instance, has received for all of his overseas trips? I have just read the amounts involved. They total more than $400,000.

When Mr Sinclair was the Minister for Communications, which was for only part of the time, the cost of his overseas travel was $31,492, plus $8,920 for his staff. We can see that these people are really on clover. That is what the public is growling about. After I raised these matters in the course of questions last week, they received a lot of publicity. Subsequently, we had denials from Mr Anthony, Mr Sinclair and Mr Street. I was very interested to read on the front page of the Age today an article by Michelle Grattan and Ian Davis which states, 'Ministers seek travel allowance ruling'. These people are running the country yet they do not even know what the travel allowance is really all about. The article states under a Canberra byline:
The Federal Government has asked the Remuneration Tribunal to clarify its rules for travelling allowances claimed by Ministers and other members of Parliament.
Last night the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Street, indicated that if the tribunal's reply suggested that he had wrongly claimed allowances for some days he would repay the funds.

Members of the National Party of Australia have never made such an offer. I am sure they will not. I well recall years ago, when Mr Daly was the Minister for Administrative Services, a huge bill for Avis cars. Mr Sinclair was using these cars after he went out of office and would not pay the bill, which, was for about $1,500. The Government of the day had to foot the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are criticising your side as well now.

—Senator Kilgariff can look in the Hansard. He will see it all written there. These are the types of people who will use taxpayers' money but, when they are found out, refuse to pay. That is the National Party. That is apparently why Senator Kilgariff came in here as a member of the Country Party and bailed out-because he could not stand the way it operated. The article goes on to state:

SPEECH.PARA: The request to the Tribunal, made on Tuesday by the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Newman, follows controversy over the travelling allowances claimed by Mr Street, the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony,-
Of course, he is the Acting Prime Minister now-
and the Minister for Defence, Mr Sinclair.
The article goes on to state that:
The Government has asked the tribunal to give more details on how 'principal place of residence' applies to Ministers from country areas who cannot run a Ministerial office from near their home.
Why can they not run a ministerial office from near their homes? The article states further:
At the Monday meeting-
This is, of course, a meeting of Ministers. This has caused a lot of concern. The meeting was held before these figures were tabled in the Parliament-
Mr Street, Mr Anthony and Mr Sinclair were anxious to get the definition of ' principal place of residence' spelled out.

A spokesman for Mr Street said last night: 'If it was found after a precise definition that money was required to be paid back, there would be no question'. Presumably, any refund would apply only after the tribunal's July ruling on ' principal place of residence'.
So if any money is to be paid back it will be only from 1 July of this year; it will not be for last year. The article states further:
The spokesman said that Mr Street spent more time at his Melbourne home than at Barwon Heads.

Yet we know that he has designated Barwon Heads as his home base. When he is away from there as a Minister he can get the travelling allowance. But if a back bencher is away from his home base he does not get it, unless he is in Canberra for the sittings of the Parliament, for Senate committee meetings or for meetings of his own party which have been authorised by his leader. We can see from that article that, after all the blunt denials about those questions which I asked last week, the Government is now backing away and is seeking from the Tribunal a ruling on the definition of 'home base'. That is why I will ask a series of questions.

I now refer to the tabling on Tuesday in the Senate by Senator Guilfoyle of certain documents relating to the travel allowance paid to Ministers and Opposition office holders. When the Minister for Finance tabled that statement she said that she was tabling the travel allowances for all office holders. In the Tribunal's 1982 report-I have it here; it was tabled in Parliament-there is mention of Australian Democrats office holders. The Leader and the Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats are office holders yet their allowances were not mentioned in the statement tabled. I wonder why those details were omitted? Perhaps the Minister can tell me and next week we might get a statement showing the travel allowances paid to those people.

It will be recalled that when I asked these questions last week I queried only the travel allowance payments to three Ministers-Mr Anthony, Mr Sinclair and Mr Street. When the answer was given by Senator Guilfoyle-I had said that I had no objection to the tabling of a statement showing all travel allowance payments-a schedule was incorporated showing the TA paid to all Ministers and to the Leader and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives and their counterparts in the Senate. But no mention was made of the Leader and the Deputy Leader of the third political party in the Parliament. Therefore, I am anxiously waiting to see whether we get those figures.

I have further questions to ask. I hope the answer to my first question will now be forthcoming as the Ministers have raised the issue. My question relates to the change in the definition of 'home base' for the purpose of payment of travelling allowance contained in the Remuneration Tribunal's 1982 review which represented a considerable tightening up of procedures. There had to be a reason for those procedures being tightened up. The answer I received said that neither the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman), who is responsible for this area, nor officers of the Department of Administrative Services had made any recommendations or requests to the Tribunal. There had to be a reason for this tightening up. It did not just happen out of the blue. There had to be a reason for it. In the new wording there is no provision for a Minister to nominate any residence he wishes as happened under the previous wording. The 1982 review states that a Minister's home base shall be his or her principal place of residence. So it ought to be. It ought to be the same as in the case of a back bencher.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did they employ their families at their home bases too, senator, as research assistants, or did you just do that by yourself?

—Perhaps Senator Lewis should have a look at some people on his side before he starts throwing stones. I certainly do not employ any member of my family as a research assistant. I do not know what Senator Lewis and some of his colleagues do. He has some knowledge of the practice; he might tell the Senate how many members of the Liberal Party employ members of their families as electorate assistants.
—I am just asking if you employ your family.

—Senator Lewis can make a speech after me if he has some accusations to make. Does the Minister agree that the new wording represents considerable tightening up of procedures? I have dealt with that-it certainly does. I ask the Minister if she will table, tomorrow if possible, or next week, copies of all the memoranda or advice that was submitted to the Remuneration Tribunal in relation to the definition of home base in the Remuneration Tribunal 's 1982 determination. In particular, will the Minister table all copies of advice submitted to the Remuneration Tribunal on the subject of definition of ' home base' by senior officers of the Department of Administrative Services? Does she agree that it is highly unlikely that the Remuneration Tribunal would have decided to change the wording of the definition of 'home base' in the 1982 review without some evidence having been submitted to it outlining the need for such change?

SPEECH.PARA: Those are some of the questions that I pose today; I have a few more yet. Will the Minister table a list of all the designated home bases of all Ministers in the Government for the years 1980-81 and 1981-82? Will the Minister table documents identifying the payment of travel allowance to all Ministers on Christmas Day of 1980 and 1981? Since the 1982 determination by the Remuneration Tribunal has there been any change in the nomination of a home base by any Minister in the Government? I could ask the same question about back benchers although it does not really apply to them. It is spelt out in the Tribunal determination that back benchers can have only one home base. They are not entitled to TA unless they are in Canberra for the sitting of Parliament or the sitting of committees. Members of Senate committees are entitled to the allowance if they are away interstate on a committee. There is very little scope for a back bencher to be paid TA to which he is not entitled.

Finally, will the Minister table copies of the documents outlining any changes in the nomination of home base or principal place of residence since the 1982 review? I have put forward a series of questions. The Minister has indicated to me that she has some answers to some of the questions which I raised the other day. I hope that the answers she has will suffice for my purpose. If so, I will not have to pursue this matter any further. I also hope I can clarify a matter referred to in a letter I received this morning as a result of my being misheard on the radio. I asked people in Adelaide who are under threat of losing their homes to write not to me but to Mr Anthony or Mr Fraser, particularly to Mr Anthony, if they are running into trouble with home loan payments. He obviously is well versed in how to pay off just $395.06 in 11 months. He would be able to give them some very good advice as to how to deal with their bank or building society. I am sure he would help them because he has helped himself in no uncertain terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are always helping themselves.

—As my colleague says, they are always helping themselves. That is typical of the National Party. If they write to Mr Anthony I am sure that he will do all he can to assist them so that they will not be thrown out into the street with their wives and families. A young chap came to see me the other day. He has contracted brucellosis at a meat works. His compensation case is pending, but before the case has been heard he has been threatened with a court order and a summons. He has to pay off his home or they will sell it up. That young gentleman has four children, one of whom is a spina bifida case in a wheelchair. When it gets down to real money terms the banking institutions of this country have very little compassion for people who have fallen on bad times because of the policies of this Government-policies which have led to high unemployment and high interest rates. Chaos is being wreaked throughout the community by a government that is not capable of doing the things that it promised to do. I am sure that as soon as the electors get an opportunity, at the next election, there will be a change of government. We will try to get this country back onto an even keel again even though, as my leader has said, it will take up to six years to clear up the mess with which we are now faced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McLaren mentioned that the Australian Labor Party candidate for the Federal seat of New England is Laurence Daly, son of the former member of the House of Representatives and Labor Minister Fred Daly. He is, of course, Mr Sinclair's opponent for that seat. That reminded me of an exchange between the Dalys and the Sinclairs that occurred some time late last year, I think, when Mr Sinclair said that Laurence Daly was not a real person; he was just a puppet for his father. Laurence Daly's reply was this offer to Mr Sinclair: If Mr Sinclair did not talk about Laurence Daly's father, Laurence Daly would not talk about Mr Sinclair's father.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise two matters arising from discussion during the Committee stage of this debate. As yet no satisfactory replies have been received to them. The first concerns the circumstances under which and the precise date on which the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) and the head of that Department approached Mr Costigan regarding the suggestion of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) that Mr Costigan conduct an inquiry into the business transactions between Mr Denis Horgan and representatives of Mr Brian Maher. When the Treasurer (Mr Howard) was asked on 14 October why Mr Costigan was not conducting the inquiry, as originally suggested, the Treasurer replied that he was not really too sure about it but he thought that Mr Costigan had been approached by the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Newman, who handles royal commissions, by the departmental head or by some other senior officer of the Department. As has been observed previously, it was rather extraordinary that the Treasurer could be so imprecise about a matter which had been the subject of several special meetings of the Cabinet.

Subsequently, questions were asked in the Committee stage of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) replied ultimately, on behalf of Mr Newman, that the Minister and the departmental head discussed the question with Mr Costigan-I use the Minister's words-'during the week beginning 18 September 1982'. That reply provoked a question yesterday from Senator McIntosh and a reply in which the Minister for Finance said that she would seek advice as to whether the communication was in writing, by telephone, or in what form. She added that she did not have the information at present. Again, I observe that, given that this matter was initially of sufficient importance to induce several special meetings of Cabinet, it is surprising to say the least that a Minister, knowing that she will be questioned on this matter, is not more adequately briefed.

But that is not my main point. I return to the line 'during the week beginning 18 September 1982'. The date of 18 September was a Saturday, so the Senate has been given a reply to a question-presumably delivered in writing to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle-which refers to a week beginning on a Saturday. We have known Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle to have problems with numbers previously but we have not known her previously to have problems with the days of the week. It is not necessarily just a trivial or careless error because, as late as 22 September, the Prime Minister was still saying that Mr Costigan was the obvious man to do the job. I agree with the Prime Minister that Mr Costigan was the obvious man to do the job because at least two of the companies that Denis Horgan sold to the Maher organisation finished up on the bottom of the harbour with registered painters and dockers as directors. It is not only entirely appropriate but also logical that the Royal Commissioner inquiring into the activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union should extend his inquiry, if requested to do so, to cover the transactions between Mr Horgan, Mr Maher and, ultimately, registered painters and dockers.

As late as 22 September the Prime Minister was saying that Mr Costigan should do the job. Yesterday the Minister for Finance told us that during the week beginning 18 September-during the week beginning on a Saturday-Minister Newman and the departmental head discussed the matter with Mr Costigan.
