She added that Mr Costigan was willing to act only in his capacity as Royal Commissioner and the Government decided that that was inappropriate. Presumably we can agree with the Government, or the Minister will agree with the Opposition, that weeks do not start on a Saturday. But what I want to know is precisely when that alleged discussion took place. If it was as early as 18 September, why was the Prime Minister still saying four days later that Mr Costigan was the obvious person to do the job? To say the least, I find it very hard to believe that such a discussion did take place on 18 September.

I also seek from the Minister for Finance a response-she undertook to do this yesterday in reply to a question from Senator McIntosh-as to when she will tell the Senate whether there was any communication in writing or by telephone between the Minister or departmental head and Mr Costigan. I add to that a request for the precise date or dates on which such consultation took place. I believe-nothing that the Government has done since this matter was first raised has done anything to shake that belief; indeed, it has confirmed it because the Government's answers have been evasive and in the most recent instance, at least on a matter of detail, clearly in error-that what happened was that the Prime Minister realised that he had to be seen to be doing something about this government office holder who had been revealed by documents tabled and incorporated in Parliament to have been a director of at least nine companies which were registered in three States and sold to two different tax promoters and who was holder of seven discretionary government positions. That is why there were special Cabinet meetings every five minutes.

The Prime Minister wanted to throw his encumbrance overboard-to sack Mr Horgan from the government positions-but some other Ministers would not agree. Hence there were a number of special Cabinet meetings. But the Prime Minister, believing that he had to be seen to be doing something, said: 'We will ask Mr Costigan to conduct an inquiry'. Then some of the other Ministers came to him and said: 'Hang on. That fellow is actually serious about exposing tax dodgers and even if you load the terms of reference of this inquiry'-this is what ultimately the Government did-'Costigan might answer the crucial questions whether explicitly asked to do so or not'. In other words it was thumbs down for Costigan. Then some excuse had to be found for not allowing Mr Costigan to proceed with the inquiry. Apart from the toing and froing and evasiveness-and in the most recent case the clear error-I suspect that there is information on the record on this matter which the Government has refused to disclose.

The critical questions that should be asked in this inquiry are, firstly, whether, as a result of the transactions between Mr Horgan, Mr Maher and his friends, tax which would have been paid was not paid and, secondly, whether, under the provisions of the tax recoupment legislation originally introduced on 23 September, Mr Horgan would have been a vendor shareholder liable to repay money. They are the critical questions. I suggest that they have deliberately not been asked in the terms of reference finally given to Mr Von Doussa. I make no reflection at all upon Mr Von Doussa in making these comments. Indeed, in a previous inquiry, Mr Von Doussa showed that he is a man of some determination. He, of course, was not nominated explicitly by the Government but by the Law Council of Australia. The point I am making is that Mr Costigan was deliberately excluded from this inquiry by the Government because the Government was afraid that Mr Costigan would flush out the truth and reveal it. When speaking about the potential liability of Mr Horgan to pay recoupment tax, I referred to the legislation which was introduced in the House of Representatives on 23 September . That is a very different Bill from the one that replaced it on 21 October. The principal difference is that there is a sub-clause (12) of clause 3 in the latter Bill which exempts the whole class of vendor-shareholders. That is the Horgan amendment. It is there to ensure that Mr Horgan does not have to pay back any of the money that he has stolen, to use the Prime Minister's description. That will be the subject of debate either tomorrow or next week.

I want to raise one other matter. I might add that I do not expect to get a substantial response from the Minister for Finance to any of the questions I have raised. I refer to the matter the matter touched upon by Senator McLaren concerning travelling allowances paid, in particular, to Messrs Sinclair and Anthony and the following reply given by Senator Guilfoyle on 16 November:

Ministers and Opposition officeholders have nominated their home bases in writing. The Department of Administrative Services finds no substance in the allegation that Ministers nominated one home base for periods when Parliament was sitting and another for the rest of the year.

I draw attention to the fact that that is not a categorical denial that some Minister or Ministers changed their home bases during a year. The operative part of the reply states that no Minister nominated one home base for periods when Parliament was sitting and another for the rest of the year. It does not say that no Minister had more than one home base during a year. I believe those words were very carefully chosen because, in making that statement, the Minister probably has not told the Senate anything which is not correct but nor has the Minister told the whole truth. The whole truth is that home bases were changed during the financial year. The only way in which the Government can clear up this matter is to table the files of those two Ministers on this matter-the two Ministers, of course, being Mr Anthony and Mr Sinclair. Again, I do not expect that that will be done voluntarily.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This third reading debate gives me an opportunity to summarise some of the aspects of the Budget legislation which we have been considering for some time. I want to make a few general comments about it. The first point I make is that we are now in the month of November and it is some two and a half months since the Budget was brought down. It is clearly apparent that there are a number of tremendous defects in the Budget strategy. They become more and more apparent every day. It now appears that the Government is looking at a blow-out in the Budget deficit of some one and a half billion dollars. That is due to a number of factors, some of which may have been foreseen and others of which may not have been foreseen. It is important to consider the implications of the Budget in the light of the Government's latest strategy announcement in respect of a wages pause as a method dealing with unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me look at some of the factors which have contributed to the increase in the Budget deficit. The first, of course, is the increase in the estimate for drought relief. The second is the Budget forecast in relation to unemployment. I will deal with the Budget forecast in relation to unemployment first. The Budget forecast was for a marked increase in unemployment in Australia. The estimates of the amount of unemployment benefits which would have to be paid in the year 1982-83 were based on an average figure which was only 4,000 above the figure for June 1982 and in fact some 10,000 below the unemployment figure of July 1982 . When the Budget was brought down in August the estimates for unemployment benefit recipients for the year 1982-83 were way out of kilter. I want to make the point again that unemployment has been increasing in this country at the rate of 1,000 people a day in more recent weeks. The estimates of unemployment benefits which will have to be paid increase every day. I do not think we should underestimate the importance of that, because one extra percentage increase in unemployed members of the work force costs this country an enormous sum of money . The current estimate of the cost of unemployment is $8 billion and it is increasing, of course, as unemployment increases every day. That is the first rubbery, strange figure in the Budget which needs some comment at this point.

The second point I make relates to the amount for pay-as-you-earn income tax receipts in the Budget. That is calculated on the assumption of no change in the level of employment of wage and salary earners. That assumption just does not square with the estimate of negative economic growth in the Budget, nor does it square with the now acknowledged large rise in the level of unemployment. So, as unemployment increases every day, the receipts side of the Budget will be affected in terms of PAYE income earners.

The third matter I raise concerns the Government's estimate in the Budget that there will be no loss of revenue through tax avoidance in the year 1982-83. I remind the Senate that last year the estimate for loss of receipts through tax avoidance was $300m. This year the Treasurer, Mr Howard, declared that tax avoidance schemes were no longer succeeding; that he had effectively abolished them by fiat. He declared that they did not exist any more. The self-delusion which is apparent in the Treasurer's statement appears to be transparent if we examine the Budget estimates. In August of this year the Opposition did not accept that there would be no loss of revenue from tax avoidance. That view, of course, is borne out by the Commissioner of Taxation. The Treasurer ought to have a look at the sixty-first annual report of the Commissioner of Taxation for the year 1981-82, which was brought down in the Senate in September of this year . At page 21 of that report the Commissioner had this to say:

It is noteworthy that, in revenue terms, overall results for the year were marginally ahead of the 1980-81 year despite a significant drop in the numbers of cases completed by all programs brought about largely by the decrease in staff ceiling in 1981 and the need to devote additional resources to tax avoidance activities. That greater revenue was obtained from fewer completed cases tends to confirm the view expressed last year that tax evasion appears to be increasing. This is, of course-
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report: 'An Aircraft Carrier for the Australian Defence Force'

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 October, on motion by Senator Sibraa:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence entitled 'An Aircraft Carrier for the Australian Defence Force' is particularly pertinent because the Government said that it would make the decision on the aircraft carrier before the end of this month. I want to deal with particular aspects of this proposal that there be an aircraft carrier for the Australian Defence Force. I commend the Committee's report to the Senate. I believe it is a very thoughtful and important addition to the discussion of our defence needs. Unfortunately the Government's record in this area is far different from the style of this report. Of course, the Government let the United Kingdom keep the aircraft carrier HMS Invincible in a pre- election Budget proposal because of the need for it to slash defence expenditure to give it more money for electioneering purposes when the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) anticipated an election this year.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee needs to be commended for the way in which it indicated that it felt that the cost of a carrier was far too high because of the other options that its purchase would close off. I agree with the Committee in that decision. The Committee recognised the need for a maritime command structure. It pointed out that the Tracker and Orion aircraft of the Fleet Air Arm should be relocated . In my view, the Nowra air base in the electorate of Macarthur would be an ideal place. Under this Government aided by the honourable member for Macarthur, Mr Baume, we have seen the Nowra air base wither on the vine. Indeed, figures from the Department of Defence show that the Navy's approved manpower terminal strength and needs have been reduced as a result of the decommissioning of HMAS Melbourne by 300 and that there has been a reduction of flying hours for Skyhawk , Macchi and Tracker aircraft of 180. That is the serious situation facing the Nowra base at present. The Government's inaction has led to a great deal of uncertainty for the servicemen in that area. Unfortunately that has been made more difficult by the convulsions and acrobatics of the honourable member for Macarthur, Mr Baume, who has said different things each week as the Government's role has changed and, of course, as it has played politics with our defence needs.

The Government's role in coastal surveillance is a matter of particular concern . The Government has encouraged private surveillance for the security of this nation. In other words, Ansett planes and even foreign planes are surveying our shoreline. This is one area where Fraserism has gone mad. The private sector is handling legitimate defence needs. I suggest that Australian servicemen could be most effectively employed in revamping the Nowra base to allow our surveillance activity to be based there. Mr Baume has focused on headline making by promising a carrier to the people in the Macarthur electorate. The people at HMAS Albatross believe the Fleet Air Arm has been left with no role because 13 Tracker aircraft are in mothballs. The Fraser Government and the honourable member for Macarthur have undeniably placed us in the position of having servicemen unable to fly the hours they need effectively to gain the experience needed for their service. The aircraft should be used. As colleagues of mine in another place have pointed out, trained pilots, instead of sitting on their hands at the Nowra base as they are at present, should be used in coastal surveillance. Ansett planes are going around Australia doing the work of guarding our coastline from the types of problems that the report referred to.

I believe HMAS Albatross has a changing role but it must have a continuing role . Its personnel need to be reassured, just as the people of Nowra itself need to be certain of the economic stability that the base supplies to the area. We cannot afford to allow this Government to gamble with our defence needs. We cannot allow the honourable member for Macarthur to continue to distort the situation or to mislead the people in the Macarthur electorate about the defence needs of Australia. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that this report from the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence puts to rest all further discussion on the need for a carrier for the Royal Australian Navy. I am in broad agreement with its recommendations; they are well researched. It is a well-reasoned document. When one considers the restraints that were imposed on the Committee with respect to both time and resources it is a most commendable result. Had the Committee had even more time and resources, it would have come up with the same answer. The report confirms the naval tactical air power study of nearly 10 years ago which looked in great detail at 14 different scenarios in the use of naval tactical air power and came up with the solution that in every case land- based air was a more appropriate, more cost effective and more functionally effective way to go.

SPEECH.PARA: Very briefly, Australia has no place for the mini-carriers that are examined in this report, be they the Invincible, the Iwo Jima landing platform helicopter class, the Italian Garibaldi class or the Spanish sea control-type. All those ships are designed to be defended by air from sources other than that of their own origin. In the United States Navy these carriers operate as part of a major fleet which will provide the heavy fleet aircraft, such as the F4s, the F14s or the F18s, for air superiority and the airborne early warning radar capability. The Invincible was designed for use by the Royal Navy in the North Sea with land -based air for both air superiority and AEW. It is the lack of this AEW capacity which is the Achilles heel of this type of ship. Without an airborne early warning capability there is no beyond-the-horizon radar possibility and those ships are vulnerable to low flying strike aircraft. It has been proposed by Senator Hamer in speaking to this report that the helicopter-borne AEW radar would provide this capability. That is not true. The sophistication of the equipment that can be put in a helicopter is limited. The altitude, of course, is very restricted-probably below 10,000 feet-and range is a function of height as well as signal strength with radar for target acquisition. One would want to operate at heights probably twice those attainable with helicopters to get an adequate warning time. Time on station and range is also very critical with a helicopter. Of course, there are always major serviceability problems with helicopters. I guess it is better than nothing. But it is nowhere near adequate for what we need. If we do need a carrier we need a conventional type carrier of at least 40,000 tonnes. We are looking at an investment beyond that which Australia can afford. As the report says, we probably need three of them because we are at least a two ocean navy and we need one in reserve.

The most important thing in relation to this document is the matter of timing. Cabinet will receive a report from the Department of Defence by 30 November, I understand. The Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair) has made a statement that by the end of December a decision will be made on whether Australia will get a carrier. Whatever that decision might be it is quite wrong for the decision to be taken this year because the Government has called for a new strategic assessment which will be provided in the early part of the new year. The strategic assessment is a confidential document which looks at all the threats to Australia, at needs, the Defence Force structure, manpower and equipment. It is the definitive document against which all equipment and all Force structure is based. If we are having a new assessment done then it is the height of folly to be deciding on a major piece of equipment-whether or not we are going to get it-in advance of the new strategic assessment coming in. This assessment, of course, is always a confidential document, but it is crucial to a decision on a piece of major equipment like that.

Recommendation 9 of the report deals with the assigning of maritime surveillance aircraft-namely, the P3Cs-to the Navy. The report goes on to comment on the retention of the Fleet Air Arm and what to do with it. If we do not have a carrier then the place of the Fleet Air Arm has to be reviewed. We live in a world of changing technology. Because we have some skills-it does not matter how highly developed those skills are-it does not mean that they have to be retained. Of course, in the Navy stokers gave way to ERAs when coal firing went out of stokeholds of coal fired ships. Of course those stokers in turn replaced sailmakers. There is nothing inviolate about any occupation. Of course, there are many parellels in private industry.

I think the solution to the position of the Fleet Air Arm would be to second flying officers and ground staff to the Royal Australian Air Force and have them serve in maritime reconnaissance squadrons. I think that a valid liaison role can be developed for those airmen in the organisation between the Navy and the Air Force. They would be quite valuable in that role. Of course, if at a future date we did want to go to a carrier then we would have those skills retained in the Navy. As for carrier work, the officers could do exchange postings with the United States Navy. So, I do not attach much importance to the argument that we need a carrier to retain those skills in the Fleet Air Arm.
I turn to the comments on page 25 of the report in relation to the Harrier. Most of the people who have spoken to this report have commented on this. Page 25 states:

. . . the Harrier is a sub-sonic aircraft, with a relatively short range . . . radius of action, a poor radar, capable only of daytime or clear weather operations, poor 'look-down' capability . . . imcompatible with modern weapon systems . . .

That is a factual account of the capabilities of the Harrier. I saw the first of these aircraft fly in 1959 or 1960 at Farnborough in England. What one has to remember about the Harrier is that it was a proof of concept aircraft-it set out to prove that one could build an aeroplane that could take off and land vertically. It was never designed as a fighter; it was never designed as a strike aircraft. Having invested hundreds of millions of dollars in research and development into it the company had to make it work in some way. It had no application in private industry so it went into Service life. It uses basically Korean War technology. It is a very slow aeroplane-mach .9 at best; when weapons and stores are hung on it it gets considerably slower. Aircraft simply have to be supersonic-at least to a level of about mach 1.4-these days to stay alive in the air. Aircraft have to be able to accelerate rapidly through the trans-sonic regime. This aeroplane simply will not do any of these things.

The Harrier is a very short range aircraft. Despite what Senator Collard said, range is crucial. It is a matter of its pay load, whether it is taken out as ordnance or fuel, and the fact remains that there is very little capability with this aircraft. The fact that it was ferried an enormously long distance to the Falkland Islands is quite irrelevant from a fighting point of view because it was done with a ferry probe on it. This is always detached in the operational field because there is such an enormous amount of drag from it.

It is a very unmanoeuvrable aeroplane. Proof of that is in the great plans that the Royal Air Force had to develop a big wing Harrier to gain more manoeuvrability. The Blue Fox radar, of Ferranti, has proved to be a failure. If one were the designer of it one would say that it was a success because it met the design parameters. But it is short range radar with no look-down capability, no all weather capability. The proof of its shortcomings can be found in the fact that the C130P, which is a slow transport aircraft, could operate into Port Stanley every night throughout the conflict up until the last night before Port Stanley airfield fell.

The success of the Harrier came exclusively from its 9L Sidewinder missile. It gave an advantage to the British that the Argentinians did not have. The fact that the Argentinian aircraft were operating below 5,000 feet at low air speeds meant that firing was rather like shooting fish in a barrel. There were 19 Mirages shot down by the Harriers of a total of 24 aircraft destroyed by 9Ls; ground fire accounted for 47. So, there were considerably more Argentinian aircraft lost though ground fire. Of course, the British lost nine Harriers out of 42. This is between a fifth and a quarter of its number. This is a not inconsequential loss rate.

In the strike role the aircraft were similarly ineffective. They flew more than 40 sorties against Port Stanley airfield at very short range. They had three, 1, 000 lb bombs each. I do not believe that they put one crater in the runway. They proved themselves incapable of penetrating the defences of Port Stanely-which were quite minimal-because they lacked speed, manoeuvreability and and ECM capability. Furthermore, the aeroplane has some major handling defects. In 1971 the United States Marine Corps acquired 110 of these aircraft; by March 1982 it had only 68 left. These aircraft have had the highest accident rate of any aircraft in US Air Force history and a higher loss rate after 11 years in service than in the first year of service. This is in contradiction to every other aircraft ever introduced. It is dissembling for pilots to say-as I heard pilots on behalf of British Aerospace Australia Ltd say-that the US Marine Corps put in helicopter pilots who had no fixed wing experience in this role. That is not true at all. Those pilots went through an adequate training program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wish to say a few words on the report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence entitled 'An Aircraft Carrier for the Australian Defence Force'. As I was one of the people who made up the Committee that handed in this report I feel duty bound to speak. I agree with the different comments by Senator Childs and Senator MacGibbon. But I wish to say a few other words in the few minutes that are available to me. I believe that Australia has to look very carefully at our defence effort. Australia is, after all, only a small nation. We are limited as to the amount of money that we can spend on defence. I believe that money has to be spent very wisely. The Committee did not, in the true sense, take a political view. The Australian Labor Party members on that Committee, as it happened, were in the majority simply because the Liberal Party Committee members, through unforeseen circumstances, could not always attend that Committee's meetings. It happened that the Labor Party people were in the majority. Right from the outset all the members of that Committee did not look at this reference as a political stunt. I believe that every member of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, irrespective of his politics, is looking at his responsibility in relation to Australia and what is good for Australia. I am very happy that that is so.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the financial aspect. Australia has spent not quite 3 per cent of its gross domestic product on defence. I do not believe that any political party can lift this in the foreseeable future to any great amount, so we are restricted in terms of finance. I agree with Senator MacGibbon that it would be far too costly to buy an aircraft carrier. The Midway class aircraft carrier would be ideal if we could afford it, but I believe that the cost would be astronomical. Even if the United States of America had several of the Midway class carriers in mothballs and even if we could buy one on cheap terms I believe the running costs of it would be out of Australia's reach. To man that aircraft carrier we would need in the vicinity of 4,500 men; it would carry 75 aircraft of various sorts. Had Australia gone ahead and bought HMS Invincible it would have been a bargain. There is no doubt about that. To have a cheap alternative in the true sense would not really be an aircraft carrier. We would have a ship capable of carrying hover aircraft whether they be short take off and vertical landing or helicopters. I agree with Senators MacGibbon and Childs that a ship which is not capable of carrying early warning aircraft is highly vulnerable. It cannot survive in modern warfare; that is our experience.

I think one of the lessons that we can learn from the Falklands war is that although the British forces equipment was not all that much more superior to that of the armed forces of Argentina, the British forces were superior in that they were very highly trained. My fear is that if Australia went ahead and bought an aircraft carrier, even a cheap aircraft carrier, we would be spending in the vicinity of $2,000m. I do not believe it is possible to do that. If we did that we would have to restrict the training of our Air Force, Army and Navy, which would be to their detriment. That would not be good enough. I believe that if trouble ever arose it would be more important to have highly trained troops than to have an aircraft carrier, as was seen in the Falkland Islands dispute.

I believe that Australia is the best aircraft carrier. We should be placing more airfields around this nation. We have islands that are quite capable of taking our aircraft. The Committee has recommended that we have in-fuelling services so that our aircraft can reach out to greater mileages and defend this nation. I think six early warning aircraft should be purchased. The Government, instead of looking at another aircraft carrier, should look at buying in the vicinity of 10 refuelling aircraft and six early warning aircraft. In that way Australia's defences would be far better than having one aircraft carrier. One aircraft carrier cannot supply the defences that are needed. If Australia really wanted to go into aircraft carriers it would be necessary, as Senator MacGibbon said, to have three. Two would be needed to patrol the Pacific Ocean and the Indian Ocean while a third was being repaired or under maintenance. The cost of that would be so astronomical that all our defences would be stripped to almost nothing. Our defences would be capable only of maintaining a reasonable defence structure. As I said, the Committee looked at that in the reality of the situation.

It is a very honest report although there has been some criticism that we made some wrong assessments on the Harrier aircraft. That, to a small extent, is correct, but I do not believe that the Harrier aircraft is the type that Australia needs to defend itself. I honestly believe that the F18 aircraft-some criticism has been made about them-will be of major benefit to the defence of this nation and I hope that nothing goes wrong to stop that purchase.

Unlike Senator MacGibbon I would like to see the Fleet Air Arm maintained. I think that naval pilots work better with naval personnel. There is a need to maintain the Fleet Air Arm. The Committee recommended that all or some of the P3C Orions should be transferred. The aircraft that are presently available, particularly the Trackers, should be used for the protection of this nation. I do not believe privately owned planes should be keeping surveillance around this nation. I am far happier to see armed and trained personnel doing so. They are professionals, and I want professionals to look after my security. I hope that all Australians want that. It is no use having untrained people doing this job and having trained personnel and their aircraft sitting on the ground doing nothing. We have also made a recommendation that the Fleet Air Arm should be trained in the other modern aircraft that Australia will purchase. We should at least always keep our options open. We did that for a reason. I would like to see the Nowra base kept operational. After talking with the Navy I am of the opinion that naval personnel work better together.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Retail Trading Hours in the Australian Capital Territory

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 November, on motion by Senator Reid:
That the Senate take note of the report.
upon which Senator Colston had moved by way of an amendment:

At end of motion, add: ', but the Senate agrees with the views and the conclusions expressed in the Dissenting Report by Mrs R. J. Kelly, M.P., Mr K. L . Fry, M.P., and Senator Colston, and that the President forward a copy of this Resolution to the Speaker of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly'
and upon which Senator Reid had moved by way of an amendment to the amendment:

Leave out all words after 'Senate', insert 'is of the opinion that it would be premature for the Senate to determine an attitude to the Report of the Committee before the Canberra community has had the opportunity to consider the Report in detail and before the Government has had an opportunity to respond to the Report '

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was speaking against Senator Colston's amendment last week when the debate on this report was adjourned. I said that I supported the general drift of the report with much pleasure. It makes only modest recommendations. I am sorry that it does not recommend completely unrestricted trading hours because ultimately that is the way trade will be carried on in this country. The sooner we get there the better. Quite simply there is no place for government legislation at all in respect of trading hours in the market place. It is a big adult world and the market is well able to set its own standards as to whether it needs to trade 24 hours a day, seven days a week or three hours, three days a week. It is something that the Government has no place in now, never had a place in in the past, and should never have a place in the future. It has nothing to do with a bunch of bureaucrats or a bunch of legislators.

SPEECH.PARA: No company can exist like an 18th century capitalist in today's society. It has to be conscious of its social obligations. A company has three principal obligations. The first is to the shareholders of the company. Whether it is a sole proprietor or a proprietor does not matter; it is the same thing. The second is to its employees. The third responsibility is to look after its customers. The responsibilities are inviolate. It cannot look after two of those three or one of those three to the exclusion of the others and stay in business in the long term.

Trading hours are particularly important to customers. We have heard a lot in recent times about women in the work force, single parent mothers, the women's movement and so on. The restriction of trading hours really penalises women who have to work. Not only women but also the whole of society have moved towards a 38-hour week. If there is only a 38-hour trading week, people do not have time to go out to buy groceries, clothes and all the other requirements which keep the business world alive.

I mention also the tourist trade. We are trying to develop a tourist trade in this country in the face of implacable union and Australian Labor Party opposition. If we are to get anywhere with the tourist trade, we have to operate around the clock-24 hours a day, seven days a week. As I said earlier, it is inevitable that, in the longer term, there will be an extension of trading hours in the Australian community. It is just a matter of being bright enough at present to see the need.

The arguments against an extension of trading hours which have come from the other side of the chamber are the old socialist dogma, rehashed eternally, the closed shop philosophy and the whole authoritarian control approach of 'do what I tell you; just do not use your own judgment'. There has been a total domination of shop traders and employees who have been told what they should do with their lives and, through those people, the community is told also. We cannot live by carving up the commercial world into cosy little niches. We live and prosper through competition. Provided that competition is open and everyone can join in it, it is fair and honest. That is the way it must be because that is the only way Australia will survive. If we are to be alive commercially in the 1990s in the Asian Pacific region, with the dynamic commercial world of which we are inevitably apart, which extends from Japan down to Singapore and through Indonesia, Australia's commercial performance has to be lifted several magnitudes on what it is at present. We will not achieve that by following the Labor Party line of penalty rates and all those union domineering restrictive practices.

I am sorry that Senator Chipp is not here. If Senator Chipp went out into the real world and mixed with successful traders-I do not know with whom he mixes- the way I do, whether those traders are involved in a small business, or are owner entrepreneurs or are involved in the large corporations in the country, he will find a universal expression that we have extended trading hours for shop keeping because these people who are successful do not shrink from competition in any way at all.

It is interesting to talk to those people. I have had estimates that trade could be lifted by between 3 per cent and 5 per cent by a simple extension of trading hours. At a time of depressed economic activity in this country, an elevation of between 3 per cent and 5 per cent in the volume of trade being done in the retail world would be very significant. It would mean that factories could produce more. It would mean that more people could be employed. It would mean more money being circulated through the community. It would help us to work ourselves out of the mess which we are in.

Therefore, I have much pleasure in supporting Senator Reid and the report of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory. I condemn the restrictive practices that are proposed by Senator Colston in his amendment. We have to remember that water sets its own level in the market place. Traders will not trade if it is uneconomical for them to do so. People will not work for shopkeepers or employers if they are not paid a fair return for their effort. If the hours are inconvenient for customers, customers will not go. There is no place at all for the Government to be poking its nose into what is a simple, straightforward commercial matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move an amendment to Senator Reid's amendment to Senator Colston's amendment to the orignal motion on the report of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory into retail trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after 'that', insert:

the unanimous view of the Committee that retail trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory should not be deregulated but considers that the recommendation of the majority of the Committee is inconsistent with the Government's stated objectives of preserving jobs and small businesses and, further, is contrary to the views of the community in the A.C.T. as expressed by the House of Assembly Committee report on trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory, and that Mr President forward a copy of this resolution to the Speaker of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly.

I take this opportunity of congratulating Senator Reid on her election as Deputy Government Whip. Having said that, I beg to differ with her in respect of her majority report. I refer very briefly to the tabling statement in which Senator Reid said:

The Committee considers that deregulation would most probably accelerate or at least continue the trend towards the structural readjustment of employment in the industry-away from full time to part time and casual employment.
The statement went on:
However, it is considered that this is an inevitable trend and major retailers have stated in evidence that only voluntary staff would be used on weekends.

I think that we should analyse that for a moment in view of the concern that is being expressed in the community about the loss of jobs and in particular the loss of full time jobs. We ought to consider whether this is an inevitable trend as was suggested by the Chairman of the Committee in her tabling speech. I turn to page 30 of the report which states:
Casual positions are mainly filled by married women and students who do not wish to work full-time. This employment provides an important second source of income to the family.

A committee of this Parliament recommended to the Parliament a change in working hours which, according to the Committee, will have the effect of reducing full time jobs as stated by the Chairman's tabling speech and at page 32 of the report under the heading 'Conclusion'. The recommendation suggests that those full time jobs be made casual and part time jobs. We have also an indication from the Committee as to who will take up those part time and casual jobs. Those people will include students so they will include school students.

I refer honourable senators to my address to the Senate at the time the Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Act was before the Senate, section 90 of which relates to this matter. At that stage I indicated how many casual jobs were taken by school kids. Are we in the Senate now being asked by one of our committees to destroy full time jobs which are desperately required by those persons who now have them, and pass them over to school students? That is precisely what the Committee is doing. Indeed, the Committee admitted that in its report.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can a school child work from nine to five on a school day ?

—We are talking about extending trading hours to Saturday afternoons in the major stores. That is what we are suggesting. This will do away with the permanent jobs and cause a casualisation of the industry.
—Who does the permanent nine to five jobs?

—Nobody will because the change in the structure of the retail trading pattern will mean that fewer people will be employed during the week and more people will be employed during the weekend. The people who are employed during the weekend are the school kids. In fact, there are two things to be said about that. Firstly, those school kids are not paying taxes. Secondly, they are taking the jobs of persons who are already in jobs. I submit that it is not inevitable that we will see a shift away from full time to part time and casual employment in the retail trade. If we say that it is inevitable we, as members of the Federal Parliament-particularly in relation to Canberra-will be giving away our responsibility to preserve the jobs of people who are already in work. The Committee has said:

SPEECH.PARA: This employment provides an important second source of income to the family.

What about a first income for large numbers of unemployed people? Let us not beat around the bush. This Committee is saying-what is worse, it understands it- that this move certainly will lead to a drift from full time employment to part time and casual work and that these jobs will be taken by school kids or by people who will bring a second income into the family. Let us get rid of the hypocrisy of the Government in suggesting certain ways of maintaining employment . I am saying that this recommendation from the majority of members on the Committee will destroy employment and that is a tragedy. Why is the Committee doing this? The Committee says why it is doing this on page 18 of the report. It states:

The question of trading hours has therefore been the subject of considerable scrutiny and investigation in recent years. It reflects the great amount of pressure that has been and is continuing to be exerted on Governments by the various interest groups to effect changes to the legislative regulation of trading hours.

Only one group is trying to change the trading hours and that is the major retailers. That matter should be of concern to all honourable senators present. The other aspect of this report is that the definition of major retailers is not consistent with anything contained in the rest of the report but is consistent wih a politically motivated decision taken in Tasmania last year to get some retailer off the hook. If that is the sort of thing we in the Senate can expect from our committee system we ought to have a second look at it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that a couple of amendments have been moved, which people have seen, and an amendment has been moved by Senator Harradine, which no one has seen in written form. Therefore, so that people can consider the amendments, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the debate be now adjourned.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND THE ARTS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 November, on motion by Senator Teague:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was a little doubtful when this reference went to the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts. Usually when a fairly polarised debate took place in the chamber and the contentious matter was then flipped to a committee one would say that the objectivity of that committee was in doubt. But I have to say that the findings of the Education and Arts Committee on this matter were based only on the evidence. Some of the evidence was favourable to the Government scheme and some of it was not. We heard unfavourable evidence from the Department of Education that the scheme was rushed and implemented in a hurried manner. We also heard from the bankers that it was apparently the normal practice of this Government to devise legislation, pass it and work out the problems afterwards. I would have thought that the reverse would have been the case-that any government would work out what the problems were in the scheme, and overcome them in the legislation. But we had evidence from those two groups that this was not the case.

SPEECH.PARA: The other major concern I have with the legislation-the Committee has noted this-is that it has preceded three major reports which would directly affect the legislation. Firstly, there was the Beswick inquiry into the state of student finances which was a comprehensive review of what student finances were. The Government has just received this report in the last four or five weeks and it is considering its response to the report. But it did not, at any stage, look at that report and base its student loans views on it. The Australian Vice- Chancellors' Committee has been looking at student finances as well. That Committee's report is due very soon. Finally, the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission has been looking at and doing a major report on participation rates. Within the space of two months this Government will receive three very comprehensive reports on which it could base its future strategy in terms of student finances. Yet the Government has opted for the loans scheme before considering any of these reports.
Committee on Education and the Arts
Committee on Education and the Arts

I detected some other problems in the inquiry which also gave me some concern over the legislation. The first relates to the sum of $50m which has been allocated. It is quite clear that that sum was arrived at by a decision which was not based on what the Government perceived to be the needs for student finances. That was the amount of money the banks would make available. It is true that the Government put extra pressure on the banks to increase the allocation from $30m to $50m. One of the questions I asked-I have yet to receive a satisfactory answer-was why the Government has opted to operate the scheme through the banks and not through one of its agencies. I asked why the Government was not in a position to lend the money through its own financial resources. There may be a good reason but, of course, each of the public servants who were asked this question had to state that this matter was government policy. As I understand it, that is a correct response from a public servant. I hope that when the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill comes before the Senate next week we will get some explanation of why the scheme is to operate through the banks.

The main opposition to the scheme really came from the Australian Union of Students and a few other bodies. The opposition focussed on several areas. I think this Committee has cleared up some of the doubts. The examination by the Committee has meant that some of the doubts about the scheme have been resolved. I do not know whether the Government always intended the current interpretation to apply, but certainly the investigation by the Committee has wrung out certain assurances that make me a lot happier about the scheme. The first of those major points is that the scheme is only supplementary to the grants scheme and is not intended at any stage to replace it.

TALK.START.PARA: —What guarantee have you for that?

—On our side of the chamber we had doubts that in fact this was not the future intention. In my view, if we look back at the Review of Commonwealth Functions we see quite clearly that the Government's initial intention was to bring in a students loans scheme to replace the grants scheme. I was asked a moment ago what guarantee we have. My answer would be, the credibility of the current government. When does it renege on promises? Not very often-not more than about once a day or once a week. But I think that Senator Chipp, being an idealist, would agree that there must be some trust in the world . What we are saying is that we will give the Government a year or more to put this scheme into operation and then will judge whether it is working as the Department of Education and the Minister for Education say or whether in fact it is the thin end of a wedge, whether it is intended to replace the grants scheme. There are no guarantees, but we are saying that we will see what happens with it .

SPEECH.PARA: The second major objection to the scheme was as to the criteria on which loans would be granted. When I first heard of it I thought, knowing what banks were like, that all sorts of criteria would be imposed. A person who was going to be a doctor or a lawyer would no doubt get credit. However, a person who was going on to become a politician would no doubt get none. I felt there would be discrimination against country areas, women, migrants and Aborignals-that all the groups against which banks currently tend to discriminate would be discriminated against under the scheme. However, we have had an unequivocal assurance from both the Department of Education and from the banks concerned that the only criterion used will be whether a person has had a previous bad credit dealing with a particular institution. That is a very important point to make and we will make sure that the Government and the banks stick to that assurance because if they do not in my view the whole scheme will collapse.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you reckon the banks will be fair to a single mother, for example?
—Well, that is mandatory under the Act. I dare say steps could be taken if they were not fair.

SPEECH.PARA: The third point we make is that there should be review procedures, which would take two forms. At the end of the first year's operation there should be a review to see just how the scheme is working. There are still many things that we do not know. We do not know exactly how the money is to be allocated between States or between banks. That aspect must be reviewed in the first year of operation. Also, we have asked that the Education and Arts Committee review the scheme in March 1984. Thus, some of the problems that may arise from this legislation would be reviewed by the Committee which would, I believe, examine them critically.

A few other points can be made about the scheme. The Committee has recommended that more emphasis be given to counselling, that people getting loans should have it available at the university level. We found it unlikely that the banks would have sufficient expertise to deal with this aspect; that it would be best done through the current financial counselling services at universities. Also, I believe that the scheme is not particularly suitable for post-graduate students. Usually a post-graduate student has undertaken an honours degree involving four years study and faces a minimum of another four to five years post-graduate study. As a result that student would spend nine years at a tertiary or higher education institution. By making loans available to such a person we could be increasing his indebtedness to a stage where he may never be able to repay his debts. The opportunity cost involved in completing a higher degree represents at least $60,000 to $70,000 in income forgone. It is too much to say to them at 28, 30 or 32 years of age, when probably they have established a family and bought a house: 'You must now begin to repay a debt.'

Another related anomaly is that if one happens to be a recipient of the post- graduate award at the moment and is not married one would not be eligible to borrow any money. So what, in effect, we are doing is saying that the person who is married and has greater responsibilities is to be encouraged to get into further debt. I would forewarn post-graduates that I do not think this scheme is particularly suitable for them.

The business colleges have strongly represented to every member of the Senate that a loan of $2,500 should be made available. That presents difficulties. I urge people to look at the report and examine why at this stage we cannot recommend that. Only a certain amount of money is available and we do not know what the demand for it will be. Our decision also relates to the very type of people who are attending commercial colleges.

My final point relates to appeals. If indeed someone is rejected for a loan we believe there should be some appeals mechanism by which they can take the matter further. I believe this is the only way of ensuring that the banks will apply only the criterion that I have mentioned. In summary, I am not sure that the Labor Party, if it comes to office, will want to continue this scheme, but I stress that I do not think sufficient evidence for stopping the scheme was put before the Committee. We will have a year to see how it operates. If it operated successfully, no doubt the Labor Party would continue it. If it did not, no doubt it would be discontinued. If the Education and Arts Committee re-examines the scheme in 1984 it will need only a month of hearings to ascertain exactly how it has been working.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The report by the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts was made in a fair amount of haste because of the requirement of the Senate that it report back by 16 November, which it did. Another term of reference was as to the effect of the scheme on the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme and other grants. I disagree with Senator Robert Ray 's comment that the debate on this matter in the Committee was polarised. As I recall it there was very little polarisation because Senator Button, speaking for the Australian Labor Party, said that the Opposition would in fact support the Bill. He said also that when Labor came to office it would remove the legislation. That seems to be a slightly different proposition from the one put by Senator Robert Ray.
—We have had an inquiry since then.

—Senator, you have spoken. Senator Robert Ray also said that the report was based on the evidence submitted. The Committee came to the conclusion that the students loans scheme provided for by the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill 1982 would not replace or diminish the grants scheme for student assistance. But when one seeks the evidence in the report upon which that conclusion is based one is referred to paragraphs 3.1 and 3.2. Paragraph 3. 2 states:

SPEECH.PARA: the Department of Education in its submission and through its representatives at the public hearings, was emphatic that the loans scheme would be suplementary to the existing grants scheme and would not undermine nor replace them.

I am not quite sure what the Committee expected the Department of Education to say. Presumably it would say what it had been directed to say by the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume). The level of TEAS and other grants is a political decision. Political decisions are not decisions for the Department of Education. One would want to ask, if everybody from the Minister down is so emphatic that TEAS is not about to be eroded or replaced, why the Government is so reluctant to index these allowances so that students can be assured of the continuation of those grants at a particular level. No commitment has been made. In fact, there has been a denial by the Minister that that would be done. I think one must then look at the actions of the Government in a political way to see what type of substantiation one could possibly find for a conclusion by the Committee that the grants scheme or student assistance would not be replaced or diminished. I suggest that on any fair view of the evidence it must be taken as only having the weight placed on it by the Department, which is dependent upon the weight that is placed upon it by the Minister. Surely, as Senator Robert Ray has quite correctly pointed out, this Government would be one of the last in which one would want to put one's trust.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a matter of judgment.

—It certainly is a matter of judgment. That is precisely what I have been saying. I do not know how the Committee could possibly make such a recommendation. Its recommendations must be made purely on what has come from the political wing of the Department-that is, the Minister. I think the other items in the Committee report were very useful. Certainly, the final squeezing out of all and sundry what precisely would be the criteria upon which loans would be given must have satisfied many people that it will be done in a fair and equitable way.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 4.30 p.m., under sessional order consideration of Committee reports is concluded. Pursuant to sessional order I now call on General Business.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 November, on motion by Senator Gietzelt:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I suggest that this Bill be debated cognately with the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill (No. 3) and the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill ( No. 4).
—It is the wish of the Senate that the Bills be debated cognately? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first question we might ask in looking at these three Bills is: Why are they necessary and why was it necessary for Senator Siddons also to introduce Bills along similar lines? The answer is that Liberal governments for the last 17 years have not taken a proper revision of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. The only revision and the only amendments occurred in the period 1973-75 when numerous electoral Bills were passed in the House of Representatives but foundered in the Senate. Only one Bill relating to redistribution was passed and that was at a Joint Sitting. That Bill was passed and the redistribution occurred. In every case the redistribution was rejected by this House of Parliament. I cannot really understand why the redistributions were rejected. In terms of Victoria, the Liberal redistribution of 1977 was far more favourable to the Australian Labor Party than the 1974 proposal. Nevertheless, owing to obstinacy and all sorts of suspicion, that redistribution was knocked back in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, there have been virtually no changes to the Electoral Act in the last 17 years. The only recent one that I can recall was the elimination from the Act of any restriction on election expenditure. This was done not through any sense of reform but out of fear; fear by the Liberal Party that it would go into a Federal election and that the Australian Democrats would challenge the results because every candidate would spend more money. I cannot remember what the limit was. I think it was $500 or $1,000. These days a good colour leaflet costs $2,000. This limit was removed and the promise was made that we could have a committee of inquiry into the matter and new provisions would be brought in. I do not know whether the Democrats would have challenged the election if candidates had spent too much money under the existing Act. The Democrats usually comply with the Act. They comply for the most Marxist of reasons of economic determinism-they cannot afford to spend any more money. I have sympathy with them in that regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I moved an amendment to take the figure to a realistic level and it was rejected.

—Senator Mason said that he moved an amendment to take it up to a realistic figure and that it was rejected at the time. Senator Mason will be aware that the Harders inquiry report has been in the Government's hands for over a year and that still no action has been taken on it. At least two inquiries have been commissioned to look into the Commonwealth Electoral Act. The reports of both of them have been given to the Government. The first report recommended a whole series of changes which were in line to some extent with Labor and Democrats policy and was rejected by the Government. The Government then commissioned another inquiry. The report of that inquiry is now held by the Government. Again it did not come up with the required answers, so there is still no action. Over the last few years we have had absolutely no action on electoral reform. I congratulate Senator Gietzelt on taking the initiative in introducing this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The first Bill I wish to deal with relates to 6 o'clock closing. I think the voting hours, from 8 o'clock to 8 o'clock, were set 80 years ago. First of all, it was decided by the Conservatives to have the election on a Thursday but that rort was amended by a Labor Party government and elections were then held on Saturdays. Many changes have occurred in the last 80 years, at least in the community if not in the parties represented opposite. First of all there has been a change in work patterns. Eighty years ago people were working a 48-hour week. It was common for people to work for nearly all of Saturday and they therefore needed until 8 o'clock to vote. Secondly, we have an improved transport system now. It is much easier to get to the polling booths than it was 80 years ago. Finally, with refined techniques in terms of absentee and postal voting, anyone is able to vote on election day if he or she has difficulty in getting to the polling booth between the hours of 8 a.m. and 6 o'clock at night. Especially in a good Liberal electorate with a good rorted postal vote machine, everyone gets a vote whether they want one or not. Those conditions have changed , which I think justifies 6 o'clock closing.

Of course, there are reasons other than changed conditions for supporting 6 o' clock closing. Firstly, let us have a look at the costs. During the last election, 61,111 people were employed on election day. If we were to reduce the voting hours by two hours and if we assume that such people are paid a minimum of $5 to $6 an hour, that immediately brings about a saving of over $700,000 for the Government. The second factor to bring into account is the actual efficiency . If electoral officers have been working for 12 hours efficiency tends to lessen. Mistakes are made in counting. Mistakes are made in putting votes in one pile or another and they have to be rectified at another stage. My final point- we may not always be sympathetic to this-is that it would make it a lot easier for party workers on election day if they had to work for 10 rather than 12 hours. The day has long since passed in the Labor Party-and I hope it has in the Liberal Party-when one has to spend a 12-hour session at the polling booth unless one is a candidate in a marginal seat. Most of us get away with spending two to four hours at the booth these days. In by-elections in days gone by I have done the 12 o'clock to 12 o'clock stint. One really needed a week to recover, not from the actual work but from the boredom of having to stand there for 12 hours. It would be of benefit to party workers if we reduced the time by two hours.

My major interest in having 6 o'clock closing, however, comes from an ability to establish early election results on election night. Currently we have a problem in Australia that in a close election when it is very hard to establish who in fact will win, we may have to wait for the Western Australian result to determine the whole election. The problem there is that Western Australia is two hours behind the eastern States and it usually takes two hours to establish a pattern of results.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three hours.

—I am coming to that in a moment. Western Australia is two hours behind and it takes a couple of hours to establish the result. So in winter the earliest one could get the result would be midnight. But now we have daylight saving so that means effectively that if an election is held next December and if the Labor Party makes gains in the other States which are not quite large enough, we will have to wait until 1.30 in the morning for the election result. If it is a Labor victory I am quite willing to wait that long.
—You won't have to; there will be a big enough swing.

—As Senator McIntosh indicates, we will probably pick up enough seats in Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland to win an election easily, but nevertheless it is rather foolish. The public likes to know the election results. Every television channel covers them on the night of an election. To work until 1.30 or 2 o'clock in the morning trying to get a result is ridiculous. I refer to the 1982 Victorian State election results. Victoria crossed to 6 o'clock closing in 1979. In 1982, with 6 o'clock closing, the Labor Party was able to claim victory at 7.25 p.m. The Liberal Party conceded victory at 7.40 p.m. Anyone reading the tally room board could at least see the pattern by 8.30 p.m. and the Australian Broadcasting Commission's computer managed to pick up a slight trend to Labor by 10 o'clock at night. So in my view there is some advantage in early closing. It has worked well in other States. Queensland has had it since 1915. South Australia, New South Wales and Victoria have all switched to 6 o'clock closing. There have been no transitional problems. I do not think that the prospect of 6 o'clock closing would draw much opposition from the other side of the chamber. I hope that the relevant Bill is passed unanimously.

SPEECH.PARA: The second of Senator Gietzelt's Bills introduces a random draw for the position on the ballot paper. This is really in order to negate what is termed ' the donkey vote'. I believe the phrase 'donkey vote' is a good one. Malcolm Mackerras estimates that at the moment there are 11 coalition members who owe their place in the House of Representatives to the donkey vote, and that there are four Labor members who owe their position in the House of Representatives to the donkey vote. It is never easy to establish a percentage for the donkey vote. I have scrutineered at many elections and in my view it is certainly between 0.6 per cent and 2 per cent. It would have been noticed that where the communists happen to draw the first position on the ballot paper in Senate elections they poll 2 per cent and where they draw down the line they are lucky to get 0.4 per cent.

I will cite some examples from the last Victorian election. The Australian Labor Party picked up 17 seats in that State election. In those seats where we drew the number one position and got the donkey vote our average primary vote was 47.4 per cent. In the other seats where we did our vote was 46.2 per cent, indicating to me-there may be other factors involved but the general trend is there-that there was a 1.2 per cent donkey vote in those 17 critical seats. Looking at it another way, in the last Victorian election the Australian Democrats contested 62 of the 81 seats. On 17 occasions they drew the top position. On those occasions they averaged 8 per cent of the vote. In the other 45 seats where they did not draw the top position they averaged 5.6 per cent of the vote. It may be that all the Democrat candidates with ability were right at the top of the ballot paper, but I do not think anyone, especially Senator Mason , would agree with that. I could give many other examples of the existence of the donkey vote and its effect on politics.

Ninety-six of the 125 members of the House of Representatives have names starting with the letters A to M. If one goes through a telephone book or an electoral roll and works out the average, one will find that there are more people in the A to M group, but not to the extent of 76.8 per cent. The seat for the area in which I live has always been used as a haven for donkeys in terms of the Liberal Party. We held the seat in 1974. The Liberal Party then held a pre- selection and the one and only criterion for picking that dolt was that his name started with A. Local Liberals told me that that was what had influenced them. They had to get the donkey vote as it could have been a very critical seat at the election. So for five years my electorate was left virtually unrepresented.

The Liberal Party held another pre-selection about eight or 10 weeks ago for the electorate in which I live. Its candidate's name begins with B. He does not live anywhere in the electorate. He is unknown to most of the people in the electorate. Again, he was chosen on the basis that his name begins with B. I am sure he was not chosen because he is a lawyer who lives miles outside the electorate. This effectively means that people with names such as Walsh, Withers , Watson or Ray are deprived of having a reasonable chance of running for the House of Representatives. I must say that that has been of great benefit to the Senate. Nevertheless, it is unfair to those people to have to give that sort of head start.

I realise that drawing names out of the hat would not eliminate the donkey vote . All it would do is eliminate the manipulation of pre-selections and other things aimed at someone capturing the donkey vote. The donkey vote would still exist and it will always exist as long as there is one set order on the ballot paper. It would be inappropriate at this stage for me to discuss at any length Senator Siddons's suggestion about the rotation of names on ballot papers. I hope to have the opportunity to do that at a later stage. That system is used in Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with that?

—I believe it has certain difficulties in terms of increasing informality. However, if there was optional preferential voting, a point to which I will come in a moment, that particular problem of rotation on ballot papers would become far less. But I think that this is a more appropriate debate to have when Senator Siddons's Bill comes up, and I hope it will come up shortly .

SPEECH.PARA: I have heard quite a few Liberals call for names to be drawn out of a hat. They all have one thing in common. They are defeated Liberal candidates. After the last two State elections in Victoria several Liberals have said that candidates should draw for positions. Most of their names began with the initials S, T or W . They all suggested that there should be a draw for positions.

TALK.START.PARA: —They would all be better off.
—Indeed. I wish the defeated Liberal club actually had a vote in the Senate on this Bill. They would all vote for a draw for positions.

SPEECH.PARA: The final Bill that Senator Gietzelt presented, and probably the most important from the point of view of the Australian Labor Party, relates to his advocacy of optional preferential voting and the relaxing of the definition of what is a formal vote is and what is not. The Australian voting system, especially in the last 60 years, has always aimed at maximising the number of people being able to vote. In this country we have a situation in which never more than 80 per cent of the eligible people determine who should govern and who should not. Firstly, 5 per cent of the people who are on the electoral roll never vote. We rarely have an election in which over 93 per cent or 94 per cent of the people on the electoral roll vote. Secondly, people are left off the roll inadvertently, often by their own mistake. Perhaps they have moved and failed to get back on the roll .

Thirdly, many naturalised citizens do not realise that the next step after naturalisation is to go and get on the electoral roll. This Government does nothing to encourage that. I have had many experiences of talking to representatives of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and others and requesting them actually to go to the regions in which naturalisation ceremonies are held and to hand out electoral enrolment cards on that day but they will not do it. Finally, we have a group of scarlet pimpernels who just refuse to get on to the electoral roll, usually because it is the best way a creditor can track them down or, even more appropriately, the police. So there is a whole range of people who do not vote in any particular Federal election. But what our system does is add to that and disenfranchise people who want to vote, people who are on the roll and who go along conscientiously to vote but do not have the ability to fill out a ballot paper formally. Those people are penalised.

In my experience of scrutineering I have found three different types of informal voting. Firstly, there is the blank ballot paper. That to me indicates two things, either total confusion at being able to handle our electoral system or that people deliberately vote with a blank ballot paper. I am sure that there are people who do that, that there are people who say 'a plague on all Houses' and just put in a blank ballot paper so that they do not get fined. There is not much we can do about that with any particular voting system. It is up to the parties to encourage such people to vote for them. The second type of informal vote one finds is the cross or the tick. That is most common amongst migrants to this country. I am not referring just to non-English speaking migrants, but to all groups. People who come from England and who are used to the first past the post voting system just put an X on the ballot paper. I would say that that accounts for about 20 per cent to 30 per cent of all informal votes.

The third group consists of those people who inadvertently vote informal, who put two 3s or two 4s or, in the case of a Senate election, two 27s. I do not know what the magic thing is about the number 27, but in my scrutineering experience it has come up time and again in Senate elections. I do not know what it is about Australian people that they insist on putting two 27s but that mistake occurs more often than any other.

What is the extent of this informal voting problem? In House of Representatives elections we usually have a 2 per cent informal voting rate. I am not so sure that optional preferential voting would alter that situation dramatically, but it would at least mean that those people who inadvertently put in the same number twice will have their vote recorded formally. Senate elections are averaging an informal vote of something like 9 per cent. Given the figures I mentioned earlier, we could well have a situation in which government is affected in this chamber, firstly, because 5 per cent of the people do not vote; secondly, because other people are left off the roll; and, thirdly, because some people deliberately do not want to be on the roll. Migrants and 18-year-olds are not on the roll. That reduces quite a few of the potential voters. If we took out another 9 per cent for informal votes, under the proportional representation system we could well have 16 per cent of the people voting for the wasted quota. So we could have a government determined or controlled by this body with only 75 per cent of the Australian community having an effective say in the representation in this chamber.

We had a classic case in 1974 in New South Wales where in the electorate of Bradfield 5.6 of the people voted informally. I congratulate the electorate for that low level. But in the electorate of Sydney there was a 20.5 per cent informal vote. Part of the reason for that is the number of candidates who are permitted to run in Senate elections. We are all aware of what happened in 1974 when 73 candidates nominated in New South Wales, 48 in Victoria and 38 in South Australia. One might ask what was the cause of the sudden burst of enthusiasm by people to nominate. To be charitable, one could say that many people heard the call. But the reality, as far as I am concerned, is that a deliberate attempt was made there to fill out the ballot paper. There were probably 40 genuine candidates and 33 bodgie ones who were paid by a political group in this country and who were there to try to increase the informality. It is a fact that informal votes affect two major areas. One is the working class suburbs of major metropolitan areas. The reason that area ia so badly affected is that the people there do not have the same educational achievement as people in other parts of the metropolitan area and find it difficult to handle the voting system. The other area in which we find a very high informal vote is country regions. That is also due to educational deprivation and the unavailability of how-to-vote cards.

The main argument against optional preferential voting is that people may not express their preferences. But they are given the chance, under optional preferential, either to extend their preferences or not. The Labor Party would not very often allocate preferences in House of Representatives voting because I do not think that there is a seat in this country-perhaps there is one or two- where our preferences are ever distributed. We usually finish first or second so that our preferences are irrelevant. In a Senate election we would always distribute our preferences because there is always a preferred choice as to who sits in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Instead of a conservative.

—As Senator Gietzelt says, we would probably send them anywhere but to a conservative. But that is our right. I think the Liberal Party would send its preferences anywhere but to the Labor Party-other than in South Australia, of course. So, we are not taking preferential voting away; we are giving people the option of exercising a preference or not. Under this system, if people made a minor mistake on the ballot paper, the vote would not become informal. A poll conducted by the Bulletin in 1980 indicated that 60 per cent of people preferred the first past the post system of voting. This was the policy of the Labor Party for many years, mostly as a reaction to what happened with the Democratic Labor Party. We do not support that any more, but we support optional preferential voting.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion I mention some of the views of the Liberal Party of some years back. I will go back to 1948 as a matter of fact. Mr Gullett, the then member for the electorate in which I live, said:
If the elector is required to place all the candidates in the correct order it must result in an increase in the number of informal votes.
He was quite correct. Another member of parliament said:
The percentage of informal votes cast at every election is excessive.

Mr Anthony, whose son is now Acting Prime Minister, said that. The final quote from that debate in 1948 comes from Mr Archie Cameron, who went on to be a famous, or infamous, Speaker of the House of Representatives, depending upon which point of view one wants to approach the matter. He said:

. . . it seems utterly futile to propose seriously that an elector should be obliged to vote for every candidate on the list in order to record a formal vote . It is hard for electors to express their preference beyond three or four candidates and to compel a man to vote for 30 or 40 candidates-for the Lord knows how many aspirants for office there will be-is to go too far.
