That was the view of the Liberal Party three or four years after its birth. Honourable senators might ask why it does not change that view. The answer to that comes if one looks back to a 1974 Hansard when Senator Withers made the classic statement that no government amends an electoral Act to advantage the Opposition. The reason the electoral legislation has not been altered in the last 17 years is that it currently advantages the Liberal and National parties of Australia. We will have no change to electoral legislation emanating from the Government benches for that reason. The electoral laws favour those parties. I know that every time we propose a change to the Electoral Act the group opposite usually says that the Labor Party is trying to rig the system or that we are trying to work a rort in the system, et cetera. Senator Gietzelt has introduced three amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act. I think that even in 1974 many aspects of these Bills would have drawn support from members on the opposite side of the chamber. The reason for the rejection of the electoral Bills at that stage was that they tended to be presented in an omnibus form with some aspects being objectionable and some being acceptable to the Liberal Party. We are now putting up Bills relating to separate and distinct areas. The ball is now in the Liberal Party's court either to accept these Bills or to introduce effective reforms. If it does not, all its statements that it accepts a democratic system go down the tube.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bills which are before us this afternoon are private member's Bills. They have been brought in by Senator Gietzelt. I congratulate him for doing that. But it is a pity that they were not Government-initiated Bills because they deserve the support of all honourable senators. This Government has promised electoral reform many times in the past but it never seems to do anything about it. I want to make some brief remarks first about the proposed closing time for polling booths of 6 p.m. That was introduced in New South Wales by a Liberal-Country Party Premier, Mr Tom Lewis. I can understand it if many honourable senators here this afternoon do not remember Mr Lewis. He was one of six leaders of the Liberal Party in New South Wales in seven years. In fact, if honourable senators count the present leader, Mr Dowd, he was one of seven leaders--
—Who?

—Mr Dowd. Mr Lewis was one of seven leaders that the Liberal Party had in eight years. He might not be remembered for doing much at all for the State of New South Wales, but he will certainly be remembered for introducing the early closing time for the polls, as suggested by the Australian Labor Party at the time. The voting stops at 6 p.m. It has not caused a noticeable decline in the number of people voting. It has been of great assistance in enabling the electorate to know with reasonable certainty who has won the election by midnight on the day of polling. I admit that sometimes it takes weeks for the complete results of elections in Australia to be known, but that is a matter with which I shall deal when I discuss optional preferential voting. As Senator Robert Ray said, one cannot expect Commonwealth Electorate Office staff to be fully efficient in counting votes up to, say, 10 p.m. or midnight when they have been on duty since 7 a.m. At least 6 p.m. closing shortens their day, and it improves the efficiency of the staff.

SPEECH.PARA: The second of the Bills, which has been dealt with very well by Senator Robert Ray, concerns the drawing for positions on the ballot paper. I support that. However, I wish to make some remarks about party affiliation being listed on the ballot paper. I do so because the Australian Democrats have already made moves in this direction, and it is part and parcel of the Labor Party's electoral reform Bills. I support completely the concept that party affiliation should be shown on the ballot papers. More than 40 countries follow this practice already, including West Germany and Austria, and a case can be made out that those two countries have systems which are among the most democratic electoral systems in the world. It is also in existence in countries such as Italy and Ireland. If this practice were introduced in Australia it would help all voters, but it would be especially useful to the voters who were not born in this country and are not used to the practice of having to fill out every spot on the ballot paper and who, when they get into the booth, do not know for which candidate or which party they are voting.

That is especially important when one takes into account the ludicrous situation of people having been forced to fill in up to 73 squares on a Senate ballot paper, as happened in New South Wales in 1974. Again, that is something with which I shall deal in more detail during my remarks on optional preferential voting. What we should be doing is investigating the use of voting machines and examining all methods of making it easier for a voter to cast his vote, not making it harder. Surely that is what our democratic system is all about. If a Senate committee, as proposed by Senator Gietzelt and by me many times in the past but always rejected by the Government, could look into this matter in a bipartisan way, and not under pressure, a suitable result could be achieved.

Prior to 1975 even the major parties had difficulty in manning polling booths throughout New South Wales, particularly at Federal election level. But since the events of 1975 I have found that, be it at State level or Federal level, the Labor Party in New South Wales has had no difficulty in manning the polling booths, or the vast majority of them. Therefore, if the party affiliation is indicated on the ballot paper, it will not help the Labor Party. It certainly will not help the Labor Party in the same way as it will help the minor parties. However, it will reduce the informal vote and therefore it will be more democratic.

As to the Bill concerning optional preferential voting, what is needed is a complete overhaul of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. This has been promised to us in the past by Senator Withers and Senator Chaney, when they were the appropriate Ministers. It was also promised by Mr John McLeay when he was the appropriate Minister. But all that we have heard from this Government is deafening silence. Optional preferential voting is only one issue, but it would certainly go a long way towards making the Australian electoral system more reasonable. If ever proof were needed as to why our electoral procedures are outdated, we need only look at the Senate election in New South Wales in 1975. The ballot in New South Wales took place on 13 December 1975, and we received the final result on 6 February 1976. That is nearly two months later. Admittedly there were two recounts of the votes cast, but the very task of recounting was complicated by the fact that the voters had to fill in every square on the ballot paper.

Let me explain in some detail what happened in that 1975 poll. On the first count, the winning candidate for the last position-who happened to be myself-was elected by the margin of 854 votes out of about 3 million. That is 19 for each Federal division in New South Wales. I believe that that was the closest result in Senate history and it remains so. But when the full recount was taken we found that my winning margin had gone up from 854 votes to 2,016. I suppose people will say that when nearly three million votes have to be counted again it is a reasonable result to find a difference of only that many votes. But if we look at the total formal vote in 1975 we find that the scrutineers found, after recounting the ballot completely, another 12,000 informal votes. Twelve thousand votes is the total decline in the formal vote. What happened was that many votes which had been thrown out the first time went back into the count. Of course this further added to the number of informal votes.

In the recount in 1975 we found that hundreds of ballot papers had been credited to the wrong candidates. This occurred in every electoral division throughout New South Wales. Scrutineers rang me up and said: 'We have got some good news. We have just found 100 votes in the electorate of St George which were credited to the Liberal Party but which should have been credited to the Labor Party'. I knew that within 10 minutes the telephone would ring with news from another division that another 100 or 150 votes had gone the other way. The votes in the Senate election in New South Wales had been counted on the night of the election and the following week. They were rechecked and then opened up and recounted again. They were counted three times. I am convinced that if they had been counted a fourth time we would have found many more informal votes running into some hundreds at least. The quotas would have been different and we could have even had a different result, not in the elected candidate but certainly in the margin by which the candidate was elected.

I believe it is a farcical situation when the election result of the Australian Senate is not known for nearly two months after the election yet the result of an election in Great Britain, which has over 600 seats in the House of Commons, is known within 48 hours. In the United States of America, where literally hundreds of thousands of polling booths are spread over four distinct time zones , we know who is the president within 24 to 48 hours after the poll closes. I believe that our present system of exhaustive preferential voting discriminates heavily against the aged, the infirm, migrants and Aborigines. In those electorates in which there is a high concentration of socially disadvantaged electors one finds by far the highest informal voting figures. Senator Robert Ray gave examples of the fact that in the electorate of Sydney the 1974 Senate election informal vote was in excess of 20 per cent.

I want to cite figures from the 1977 House of Representatives and Senate elections. In 1977 the electorate of Sydney had an informal vote for the House of Representatives of 4.27 per cent. That was the highest in New South Wales. The electorate of Bradfield had the lowest informal vote in New South Wales; it was 1.3 per cent. Of course the electorate of Bradfield has the highest income per voter of any electorate in Australia. It is also the safest Liberal seat in Australia. In the 1977 Senate election the informal vote in the electorate of Sydney was 12.5 per cent-again that was the highest in the State-and the informal vote in Bradfield was 4.9 per cent, again the lowest of any division in New South Wales. If one were cynical about the matter those figures alone would prove why the Government has never done anything about the electoral system that we are talking about today. I am pleased to say that the electorate of Sydney does not now have the highest informal vote in New South Wales because the party in that electorate determined that it would do something about it and embarked on a very extensive scrutineering campaign. It has now got the informal vote in that electorate down to 10 per cent. It has been able to cut the informal vote dramatically.

The main reason for this high informal vote is that we still have a compulsory preferential voting system. The only possible justification for that system, in my opinion, is that it perhaps reflects in greater detail the wishes of the voters in that electorate. However, I think there are two arguments that one can use against that point. First, as Senator Robert Ray said, if we had an optional preferential system we would still allow electors to express their preferences right through the ballot paper if they so desired. That is the system that operates in the upper House in New South Wales. Secondly, a compulsory preferential system effectively disenfranchises between 9 per cent and 10 per cent of the electors in Senate elections in each State in Australia and results in a donkey vote of up to one per cent or 2 per cent. I well remember in the 1980 Senate election in New South Wales the candidate who got the donkey vote, the Reverend Fred Nile. He was trumpeting in the media in New South Wales what a great vote he had received and what a great endorsement the 135,000 votes were of the policies of the Call to Australia or the Right to Life or whatever the organisation was that he was leading. The bad news for the Reverend Fred Nile came on the last two days of the count. As a result of the Labor Party's scrutineers in every one of the 45 divisions-we concentrated for two full days on his vote alone-his vote was reduced by over 18,000 and we did that in two days.

In 1975 in the Senate election in New South Wales the party which received the donkey vote was the Socialist Workers League, a Trotskyite organisation. It is very interesting to see where its preferences went. It received approximately 26 ,000 votes. Two thousand five hundred voters-that is 2,500 out of 26,000- followed its ticket. Twenty two thousand three hundred votes went straight to the Liberal Party whose members were listed right beside those of the Socialist Workers League. So, the Liberal Party collected 22,500 votes from a Trotskyite organisation and said: 'Thanks very much'. What that means is that candidates can be elected to the Senate purely because people are forced to vote. For instance, as I gave the example in 1974, the electorate had to vote for 73 candidates. There are people sitting in the Senate today who are here not because their election reflects the wishes of the voters in their particular States but because of the position that they occupied on the ballot paper-the luck of the draw out of a hat. I believe it is a scandalous situation when control of the Senate can depend on a lottery as to who draws a particular position on a ballot paper when everybody in a State is forced to vote a certain way and when thousands of donkey votes help to elect a particular candidate.

In the New South Wales Legislative Council where the Labor Party introduced the first democratic elections ever to be held in that chamber the optional preferential system is in force. To cast a formal vote the person need only vote from one to nine. That does not stop people, if they want, from voting for every person on the ballot paper. It does not stop a party such as the Australian Democrats from putting out a how-to-vote card that has a number in every square. As a result of the optional preferential system in New South Wales the State- wide informal vote was approximately 4 per cent. In my opinion, that is still much too high but certainly much better than the average of 10 per cent that occurs in the Senate in my State.

Another point that I think should be made is why people should be forced to vote for some of the joke candidates that we have had standing for the Senate in recent years. Again I refer to my own State. We have had rock groups and disc jockeys puting their names on the Senate ballot paper just so they can get publicity. We have had people put their names on the ballot paper purely for tax evasion purposes. I do not believe that it is in the interests of democracy that people should be forced to give these candidates a vote.

The seriousness of this whole debate is shown by the fact that when voters were forced to fill out every square in 1974 on the Senate ballot paper the resulting informal vote and the position on the ballot paper, I believe, cost the Australian Labor Party the sixth Senate seat in New South Wales and the fifth Senate seat in Queensland. I believe that if one examines the percentage of the State-wide vote that the Labor Party received in New South Wales and in Queensland in 1974 either Westerway, the candidate for the Labor Party in New South Wales, or my colleague, Mal Colston, who was then the candidate in question in Queensland, should have won. If either of those seats had been won by the Labor Party the tragic events of 1975 that still divide this country would not have occurred. I hope that the Senate passes these Bills this afternoon. I believe the Senate should set up a committee on electoral reform as a matter of urgency. I believe that committee could go a long way towards making elections in Australia more democratic.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak only briefly on these three Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bills. We have had two very informative and interesting speeches on the Bills from members of the Australian Labor Party. It is good to see that the Labor Party is doing something about electoral reform. Nevertheless, I must say that I am somewhat disappointed that my own Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill, which was introduced in September and which sought, in particular, that party affiliations be placed on the ballot paper, was not listed for debate today. I believe a cognate debate on all four Bills could have been a very useful exercise. Electoral reform in this country has been a painfully slow business. These three Bills are part of a process of gradual change which began shortly after Federation and has continued intermittently ever since.

SPEECH.PARA: Of the three Bills before us now, I will be supporting wholeheartedly the Bill that seeks to have the poll closing time of six o'clock rather than eight o' clock. I will not go over the ground that has already been very well covered by Senator Robert Ray in particular, but the changed closing time is surely a very worthwhile reform. Personally, I support the Bill that deals with optional preferential voting. I think that the democratic process is at risk when candidates can so easily nominate for election to the Senate with the simple objective of confusing the voter through the ballot paper. We have an enlightened process of electing senators by the proportional representation system; we do get a selection of candidates to this chamber which reflects the proportion of votes cast for each party elected. That is a big advance. But the process is being held in some disrepute simply because of the ability of candidates, who have no objective other than to confuse the system, to put their names up as candidates thus making the voting process difficult for electors. Therefore, optional preferential voting, I think, is necessary if we are to continue to have support for our system of voting for candidates for election to the Senate, that is, proportional representation. I think the optional preferential voting would be a step in the right direction from the point of view of giving the elector an option whether he fills in every square. It could then be extended, I believe, to the proportional representation system for the Senate.

I particularly want to speak on the Bill that addresses the problem of the donkey vote. In my Bill, I suggested that this problem could best be solved by rotating the placement of the name of each candidate so that each candidate in turn had his name at the top of the ballot paper and the same number of ballot papers had the candidate's name at the top. Such a device would completely neutralise the donkey vote once and for all. The main problem with Senator Gietzelt's proposal is that it does not really tackle the problem. It is still leaving to fate which candidate is to be put at the top of a ballot paper. As we have been told by Senator Robert Ray, this donkey vote could be between two, three or four per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said it could be between 0.6 and 2 per cent.
—I thought Senator Ray instanced some Democrat results which he put higher than two per cent.
—I put some of it down to the quality of the candidate.
—Thank you.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I intervene to draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of a delegation from the Energy and Commerce Committee of the Congress of the United States of America. They are led by Representative Cardiss Collins from Illinois. On behalf of all honourable senators, I welcome the delegation to Australia and, in particular, to this chamber. I trust that their visit to Australia will be a happy and rewarding one.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —By rotating the names of the candidates on the ballot paper we would eliminate the element of chance. Every candidate would be fairly treated and we would address and overcome this very considerable problem. I foreshadow that during the Committee stage I will move an amendment to the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill (No. 2) designed to determine the order of names on the ballot papers for the House of Representatives by rotation and not by lot. I conclude my remarks at this point. I will again address this problem during the Committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly to the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1982 and the Bills which we are debating cognately to raise a central theme in terms of electoral reform, that is, we wish to make it as easy as possible for every citizen to cast his vote in the most effective way. Therefore, the various proposals that come forward from time to time have to be judged in the light of the way that the citizen is able to be effective democratically. I believe that the three Bills before us provide ways in which that would be able to be obtained. The Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill (No. 3), relating to time, is probably one of the least contentious. I believe that most State governments-certainly my State has done so for a long time-would agree to closing the polls at the earlier hour of 6 o'clock. There seems to be no problem. It is a matter of voter understanding and habit. It would make for a more effective operation of polling day.

SPEECH.PARA: We sometimes look at electoral matters in a one-off way. There are many ways in which elections can be streamlined and made more effective. It is a pity that Senator Gietzelt's proposal-I think it was last year-to have a select committee was never able to be implemented. The original intention was to seek a joint committee but that was refused by the House of Representatives. However, I believe advertisements were put in newspapers and some submissions were received . The Senate should again look, perhaps in the few years at activating such a committee to look at a very wide range of proposals that come forward not only from Australia but also from overseas. I mention one which may seem heretical to many people. In Switzerland it is permissible for a voter to use a 'how to vote' card when voting. When one thinks about it at first blush it seems rather odd but, on second thoughts, there seems to be no reason why, provided the normal safeguards in our particular way of voting are applied, a person could not use a 'how to vote' card if that was his or her intention. Many systems operate that we could look at not only in other countries but also in our State governments. Senator Siddons has already mentioned the system that is used currently in Tasmania. Proposals that have been implemented by State governments in Australia may very well be the first ones off the rank in a Federal sphere because we know that they work and that voters will adopt and use them in an effective and useful way.

The last point to make relates to the points made by Senator Sibraa which I thought were very interesting, particularly those relating to the counting of the Senate vote. Senator Colston has also written fairly extensively on this issue. We must look not only at the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill (No. 4 ) which relates to optional preferential voting, but also at the very heart of the way in which the Senate vote is counted. It is counted-most people in Australia probably do not know this-by one of the most idiosyncratic implementations of the method anywhere in the world. I believe that the reason that we have stayed away from and the strength of the argument to stay away from a correct counting method, is that people say it would take an exceptionally long time. Here I recall to honourable senators' minds a point that I made some weeks ago in relation to the annual report of the Australian Electoral Office. I referred to a reply given by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman ) about the possibility of using computers in elections. In part of his answer the Minister referred to computers as giant adding machines. I made the point at that time-I make it again now-that that sort of comment could have been made in the 1960s, it might have been pardoned in the 1970s but it is totally unpardonable in the 1980s. It is certainly unpardonable when given by the Minister in response to a formal question. It is a most extraordinary statement. It will probably go down in the annals as one of the silliest answers given in the Parliament.

The use of technology in regard to electoral systems is complex. I acknowledge that a lot of arguments must be thrashed out before computers can be used for that purpose. The point I am trying to make is that we ought to be addressing ourselves to the problem. We ought to be acknowledging that other countries are using this technology and are seeking to do so in a more and more refined fashion. As I pointed out in speaking on electoral matters on another occasion, computer technology is used very effectively by our gambling establishment, the Totalisator Agency Board. The facilities offered by the TAB are used by all sectors of the Australian population.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't find it very effective.

—I do not find it very effective either, Senator, because I do not use those facilities. However, I have looked at the system and it works. It works from the point of view of the user. It is very simple and straightforward and given the various combinations and permutations that are available for betting, the TAB carries out a number of quite sophisticated operations. Such a system would not have to be developed much further in order to be used when elections are held. If the old problem of cost is raised perhaps that could be solved by going into partnership with the TAB. It would also defray part of that organisation's costs. The day on which elections were held would probably have to be changed to Wednesday. We could not possibly hold them on Saturday because the races would be interrupted! Nevertheless, an interlinked, complex computer system has been established all around Australia for the entertainment of our citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that in an area as vital as elections we ought to have examined this possibility before now. Such a system could be employed in a range of areas. Obviously it could be employed at a federal level. It could be employed at the State government level and also at the local government level. It could also be employed by unions, in respect of which this Liberal Party Government is vociferous about holding secret postal ballots. It is a good way of holding such a ballot and overcoming the objections of unionists about the length of time it takes to get the results. In other words, this resource would be available to a variety of people within the community. That particular item was included in the terms of reference specified for the Senate select committee proposed by Senator Gietzelt. If the Government does not see fit to support these Bills, I hope that it will at least support the establishment of a select committee so that we can have a detailed, in-depth, comprehensive view of elections and electoral matters . If we establish such a committee we will be able to say to our citizens in 1982 and in the period to the year 2000 that at least we have made an attempt to update our electoral methods and make them as democratic as we can afford and manage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say at the outset that the Government opposes all of the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bills before the Senate. Indeed, I am at a loss to know why the Australian Labor Party is rehashing these matters now. They were put before this chamber and were rejected several years ago. Basically, there is nothing new in this legislation. Having said that, I must also draw to the Senate's attention the fact that in April 1980 the Government established the Harders Committee of Inquiry into Disclosure of Electoral Expenses to examine electoral legislation and has given quite a deal of considerations to its report, which has been in its hands for some time. The report is complex and far-ranging and covers many matters which affect every senator and member of the Parliament. In the new year the Government will put before the Parliament recommendations that flow from its consideration of that report.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer first to Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1982, which proposes that candidates' positions on House of Representatives ballot papers be determined by lot. I acknowledge the amendment now foreshadowed by Senator Siddons seeking an alteration to that. Senator Gietzelt argues that this will reduce the effect of the unconsidered vote, normally called the donkey vote, on the national result in House of Representatives elections. Let us look at that argument carefully. In individual electorates the effect of any donkey vote would not be eliminated. Senator Gietzelt's amendment would merely substitute the luck of the draw for the fact that one's surname begins with A or Z. We noted Senator Robert Ray's very interesting explanation and exposition on the number of candidates whose names begin with a letter between A and M. Taken across the whole country in respect of the House of Representatives, not only would the donkey vote not be eliminated but also its effects would not necessarily be reduced. Indeed, if a party had the luck of the draw in the comparatively small number of marginal seats decided by sufficiently few votes for the donkey vote to have had some influence, the possible effect could turn out to be greater than under the present system.

Just as an illustration, in the draw for positions for groups at the 1975 Senate election the coalition parties' candidates were drawn ahead of the Australian Labor Party candidates on the ballot papers in all six States and in both Territories. Frankly, one is forced to ask whether this is an amendment merely for the sake of an amendment. I must say that I am also not convinced that we should legislate, as Senator Gietzelt seems to think we should, to remove possibilities that political parties in their preselections will seek to choose candidates whose surnames are likely to place them near the top of the ballot paper.

I turn to the third Bill, which proposes to close the polls at 6 o'clock instead of 8 o'clock to reduce the hours which polling staff are asked to work. Nowhere in his second reading speech did Senator Gietzelt show any concern whatsoever for the elector. That principle has not been brought out by any speakers. The general principle underlying the current polling hours at Federal elections is that they should enable the largest possible number of voters to record their votes with a minimum of inconvenience. Given that voting is compulsory, it is particularly important that the task of casting a vote be facilitated. For example, extended polling hours give electors in hot climates the chance to vote in the cooler evening. At the 1980 election about 8 per cent of electors nationwide voted between 6 p.m. and 8 p.m. and in Western Australia the figure was as high as 11.3 per cent. In the Northern Territory it was 10.4 per cent. Right across the country 680,000 people took advantage of the opportunity to vote between 6 p.m. and 8 p.m. There is little doubt that a substantial number of them would have been inconvenienced had the polls closed earlier than they did.

Senator Gietzelt also seems to think that 6 p.m. closing will somehow enhance the ability of the Australian Electoral Office to conclude the night's count with a firm result in any but a finely balanced situation. This point was drawn out by Senator Robert Ray also. I just draw attention to the fact that in the recent election in South Australia where the polls closed at 6 p.m. there was no noticeable improvement in the delivery of the result. In fact it seemed to be somewhat later than one would have expected. It was 9.30 to 10 o'clock before the result became anywhere near clarified. I suppose that the closeness of the result and the failure of the ALP to do particularly well were the reasons for that.

TALK.START.PARA: —We knocked you right off.

—You only just scraped in. Senator Gietzelt does not seem to realise that already under the current law ordinary votes for the House of Representatives are counted on election night. As honourable senators will be aware, absentee votes are not counted on the night and postal votes can come in up to 10 days after the close of the poll. That is highly relevant to the Senate , as every honourable senator should understand.

SPEECH.PARA: The arrival of absentee and postal votes would determine the time upon which the quota could be finally determined. Furthermore, in Victoria, which has 6 o' clock closing for State elections, experience has been that counts are concluded only marginally earlier. I draw attention to that South Australian result as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Victoria we knew at 7.30 p.m.

—It happened also to be a particularly warm day that day so, no doubt, people would have appreciated the booths staying open a little later. It is doubtful whether any great benefits would flow from a reduction in the hours worked by polling staff. The cost savings would be very slight. It is unlikely that there would be any reduction in the hours worked on polling day by permanent staff of the Electoral Office. Casual staff are fully aware of the hours they are to work before they seek positions as polling officials. The alleged reduction in the pressure on party supporters must be set against the inconvenience which could be experienced by a much greater number of electors if the proposal were implemented.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill (No. 4), which proposes optional preferential voting and a broader criteria of formality. I interpose here to respond to Senator Robert Ray's point that elections conducted with a form of optional preferential voting are, in fact, easier to count and take considerably less time to count. I think Senator Sibraa referred to this matter also. That does not happen to be the experience in South Australia where optional preferential voting has been applying for the last two elections for the Legislative Council, the upper House. Clearly, in those two elections-in 1979 and in 1982, which has just passed-there was no evidence that the elections were conducted in any quicker time than would otherwise have applied. In fact we are now almost three weeks on from the date of the 1982 South Australian election and there is still no result for the Legislative Council election.

There are, of course, numbers of defects in the scheme proposed by Senator Geitzelt. These all arise from the fact that the Bill would create a new category of vote-the exhausted vote. Votes would become exhausted at the stage of the count at which the elector did not indicate a preference for any candidate left in the count or where a voter skipped a number or showed the same preference for more than one candidate left in the count. The first possible effect of this is that a party's candidates could get an absolute majority of first preference votes at a Senate election but fail, for example, to get the three seats out of five which it might expect under the current system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, you are joking. You don't understand the Senate count.

—Just listen, Senator. This could happen if a party's supporters had failed to indicate sufficient later preferences. Honourable senators will be aware that in order to gain election they must get that quota. Under the Commonwealth Electoral Act as it stands the only exception to this rule arises where there is only one seat left to be filled and only two candidates left. In this situation the candidate with the majority of votes is elected even if he does not have that quota. If Senator Gietzelt's Bill becomes law it would be possible for votes to be exhausted on such a scale that there could be two seats left to fill and only two candidates left with neither having gained a quota. What would happen in that situation? Neither could be elected because under the Act as amended a quota would still be needed to win the second last seat. The Bill just does not take that posibility into account. Even if votes were not exhausted on a large enough scale to give rise to that anomaly the probability of a candidate winning the last position with less than a quota would be increased. Extreme those examples might be but the law must be precise and must cover those kinds of situations.

SPEECH.PARA: The final defect is connected with the random sampling of surplus ballot papers of elected candidates which are to be distributed to the remaining candidates during the Senate count. Honourable senators may recall that in the event of a recount a fresh random sample of ballot papers is taken. I am advised that the probability of the result being changed by the taking of a fresh sample is very small under the current system. This probability would certainly be increased somewhat if Senator Gietzelt's Bills were passed, since the exhausted votes in the system would introduce a new element of variability in the sampling.

I would like to deal with one or two other points which were mentioned during the debate, in particular the questions raised by Senator Robert Ray concerning new citizens or new enrollees. The Australian Electoral Office writes to every new citizen and advises him of his franchise obligations and entitlements to vote. Senator Robert Ray also drew our attention to the fact that party designations are allowed in some countries on ballot papers. The examples that he gave were, of course, those countries running proportional representation systems of government--

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that at all.
—Who was it? Was it Senator Gietzelt?
—It was another honourable senator. Get your facts right.

—I am sorry. It was one of the Opposition senators. Perhaps it was Senator Sibraa. Although there is some concern in this area, there is a difference between our system and others. Whilst it might be true that in some countries the party affiliations are shown, I certainly do not believe a case has been made out for it here. The Government will be opposing the amendment of Senator Siddons in relation to the rotation of names on ballot papers. We will deal with that when we come to the Committee stage. I repeat that the Government will be opposing all three Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I, like my colleagues, congratulate the Australian Labor Party on at least taking a crack at the essential problem of electoral reform in this country, which reform is very much overdue. But I reiterate what a number of other speakers have said-that the whole system needs a complete reworking from beginning to end. We will not achieve a great deal by simply taking a piecemeal cut at it. That applies particularly to my view of Senator Gietzelt's Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1982, which I will speak to in a minute or two. I would support the No. 2 Bill as amended by Senator Siddons's amendment, and I approve of the No. 3 Bill. These are at least two areas in which I think we can effect an improvement which would be in the interests of the people of this country. I commend those Bills from that point of view.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill No. 4 worries me greatly. The whole principle of optional preferential voting is something which I think looks good on the face of it but which does not really work when construed into practice. I know all the arguments for it. I tend to agree with all of them. It would be a very good principle. It would be the best of all possible worlds where everybody is decent, where no political party wants to get the numbers and where voters have automatically knowledge and opinions on all candidates. But it is not that kind of world. I know it is tedious for voters to have to fill in all the numbers on their Senate ballot papers but I suggest that it is in their best interests and certainly in the best interests of democracy in this country that they should do so. The point is , of course, that most people follow party how to vote cards. I say to Senator Tate, who is trying to interject, that if he looks at the history of optional preferential voting since it was introduced in New South Wales he will see abundantly demonstrated what I am now about to say-that in practice in Australian politics, and I suggest in politics in most parts of the world, it comes down to a very thinly disguised first past the post system in the lower House and a elitist system in the upper House. In by-elections and other elections in New South Wales for the lower House it has been stressed by the Australian Labor Party that the elector should vote 1 for the Labor candidate. There has been no question of any preferences whatsoever. That is a positive discouragement for any person to distribute preferences at all.

The optional preferential system is calculated absolutely to perpetuate the two -party system forever, because it will discourage and reduce the chances of the election of gifted Independents and members of emerging parties. I think that is something which is to be greatly deplored, not only because of the effect it would have on the Australian Democrats but also because of our wider belief that more diversity in politics is necessary. We must have a situation which, one way or another, expresses that diversity. Until we have a system which in totality can do better than the one we have now I fear that optional preferential voting for the Senate will not achieve that. The present system does oblige the voter to give consideration to the people who put themselves up for election. That has a certain value in its own right. If people put themselves up for election it is reasonable that they should be considered in some way by the voter. I think that the present system does oblige the voter at least to give some thought to forces in the community which might be new, which might be emerging, which, due to the sheer inertia of human nature, the voter would not consider if a purely optional situation applied. As I say-this can be proved statistically-most people follow major party how-to-vote cards. That being the case there is a complete short circuiting and a reduction virtually to a first-past-the-post system for lower Houses and a list system for upper Houses. On that basis I will oppose the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-When I spoke earlier in this debate apparently I said that the Reverend Fred Nile, who stood in the Senate election in New South Wales in 1980, led a Right to Life team. If I did say that I apologise; it was a mistake. Reverend Nile led a team called the Call to Australia, of which I certainly am aware. It was a slip of the tongue. Apparently some people from the Right to Life Association have already been on the telephone to correct the statement so I take this opportunity to correct it myself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Senate is considering three Bills to amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act. Having just heard Senator Mason, it appears that at this juncture at least the amendment which seeks to provide for optional preferential voting and the liberalisation of the definition of ' informality' will not be passed. It also appears that the Bill which seeks to reduce the effect of the unconsidered vote, which is normally called the donkey vote, will be heavily amended or perhaps will not be passed. The other Bill which is before us seeks to close the polling booths at 6 p.m. At this point it appears that this Bill may have a chance of passing the Senate. My query is this : Why should the Government and Opposition agree to these measures coming before the Senate at this time? The Bills were introduced into the Parliament last week . They have not had the normal gestation period given to measures of this sort- that is to say, that which is given to private members' Bills. Normally when private members' Bills are introduced into the Parliament a second reading speech is made, the debate is adjourned and perhaps two or three months' later consideration is given to the measures in the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Siddons has a Bill before the Parliament. Why is his Bill not being discussed at this time. What is the rush? To my knowledge there is no election around the corner. I thought that we were not having an election at this time because of the bad back of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). I cannot understand the rush. Having heard the debate on the Bill which deals with the closing hours of the polling booths, I have no objection to this measure. It seems to merit consideration and support. After all, the polls do close at 6 p.m . in a number of States when State elections are held. To my knowledge there has not been a great scream from voters in those States about the closing time of the polls. That covers that provision.

The optional preferential voting system certainly has attraction in relation to the Senate. I note the table in the second reading speech which deals with Senate elections. I recognise that there is a difficulty in Senate elections for which there are large numbers of candidates for a valid vote to be determined by reference to the fact that electors must place numerals in consecutive order in the squares opposite each and every one of those candidates. I notice that in the Senate election in 1975 there were 53 candidates for New South Wales. I suggest that there should be some amendments to the current provisions so as to ensure that the elector need not place a consecutive mark against every one of those candidates. I cannot recall the average time involved for the elector to place numbers in sequence against the names of 53 candidates but it was quite considerable.

The difficulty with this Bill is the one that was mentioned by Senator Mason, namely, the problem of the numbers of candidates in a Senate election. Having attempted to overcome that problem the Bill transposes that problem to the House of Representatives. As Senator Mason has said, this results in the House of Representatives ultimately having a first-past-the-post system. If there is to be a general acceptance of the provisions allowed for in the Bill and if electors generally opt to proceed along those lines we will see in the House of Representatives a first-past-the-post system. I do not think the honourable senator who introduced the Bill would suggest that but I suggest that that may well be the ultimate result. In any event, Senator Mason has indicated his opposition to the provision. Therefore, at this stage it appears that that will not hit the deck tonight.

The Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill (No. 4) seeks to reduce the effect of the unconsidered vote, normally called the donkey vote. The means by which it is proposed that this occur is the drawing by lot of the positions on the ballot paper. My view on this matter is similar to that of Senator Siddons and, to a certain extent, that of the Minister. That does not really get rid of the unconsidered or donkey vote. It only transposes alphabetical considerations to ones of lot. The donkey vote will still be there.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gets rid of party selection based on alphabetical superiority.

—I concede that it certainly does that. I really support this Bill but I believe it does not go far enough. The amendment proposed by Senator Siddons extends that principle and, therefore, deserves support. Senator Siddons is proposing that there be a rotational system, a system similar to that which is now in operation for elections in Tasmania. This would mean that every candidate would have a chance of being placed on the top of the ballot paper. That also does not eliminate the unconsidered or donkey vote because there will be an unconsidered or donkey vote no matter which way we go about it. But that makes no difference to the ultimate result, and that really is what we are talking about.
—It makes a how-to-vote card more difficult which may be helpful to people to prevent them casting an informal vote as opposed to an unconsidered vote.

—I understand what Senator Tate is saying, but if we are talking about an unconsidered vote and we are looking at ways and means of overcoming it then that is one way of doing so. I might mention that this system has been accepted in Tasmania and appears to have worked reasonably well. My own view about it, however, is that this proposal is limited to the House of Representatives. I am certainly not prepared to support the measure as proposed by Senator Siddons, unless it is applicable to the Senate as well. If this were done we would try to eliminate the power of the donkey vote. Also there would be an added advantage in that this proposition would also tend to remove the power exerted by political parties over their own candidates within groups. I would suggest that if the Senate is serious about this desire to eliminate the donkey vote this legislation should apply to both House of Representatives and Senate elections. If that were the case I would support the measure. As it is now, the legislation is to apply only to the House of Representatives, and I see that to be somewhat discriminatory. We are proposing to eliminate the donkey vote for House of Representatives elections but not in respect of Senate elections. Therefore, I do not propose to support the measure at this time.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I suggest that now is not the time to be debating this measure. The Minister has made a statement to the Senate concerning the intentions of the Government. The Minister said that the Government will, in the first session of Parliament next year, introduce legislation after having considered the report of the Harders Committee of Inquiry into Disclosure of Electoral Expenses. It will then be for the Houses of Parliament, both the House of Representatives and the Senate, to consider those measures and, if necessary, to amend them to ensure that the principle which these measures seek to implement are implemented in an adequate and effective manner. So I would have thought that the best means of dealing with this matter at present is for a motion to be moved at some stage that the debate be adjourned. Otherwise, it appears that both of the measures will go down the drain. I would not be happy with that arrangement because some of the proposals in the legislation have merit. Therefore my simple suggestion for anyone who might listen to me in a situation such as this is that if the Opposition wants the legislation passed at some later stage it might consider adjourning the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been suggested by Senator Harradine that the means by which this debate arose this afternoon were somewhat unusual. Perhaps I can put his mind at rest by saying that it was at the request of the Australian Democrats that debate on these Bills was brought on in preference to Bills which had their origin with the Australian Democrats. The Democrats, quite logically and properly, did not want to debate the Bills that were listed next on the Notice Paper as they related to South West Tasmania. I understand that next week some reports dealing with that issue will be presented . Therefore, we were requested to fill the breach. That is why these Bills are being debated this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: I put to Senator Harradine that one of the few options available to members of Parliament is the introduction of a private member's Bill. That is a very jealously guarded privilege which we should preserve. The Executive largely determines the legislative program. No matter which political party one supports or belongs to, one of the privileges that we have is to have private member's Bills and General Business considered on a Thursday afternoon. In recent months, attempts have been made to have these matters brought forward. The consequence of that action is that we have introduced three pieces of legislation which we hope will have the support of the Senate. When Parliament resumes next year, we will run the gauntlet in the House of Representatives where the Government has the opportunity to amend or reject private member's Bills.

I remind the Senate-and I am sure Senator Messner will agree in relation to the period since he has been a member of Cabinet-that I have asked him and before him Senator Chaney and Senator Peter Baume, numerous questions about the reports that have been compiled by the Commonwealth Electoral Office. Since I have had the responsibility of researching electoral reform for my party, I have spent most of last year and this year endeavouring to get the Government to move in respect of these reports, which have not been made available to the Parliament, and which have now been in the hands of the executive Government for more than two and a half years. I think we are entitled to say that our patience has worn thin while we have been waiting for Government action. The Minister has stated that something will happen early next year. If I were to present the Senate with the replies to my questions honourable senators would see that that is a promise which has been made to me for the last 18 months. The Government says that it has the reports and that it intends to do something about them. If, by putting down our private member's Bills we have prodded the Government to move, that is probably a step in the right direction.

I submit to the Senate that these Bills are designed to simplify the electoral processes, to make every vote effective and to bring about a situation whereby informal voting is considerably reduced and every vote becomes an effective vote . I submit also that another part of the process which I believe the Senate ought to consider seriously is a move towards a degree of uniformity in Australia's electoral voting systems. The situation now is that in five of the voting areas of Australia-four of the States and the Northern Territory-we have 6 o'clock closing of the polls. I have looked at the voting figures in each of those areas, that is, the three main States on the eastern seaboard, South Australia and the Northern Territory. When we compare State elections at which we have 6 o'clock closing with Commonwealth elections and elections in the two States that do not have 6 o'clock closing, we find no evidence to suggest that voters are disadvantaged in any way, shape or form as a result of 6 o'clock closing.

I think we can probably find at least common ground with the majority of honourable senators in that respect. No argument can be presented, apart from the disadvantages that Senator Messner put forward, that voters will be disadvantaged. He produced no evidence of that. It was purely a hearsay approach . If he is prepared to compare the voting patterns in State and Federal elections, he will find that there is absolutely no difference and no disadvantage to the voters at all.

The reduction of informal voting is a very important objective and one which the Parliament ought to be considering. I remind the Senate, for example, that there was a 15.2 per cent informal vote-a very large informal vote-for the Senate in the 1980 election in the seat of Melbourne. Thirty per cent of the voters in that electorate are migrants. So one is entitled to say that to the degree that we delay consideration of these matters we are disadvantaging almost one in three of those people insofar as they find it difficult to complete the ballot paper, as Senator Harradine and others have suggested. My colleagues Senator Robert Ray and Senator Sibraa have referred to the fact that people have difficulty, whether there are 40, 50 or 70 candidates on the ballot paper, in filling in the paper. If they fill in No. 27 twice or if they leave out a number the vote becomes invalid. That process ought to be unacceptable to any thinking person. This legislation seeks to create a new definition of an informal vote so that provided the voter's intention is clear the vote shall be regarded as formal to the level at which the informality takes place. If a ballot paper has two No. 13s on it the vote will be valid up to No. 13.

When we see the extent of the informality in Senate voting, it surely behoves the Senate to take steps to remove the difficulties that obviously face the increasing number of people who come to this country from other parts of the world where the voting systems are entirely different from ours. Some countries have a first-past-the-post system, others have proportional representation and in others voters use a cross to indicate their choice. In Australia different optional preferential systems operate in the States; a different system operates in the Federal sphere and a different system operates in the local government sphere. Can we wonder, therefore, why it is possible that, at the next Federal election, one million people in Australia may lose their votes as a result of their not understanding the voting system? The voting system discriminates against them to the extent that their votes become ineffective because of their failure to understand the system and complete every square on the ballot paper. Enough has been said in the debate to indicate that the Senate has been manipulated by certain unscrupulous political aspirants in a way which is designed to create such confusion.

The question has been raised by members of the Australian Democrats whether a vote shall be valid if the number of candidates marked exceeds by one the number of candidates to be elected. To appreciate that, the legislation, if adopted, would have the objective of making the ballot effective to the degree that if five candidates were to be elected, a voter could fill in the ballot paper to the extent of the number of candidates who had nominated on the how-to-vote card and if, in fact, he filled it in in respect of one more position, it would be a valid vote. That is a matter of some concern to Senator Mason, but the question how far a voter would fill in the ballot paper from the how-to-vote ticket would be resolved by negotiation between the parties concerned. It is not a question of this system being used to disadvantage minor parties or other candidates in the ballot. Rather, the system is designed to remove the ballot count, rather than the ballot itself. The ballot count would become an effective count when the elector filled one more name than the number of candidates to be elected. Of course, political parties will put out a how-to-vote ticket which has the names of the candidates nominated. But if, by chance, people fail to complete the ballot paper to the extent of the number of candidates nominated, that shall be a valid vote.

In respect of the point raised by Senator Siddons, I say that the system of drawing positions on the ballot paper is one that has operated advantageously for the Australian Democrats and independent senators. There is no doubt that whoever draws a key position-

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never had it.

—I am not necessarily talking about this election, I am talking generally. There is no doubt that a person who draws the number one position on the Senate ballot paper has a decided advantage. That point is conceded. It would be foolish for the Parliament to change that system because it is drawn by lot. Therefore, the candidates who group themselves have the opportunity of equality in the way in which they finish up on the ballot paper. I think, it would be true to say that at the last election the Democrats were advantaged in some of the draws that they had. I think Senator Siddons should look at the system for the House of Representatives carefully because the drawing of positions for the ballot to elect a representative there combined with the freedom that is proposed under optional preferential voting, does effect and can have the effect of eliminating any donkey vote at all because, again, it is an option. If four candidates stood for election, votes one and two would be effective votes. In fact, we find that even in the House of Representatives elections, where there are only a small number of candidates, on average two or three percent of the votes are lost. As we have seen in elections in recent times that is sufficient to affect the overall result.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine said, if I heard him correctly, that he would support the basic principle of the legislation but would not do so if it were extended to make candidates for the House of Representatives draw by lot in the same way as for the Senate. We do not seek to change the Senate system because that system was introduced when proportional representation began in 1949.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry; you misunderstood me. I think that it was the other way. What I should like to see is rotational voting for the Senate, as proposed for the House of Representatives by Senator Siddons.
—You would not support that?
—I would.

—You would; I see. That is a decision which you may well take. But what we are proposing here is to have the same system operating for the House of Representatives as operates in respect of the Senate-that is, a draw by lot. Senator Siddons seeks to have a rotating system, which is not proposed either in the legislation or in his amendment, because, as I understand it, it applies only to the House of Representatives.
—But the draw by lot for the Senate now gets the donkey vote.

—That is true, but at least everyone has equal opportunities to the donkey vote. That is an important point. We are trying to get some improvements in the Australian electoral system. I would like to go considerably further. These matters require discussion before being properly resolved.
—If we discuss it, I think that we could resolve it.

—Yes, I am sure that there are areas on which we could reach some measure of agreement. I understand that we have other legislation with which we should deal tonight. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjounred.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this debate was interrupted I was summarising some of the Opposition's views about the current Budget. I would like to go back to that and to say that the Budget is basically a receipts and expenditure document for the Government of Australia. On the receipts side of the Budget some grossly inaccurate estimates have been made by the Government. The first of those to which I wish to refer is the amount of tax from pay-as-you-earn income earners which was miscalculated in the Budget of August this year, and it is a miscalculation which is being compounded day after day as unemployment continues to rise. The estimate for receipts from PAYE tax earners did not square, even as at August of this year, with the Government's own estimate of growth in the economy-namely, nil; nor did it square with the likely estimate of unemployed persons which the Government made at the time.

SPEECH.PARA: The second item of receipts in the Budget which shows very rubbery figures-to use Sir Phillip Lynch's phrase-is that the Budget assumes no loss of revenue from tax avoidance or evasion. That was because at the time it was part of the rhetoric of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) to say that the tax evasion or tax avoidance industry had been disposed of by wave of the Treasurer's magic wand or whatever, and that there would be no loss of revenue in those areas. I just wanted to make the point again that that rhetoric and the figures in the Budget just do not square with reality or with the estimates of the Commissioner of Taxation, which have been revealed in his most recent report. I do not know whether the Treasurer has yet got the habit of talking with the Commissioner of Taxation from time to time. They certainly lost it for a number of years while tax avoidance and evasion was flourishing. But one would have hoped that by now the Treasurer, at least on these major matters, and without coming into conflict with the provisions of section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, might have got into the habit of talking occasionally with the Commissioner of Taxation, and especially when making estimates in relation to Budget receipts.

The third area in which the receipts side of the Budget is wrong is in the estimate of company tax receipts. That must be an extremely doubtful estimate. As a result of the falling profitability of companies there is an estimated error of something like $600m in company tax receipts. Another area of receipt estimates in the Budget which seems to have been wrong is that of health rebates . There seems to be a $100m underestimation by the Government in relation to that rebate system. There is also a likely error in the Budget in relation to the amount which the Government will receive from its legislation to obtain tax owing to the Commissioner of Taxation as a result of taxation avoidance in the past few years. The Government's estimates of that are, in the Opposition's view , somewhat wild.

I also make the point that the Government, in this Budget, offered tax cuts and that offer, of course, is very much affected by the number of people who are likely to be in employment. This week the Government advocated a wages pause as, in the first instance, a method of gaining an additional $700m from the salaries of public servants throughout Australia to finance the growing unemployment benefit claims which have to be paid and as a method of providing money for work which will sop up some of the unemployment figures which are now so disastrous.

On the expenditure side of the Budget, the estimated expenditure on unemployment benefits was way out at the time of the Budget and every day it gets more and more way out as unemployment rises. I remind the Senate that the cost to this country of a one per cent increase in unemployment in terms of the cost of unemployment benefit and revenue forgone has been estimated as being in the area of $1 billion. That is what unemployment is costing this country in gross terms. It is a matter of great concern when one considers the whole economic strategy of this Government.

Another area of estimated expenditure which is doubtful is that relating to drought relief. It is estimated to cost $360m. In the discussion today on the Estimates the Minister for Finance, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, gave some bases upon which that estimate was made, but there is some doubt about the real expenditure which will be incurred. So there are two items of major significance -the expenditure on drought relief and the expenditure on unemployment benefit- which drastically alter the size of the deficit and the overall strategy of the Budget.

This Government was able to find quickly an estimated $360m to assist farmers who are suffering from the drought. We have no objection to that. We supported the legislation. The farmers need relief-although we have some criticisms of the schemes which have been devised for providing that relief. But it was easy to find the money. Apparently it was easy to find the additional $300m which it has been estimated will be required for unemployment benefit. That was to cover up, as it were, a government mistake in estimating the cost of unemployment benefit. It was easy to find that total of $660m, but if one is to find more money to deal with growing unemployment the way now suggested is a wages pause. This is after seven years, of course, of fighting inflation first. It is now suggested that one of the reason for the wages pause is to assist in the reduction of inflation. If it does that, well and good, but there is some very real doubt and uncertainty as to whether that result will follow.

This Budget is a shambles of a document for the reasons which I have suggested. It is a shambles of a document in a sense culminating seven years of Government economic mismanagement of this country and a failure of government strategies. I remind the Senate that this Budget is introduced in a year in which Australia is in the unique economic situation of having rising inflation and rising unemployment at the same time. No other country in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, for example, has those two factors operating together. Only the Fraser Government has those two things happening at the same time.

This country has in addition the highest interest rates in the OECD. So we have rising inflation, rising unemployment, and the highest interest rates, no growth in the economy, no real promise of growth in the economy and no prediction of growth in the Budget Papers. We have an enormous overseas debt. We have no wages policy. We have had seven years of gross inaction on industry restructuring- seven years of dreadful inaction on this most important area which is now affecting the economy drastically. For seven years the Australian Government has followed those strat- egies. Added to that, compared with other countries which are better governed, we have falling living standards which are moving Australia down the relative tables of gross domestic product and average incomes in the OECD. We have, in fact, a country which is almost in an economic sense and in the crudest terms, bankrupt. It is bankrupt because it is led by a Government which is bankrupt of ideas and which has been recycling old economic policies and old attitudes without any success in tackling the real issues which face this economy and nation.

I make it quite clear, as the Opposition has done from the beginning, that it will not oppose these Appropriation Bills. We will not oppose them for reasons which we enunciated at the time the Budget was brought down. It is the Fraser Government's Budget and the Fraser Government will have to live with the economic and social consequences of this Budget. We will not defeat this Budget in the Senate. But this week, and in the last week, this Government has been spending $2m of taxpayers' money advertising the benefits of this Budget. It is not spending $2m of taxpayers' money or any of its own time trying to redress the ghastly errors in the Budget or pointing to the dreadful mistakes which have been made in it or some of the things to which we have referred in the context of this debate in the Senate.

It is extraordinary that we have here a Budget which was brought down with certain sweeteners with no reference to the real economic needs of this country and with no sense of long term strategy at all but with a few election sweeteners because the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) wanted an early election before the holocaust of rising unemployment and inflation and so on really became more and more apparent. So a Budget was brought down and a plan was devised to spend $2m of taxpayers' money advertising the benefits of that Budget with an early election in mind. Of course, the money still has to be spent even though the Government got caught in its little proposals. For reasons we all know and which could only occur in some Alice in Wonderland type of environment normally, this country is not having an early election. But we have the Budget and its consequences. The Opposition is very concerned about those consequences and will not shirk its duty to point them out to the people of Australia. It is in that spirit that we now proceed, I take it, to a vote on the Appropriation Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: — (Victoria-Minister for Finance) (6.25)-Before proceeding to the vote on the third reading I respond to some matters that were raised by Senator McLaren yesterday and today. He advised that he would be raising further matters during the third reading debate. Yesterday he raised matters with regard to the egg levy and he requested information on recovery of the outstanding egg levy and enforcement of the hen quota in the Australian Capital Territory. The egg levy is collected by the Department of Primary Industry pursuant to the Poultry Industry Levy Collection Act, which requires producers to submit returns and make levy payments on a fortnightly basis. If a producer fails to submit the required returns or to make levy payments, initial follow-up action is taken by the Department. If this does not achieve compliance with the legislation, the matter is referred to the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office for legal action.

SPEECH.PARA: At the hearing of Estimates Committee H on 16 September Senator McLaren sought information about possible evasion of the poultry industry levy by Bartter, who trades in the Australian Capital Territory as Parkwood Eggs Pty Ltd. By memorandum dated 9 November 1982 the Department amplified and updated the responses given at the Estimates Committee hearing. The position has changed again since that time. The present position is that Parkwood Eggs Pty Ltd has paid the levy on hens owned by it up to 4 February 1982. Further returns have been lodged for prescribed levy days up to 30 September 1982, but the levy due has not been paid. Returns have not been lodged or levy paid for prescribed levy days from 14 October 1982 to date. Legal proceedings have been commenced for the recovery of $123,862.18, being levy outstanding up to 24 June 1982, and $5,468. 41, being penalty for non-payment of that levy up to 13 October 1982. Further action is in course to have the outstanding returns lodged and the levy paid.

A further matter was raised by Senator McLaren. In answer to his query about hen quotas, I am advised that the Australian Capital Territory has a hen quota of 200,000 hens. Parkwood Eggs is the Territory's major egg producer and is licensed to keep 189,088 hens. The Australian Capital Territory quota and licence arrangements are administered by the Department of the Capital Territory under the Egg Industry Ordinance 1975 and Regulations. The payment of hen levy by Australian Capital Territory producers is administered by the Department of Primary Industry under the poultry industry levy legislation. Both the Australian Capital Territory Ordinance and the Commonwealth Acts require producers to keep and submit records of the number of hens kept and for inspections to be made of farms to count the number of hens being kept. A joint inspection was recently arranged under the provisions of both the Ordinance and the Commonwealth Acts. Inspectors arrived at the Parkwood Eggs property on Wednesday 20 October and were refused admittance. They obtained entry on 21 October by warrant and their report indicates that the hens counted were in excess of the number of hens specified in the licence held by Parkwood Eggs Pty Ltd. Follow-up inspections were arranged on 28 October 1982 and 11 November 1982 . The evidence collected by the inspectors has been forwarded to the Department' s legal advisers for action. Quota surveillance in the Territory is being maintained and prosecutions will be pressed when evidence indicates breaches have occurred.

Senator McLaren raised another matter with regard to Mr Anthony and the loan on the house which he has in the Australian Capital Territory. In response to the questions that were raised, the information is given that at the time Mr Anthony was allocated his house in May 1964, and at the time that he purchased his house in November 1964, the eligibility criteria were as follows: Firstly, an applicant had to be employed in Canberra, except in the case of pensioners who were genuinely living in Canberra; secondly, the applicant had to be continuously employed in Canberra during the period on the waiting list unless temporarily absent in the course of employment. The Commissioner for Housing can find no evidence that a 10 per cent discount was available to purchasers of government houses. A check on Mr Anthony's personal file revealed that the purchase price of the house was the same as the value placed on the property by the chief valuer.

Senator McLaren also indicated that he would seek further information on the home bases nominated by Mr Anthony and Mr Sinclair for each month of 1981. The advice from the Department of Administrative Services is that there was no change in the home base by either Mr Anthony or Mr Sinclair during 1981. Their home bases were Murwillumbah and Tamworth respectively. There has been some comment with regard to the definition of home base. The information from the Department is that the definition of home base prior to 1 July 1982 was that ' home base for the purpose of payment of travelling allowance to Ministers shall be the home of a Minister unless he nominates otherwise to the Minister for Administrative Services'. The definition of home base with effect from 1 July 1982 is now that 'home base for the purpose of payment of travelling allowance to a Minister shall be the principal place of residence of the Minister and he shall nominate to the Minister for Administrative Services his principal place of residence'.

One other matter was raised and I take this opportunity to provide information. It relates to a minor correction of the figures that were given in the schedule that was incorporated in Hansard relating to the allowance paid to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). The amount paid on that schedule should be amended to read $19,980. This amount related to 59 days, not 56 days as previously indicated. Of the amount of $19,980, $3,768 was paid to the Prime Minister for 30 days' travelling allowance. The remaining $16,212 relates to paid hotel bills covering 29 days. Of this latter amount $9,939 relates to 14 days at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting.

The other matters that required information related to the inquiry into the financial affairs of Mr Horgan. Senator Walsh raised the matter of the dates on which contact was made with Commissioner Costigan. I regret the imprecision of the earlier briefing that was given. My advice is that contact was made with Commissioner Costigan over the weekend of 18-19 September and that the Secretary to the Department of Administrative Services also spoke with Commissioner Costigan on 23 September.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

SPEECH.PARA: South Australia-Assistance for water supply facilities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

In due course, the State will apply those funds for that purpose. We will be advised when its obligations are discharged.

—This has aroused my curiosity. I now ask: Is there any documentation associated with the request from the previous South Australian Government as to where it wanted to spend this $10m? SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.
