INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the Senate commences its consideration of this Bill, I feel I should point out that the appearance of the Bill is an historic occasion in the development of parliamentary institutions in Australia. This is the first time that the appropriations for the services under the control of the Houses of Parliament have been contained in a separate Bill. The presentation of the Bill is an appropriate recognition of the status of the Houses of the Parliament and of their independence.

INTERJECT.PARA: As was pointed out by the Minister for Finance, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle , in her second reading speech, the immediate cause of the Bill was the Government's consideration of the report by the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing. The introduction of the Bill, however, may accurately be said to be the result of efforts by senators over many years. The inappropriateness of provisions for the services of the Parliament being contained in a Bill for the ordinary annual services of the Government was pointed out in the Senate by the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Murphy, as he then was, in 1964. In 1965, a committee of then Government senators appointed to consider the Appropriation Bills and the ordinary annual services of Government recommended that the appropriations for the Parliament should not be included in the Appropriation Bill for the ordinary annual services of the Government. The Committee pointed out that it had been suggested that it was inconsistent with the concept of the separation of powers and the supremacy of the Parliament for the two Houses to be treated as an ordinary annual service of the Government. This report is found in Parliamentary Paper No. 55 of 1967.

The matter was again referred to in the Senate in 1968 in debate on the 1968-69 Budget. In 1972, the Senate House Committee reported on the provision of staff and other facilities for senators and recommended that the appropriation for such staff and other facilities for the Senate, its members and office-bearers should be administered by the President, acting, where necessary, with the advice of the Senate House Committee and subject to any direction of the Senate. In 1974, Senate Estimates Committee A made a recommendation that funds for the Parliament should not be included in the appropriation Bill for the ordinary annual services of the Government. The Committee also recommended that there should be an uncommitted contingency fund upon which the President could draw for unanticipated Senate expenditure.

In 1978 and 1979, Estimates Committee A again made the recommendation that the two Houses should make such arrangements for their own resources and facilities as were necessary to achieve the proper constitutional relationship with the Executive. Specific arrangements to enable greater control by the Senate over its own appropriations were suggested by Senator Jessop in a speech during the debate on appropriations in 1979. In 1980, the Senate appointed a select committee to inquire into and report upon Parliament's control of its own appropriations and staffing and related matters. The report of the Committee, brought down on 29 June 1981, recommended, amongst other things, that the appropriations for the Parliament be contained in a separate Bill, that a standing committee on appropriations and staffing determine the estimates for inclusion in the Bill, and that services to the Parliament under the control of executive departments be examined with a view to transferring such services to the Parliament's Appropriation Bill and to the control of the Houses. The Senate has attended to those recommendations within its power, particularly by the establishment of the Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing. It is as a result of the Government's acceptance of one of the recommendations of the Select Committee that we now have this Bill before us.

I feel that I should congratulate those senators, both past and present, whose efforts over the years have come to partial fruition with the presentation of this Bill. The history which I have recounted illustrates how well the cause of the Parliament may be served by the persistence and dedication of senators who are determined to see that the two Houses are properly equipped to carry out their respective functions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, at the outset I say that I very much appreciate the historical references embodied in the statement that you have just presented to the Senate. Over the years a lot of work has been done by honourable senators on all sides of this Parliament to bring about a Bill of this nature. If I, during the course of my remarks, recapitulate some of the history that you have outlined it will be mainly for the purpose of correcting an impression that might be gained by anyone reading a statement put down by the Speaker of the House of Representatives when the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill was introduced into the House of Representatives last month.

SPEECH.PARA: I speak to the second reading of the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill because from the time I first took my seat in the Senate in 1962 I have always maintained a consistent and demonstrated interest in securing greater autonomy and independence on the part of the Parliament. Indeed, that was the theme of my maiden speech in this Senate over 20 years ago. I am pleased that, having been the Deputy Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing-I see the Chairman of that Committee, Senator Jessop , in the chamber-I have seen the introduction of this Bill during the course of my term in Parliament. Mr President, the statement that you have made has pointed to the historical occasion that the introduction of this Bill represents . It is a milestone in parliamentary democracy. Indeed, it is a reassertion of the old doctrine of the supremacy of parliament over the Executive and the bureaucracy. I trust that those who are reporting the proceedings of this Parliament are fully appreciative of the significance and importance of this measure.

However-I say this with some regret-when the Bill was first introduced into the House of Representatives I rather fear that in the statement made by the Speaker of that House there was an attempt to rewrite the real history of this matter, the history that you, Mr President, have outlined to the Senate today. I think it fair to say that if anyone were to read the Speaker's statement on 26 October that person would be left with the belief only that the Speaker was responsible for the introduction of the new financial and staffing arrangements for the Parliament that are embodied in this Bill. True it is that the Speaker himself was gracious enough to give evidence to the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing which, as I have said, was under the chairmanship of Senator Jessop of South Australia. But the real danger inherent in the Speaker's statement to the House of Representatives is that if it is not corrected parliamentary and political history will be wrongly written. One could mistakenly get the impression that it was the Speaker's initiative that indeed caused the establishment of the Senate Committee. Nothing could be further from the truth.

The statement that you have made, Mr President, summarises the history of the Parliament's appropriations and staffing arrangements. Nevertheless, I commend to all interested persons the detailed statement that is recorded in chapter 2 of the report of the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing, which was presented to the Senate in June 1981. I particularly commend to the Speaker of the House of Representatives a reading of that chapter of the report. The facts that are set therein show that it was in 1964 that Senator Murphy, as he then was, first pointed out to the Parliament the inappropriateness of the funds provided for the Parliament being included in a Bill for the provision of funds for the annual, ordinary services of the Government. Everyone who served in this Parliament during the period when Senator Murphy served, knows that throughout his political life he argued consistently that the provision for the Parliament on the one hand, and for the Government on the other, should be made in separate appropriation Bills.

After 1964 the matter was taken up by a committee of government senators, which consisted of Senator Cormack, Senator McKellar, Senator Wedgwood and Senator Wright. It was again raised in 1968 by Senator Cormack, in 1972 the Senate House Committee took the matter up. That Committee comprised Senator Cormack, Senator Guilfoyle, Senator Jessop, Senator Laucke, the late Senator Milliner, Senator Murphy and Senator O'Byrne. As an aside, it is probably fitting to note that Senator Jessop, having been a member of that Senate House Committee, was Chairman of the ultimate Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Staffing and Appropriations; also, that Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle who similarly was a member of that House Committee in 1972 and is now the Minister for Finance, has introduced this historic Bill in the Senate.

The matter was again raised in 1974 by Senate Estimates Committee A in its report to the Senate. That Committee consisted of Senator Everett, Senator Gietzelt, Senator Greenwood, Senator James McClelland and Senator Missen. I mention all of these names deliberately to show that work over a period of nearly two decades on the part of honourable senators from all sides of the Parliament has been responsible for the introduction of this Bill. That is quite contrary to the assertions of the Speaker of the House of Representatives on 26 October last.

The matter was again referred to in 1976 by the Joint Committee on the Parliamentary Committee System, also by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. It was again referred to in May 1978 by Senate Estimates Committee A. The late Senator Knight, Senator McLaren, Senator Scott, Senator Sibraa, Senator Sim and I were members of that Committee. The matter was again referred to in November 1978 by Senate Estimates Committee A, of which Senator Colston, Senator Davidson, Senator Knight, Senator Martin, Senator McLaren and Senator Wriedt were members. It was again referred to by Senate Estimates Committee A in October 1979. The membership of the Committee was the same, except that Senator Sibraa had gone back to the Committee as a replacement for Senator McLaren.

I mention these matters in detail to show that a lot of honourable senators, from all sides, in the Parliament were involved in the long political process. Finally the Senate was persuaded to appoint a Senate select committee to inquire into and report upon Parliament's staffing and appropriations. That committee was established in May 1980. It consisted of Senator Jessop, myself, the late Senator Knight, Senator Missen, Senator Robertson, Senator Sim and for a while, our colleague Senator Ryan.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Mason too.

—And indeed Senator Mason representing the Australian Democrats. I thank Senator Jessop for his assistance. It is true that the Speaker gave evidence to the select committee, as did a lot of other people. According to his statement on 26 October last year to the House of Representatives, soon after he gave his evidence, the select committee reported and, using his words, recommended sweeping changes incorporating many of those he had been advocating to ensure the independence of the Parliament. But when one reads the evidence given to the Senate select committee by the Speaker one will see that he was quite obsessed with the need for a single line appropriation. Indeed, I think I am fair in saying that he saw a single line appropriation as something of a panacea for autonomy and independence of Parliament generally.

SPEECH.PARA: The select committee's reaction to the Speaker's recommendation for a one-line appropriation is shown by the fact that not one single mention was made in the committee's report of that concept suggested by the Speaker. If one peruses the evidence given to the committee one will see that about the only time the Speaker's mind was distracted from the concept of a one-line appropriation was when he was asked for his attitude or reaction to the ideas and proposals being put forward by members of the committee. So much for the Speaker's statement that the select committee recommended sweeping changes incorporating many of those that he himself had been advocating! I suggest that his statement would have been accurate had he said that the select committee had recommended sweeping changes but had overlooked, ignored or rejected his proposal for a single-line appropriation in favour of a really independent measure-namely, that the appropriations for the Parliament be removed from the ordinary Appropriation Bill for the ordinary annual services of the Government and included in a separate parliamentary appropriation Bill. That was the concept and the recommendation of the Senate select committee which was chaired by Senator Jessop.

Let me look at the other recommendations of the committee. For instance, the committee recommended that the Senate should establish a Senate standing committee on appropriations and staffing and replace the arrangement of discussions between the President and the Leader of the Government in the Senate on matters affecting the Senate. The select committee wanted a cross representation of honourable senators to have an input into the appropriations and staffing of the Parliament. That is what was eventually agreed to. But what did the Speaker have to say about that? Mr President, because of broadcasting arrangements I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Demonstration in Sydney: Alleged Involvement of Australian Broadcasting Commission Announcer

PROCTEXT.PARA: Demonstration in Sydney: Alleged Involvement of Australian Broadcasting Commission Announcer
Motion (by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week Senator Harradine spoke in the adjournment debate and raised the matter of some information which was given over station 2JJJ which comes to Canberra through station 2CN. He referred to the fact that a disc jockey had given information about a pro-abortion rally which was to be held in Sydney. Senator Harradine said that he wanted to know by this time this week what action the Austtralian Broadcasting Commission had taken with respect to the matter. I have just received a report from the Minister for Communications (Mr N. A. Brown) containing information which has been provided, on my advice, by Mr Keith Mackriell, the Assistant General Manager, Radio, of the ABC. The information provided states:

SPEECH.PARA: The demonstration held outside Parliament House was not 'encouraged' by the ABC .
At approximately 1.45 a.m. on 11 November, the duty announcer on 2 Triple Jay read a press release issued by the Women's Abortion Campaign.
The telephone number was given once only.
The announcer offered no editorial comment on the merits or otherwise of the demonstration. He simply read the press release without comment.
The advice goes on to state:
The number of people listening to the station at such an early hour is necessarily small.
A transcript of the announcement is attached.
In view of the foregoing factors the ABC does not believe that further action is called for in this matter.

I have no wish to repeat this valuable community service which is provided by the ABC. Our proceedings are not being broadcast, so that is all right. In any event, rather than take the time of the Senate, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the extract which was provided by the ABC.
Leave granted.
The extract read as follows-

''. . . . before that you heard an oldies one from Dexy's Midnight Runners and before that JFK and the Cuban Crisis . . . um . . . in a few moments we have an item of interest for you regarding a rally that's occurring at noon tomorrow, which wishes to raise the issue that a woman's right to legal and safe abortion is possibly endangered by current acts that are occurring, so we'll tell you a bit more about that in the near future.
(MUSIC)
That's Godley and Creme. Before that you heard Japan and John Cooper Clarke.

John Cooper Clarke will be in Australia along with New Order in November, playing at the Capital Theatre and that occurs on the 29th November . . . just trying desperately to find the correct information.

Women's Abortion Action Campaign has some information here and ''Women are in danger of losing the right to legal abortion'', Angela Rose, who is the spokesman for the women's abortion action campaign said today. ''The motion to be introduced by the Rev. Fred Nile MLC into the NSW Legislative Council on 11th November, could mean a return to the days of women dying from backyard abortions '', she said, and she went on to say that Nile's motion intends to establish human status from the moment of conception and this would lead to the outlawing of abortion and the IUD's. So that WAAC has organised a rally at noon on November 11th, which is later today and calls all who wish to maintain a woman's right to a legal, safe abortion to attend it and to write voicing their protest to members of the Legislative Council and you can get further information by ringing Margaret Kirkby during work hours on 660 5051, so if you'd like to find out more about the rally, I imagine tomorrow, or later on this morning during business hours would be the time''.
(MUSIC)

TALK.START.PARA: —I also make the comment that if the announcer was simply reading a Press release it was a very oddly worded Press release, as the extract which I have just had incorporated seems to be in oral rather than written language. I would have thought that the ABC would provide to the Senate, in response to Senator Harradine, advice on the general policy of the ABC with respect to making what might be termed public service announcements. As a regular listener to the ABC, I am aware that the ABC appears to give some publicity to what might be termed community organisations. Clearly, in this case, the ABC has given publicity to a community organisation which arouses very strong feelings both for and against in the community. I will be asking the Minister for Communications to ask the ABC to provide the Senate with that additional information which I think is relevant to any judgment on whether the disc jockey concerned was behaving in a reasonable manner.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7.02 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 17 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is uranium found in many countries of the world including North and South America, South Africa and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, and is Australian's advantage in developing uranium, its cheaper cost.
(2) Are Australia's uranium deposits small when compared to those of other countries, and can relatively small amounts provide energy for nuclear weapons.
(3) Can uranium be extracted from sea water; if so, (a) what are the details of this process; and (b) has it been researched in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Commercial uranium deposits are found in over 30 countries including those mentioned by the honourable senator.

Australia's decision to develop its uranium industry was based inter alia on the need for Australia, as a country with abundant and highly competitve energy resources, to help meet the needs of an energy deficient world. A further important factor in the decision was the Government's recognition that only as a producer and supplier of uranium can Australia be an effective force in support of the international non-proliferation regime and nuclear safeguards and controls over nuclear material.

(2) No. Australia has low-cost uranium reserves of 294,000 tonnes U, which are the largest of any country in the western world and equivalent to some 19 per cent of the western world's reasonably assured resources capable of being mined at a cost below $US80 per kilogram U.

With regard to the production of nuclear weapons, several tonnes, of natural uranium are required to produce the few kilgrams of plutonium or very highly enriched uranium required for use in nuclear weapons. Australia's safeguards policy provides that Australian nuclear material may not be used for non- peaceful or explosive purposes.
(3) Yes.

(a) The concentration of uranium in sea water is approximately 0.003ppm. In aggregate terms this means that the waters of the world's seas and oceans contain an estimated 4 billion tonnes of uranium. Various reagents have been tested for the recovery of uranium by solvent extraction, ion exchange or absorption.

Research on extraction of uranium from sea water has been carried out in the United Kingdom, the United States of America, Japan, Italy and West Germany. These studies indicate that sea water extraction is technically feasible, but is at present uneconomic. A study in the USA in 1978 estimated that the cost of uranium extracted from sea water would range from $5,000 to $7,000/kg for a plant constructed by 1995. Despite the economic obstacles, the Japanese government has commissioned the Metal Mining Agency of Japan to construct a pilot plant scheduled to commence operation in 1984 with an annual production capacity of 10kg U. The Shikiku Research Agency has reported the successful operation of a different technique, which they claim to be superior to the method employed by the Metal Mining Agency.
(b) The Australian Atomic Energy Commission has never conducted research on uranium from sea water and is unaware of any such research by any other institution in Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 17 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the ease with which school children in the United States have been able to crack the codes of some of the most sophisticated and confidential computers in that country.
(2) Is it possible for people in Australia to perform the same feats of these American school children and gain access to information stored in computers used by the Minister's Department.
(3) What security precautions have been taken to prevent such invasions of privacy.
(4) Does this ability to penetrate the secrecy of computers pose a grave security risk and leave hundreds of thousands of Australians open to blackmail and blatant invasion of privacy.
(5) Can the Minister give an assurance that confidential information related to his departmental files cannot be obtained by this method of 'plugging in' to computer systems.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware that school children in the United States have managed to gain unauthorised access to some computer systems in that country.
(2) The necessary equipment and knowledge is available in Australia for members of the public to make similar attempts to gain access to computer systems in my Department.
(3), (4) and (5) My Department has taken all reasonable precautions to ensure that the security of the information contained in its computer systems is not breached. Particular measures include:
limitation of access to departmental systems via switched public telephone facilities;
application of password restrictions to access computer systems;
physical restriction on the use of departmental computing equipment;
restriction of the amount of data held on-line;
restriction of authorisation for the loading of data files on to on-line systems.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 21 September 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Were serious deficiencies found in the control and accounting procedures for cargoes imported in ship's containers in the report of the Auditor-General tabled in the Senate on 7 September 1982.

(2) Did Mr Justice Williams (of the Drugs Royal Commission) recommend stringent new procedures to ensure stricter control over containers aimed at stopping drug smuggling in his report to the Government in December 1979.
(3) Did Mr Costigan refer to contraband being smuggled through containers in Chapter 10 of the Costigan Report.
(4) Why has the Government not acted, after two and half years, on the specific warnings and recommendations given to it by Mr Justice Williams, as has been revealed by the Auditor-General's Report.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Auditor-General, in his report of 7 September 1982, tabled in the Senate identified some areas where he considered that the Department's established cargo control and accounting procedures were not being stringently applied.
The report suggests in essence that, based on audits carried out during 1981 in Queensland and Western Australia, attention should be given to:
the role of container seals as a control measure and apparent inadequacies in departmental policing of the issuing and use of container seals;
reducing the current level of departmental approvals for the unsupervised unpacking of containers;
increasing the security requirements for and undertaking the examination of ostensibly empty containers; and
stricter adherence to certain aspects of the Department's establshed cargo control and accounting procedures.
There is no legal provision in Australia, nor is there any international convention between Customs administrations that requires or provides for the sealing of containers.

Australia has, however, taken a significant role in promoting a study at the Customs Co-operation Council, Brussels (the international forum of Customs administrations) to determine the effectiveness of container sealing for Customs purposes and to define the role, if any, of the Customs in the sealing of containers. This study is still in progress.

In respect of approvals to unpack containers without supervision, it is physically impossible for the Australian Customs Service, or for that matter any other Customs Service to open and examine all cargo whether it is containerised or conventional cargo.

The only practical and effective control measure is for the Customs Service to make a risk assessment before permitting the movement of cargo from its place of discharge. Since March 1982, new controls have been introduced and the Customs Service makes a judgement about each importation before permission is granted to move any cargo.

In respect of security over empty containers, the Auditor-General acknowledged that the new procedures mentioned should provide adequate control over empty containers. The list of checks laid down for the guidance of cargo control officers includes examining ostensibly empty containers. These particular checks have been carried out on a continuing non-programmed basis for many years.

Attention has been and is being given to the additional points of detail mentioned by the Auditor-General in regard to the ongoing application of the current cargo control and accounting procedures. A comprehensive review is being undertaken.

(2) The Australian Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs recommended that increased attention and resources should be given to the detection and interception of drugs illegally imported, especialy in containerised cargo. The Royal Commission made a number of recommendations in respect of containerised cargo.
The following action has been taken in respect of these recommendations:
drug detector dogs are being used by Customs to examine containerised cargo;
containerised cargo is selected for inspection on the basis of a risk assessment and supplemented by random examinations;

development of container search and cargo examination skills are ongoing activities. Any equipment that is needed to enhance searching techniques is acquired. The Customs administration is continually monitoring developments;
the effectiveness and practicability of seals is under study;

continuing permissions granted under Section 40AA of the Customs Act for goods to be moved from initial discharge points prior to being released from Customs control have, since March 1982, required the listing of goods to be removed; the Collector responsible at the place of initial discharge to be notified prior to the goods being moved; and the Collector responsible at the destination place to be notified of the movement no later than when the goods arrive there.

(3) The part of the Report of the Royal Commission into the activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union to which the honourable senator refers has not been released. Therefore I have no comment on that part of the question.
(4) The Government has substantially improved, and is continuing to improve, the controls it exercises in respect of containerised and other imported cargo.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 October 1982 (Hansard page 1613) Senator McIntosh asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I preface my question by quoting from a United Nations General Assembly document of October 1981 headed 'Question of East Timor'. The document states:
The General Assembly . . .
1. Reaffirms the inalienable right of the people of East Timor to self- determination and independence, in accordance with General Assembly resolutions 1514 (XV).

In a recent statement to the United Nations General Assembly the Minister said that the United Nations Security Council was the main organ for maintaining international peace and security, yet many of the resolutions were routinely ignored. He also said that what applies to the Security Council applies even more to the General Assembly and other organs of the United Nations. How can the Minister justify this statement when his Government continues, year after year, to ignore the General Assembly's recommendations over East Timor and to ignore similar recommendations from the Security Council?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The senator refers to the statement delivered by the Minister for Foreign Affairs in the General Debate at the United Nations General Assembly on 6 October. The theme of the Minister's statement was that the General Assembly was meeting against a background of international tension and at a time when the performance of the United Nations itself was coming under intense and critical scrutiny. The Security Council, the key United Nations body responsible for the maintenance of international peace and security, needed to become more robust and to deal more promptly and effectively with disputes. The Minister committed Australia to support the use of the collective influence of member states to ensure respect for Security Council decisions.

The Government strongly endorsed United Nations attempts to find a solution to the situation that developed in East Timor following Indonesia's intervention in the territory in December 1975. Australia supported efforts made by the Security Council at that time to reach a solution, including the mission of the Secretary-General's special envoy, Mr Winspeare Guicciardi.

The Security Council adopted resolutions on the question of East Timor in December 1975 and April 1976. Since then, however, the General Assembly has been the main forum for debate on East Timor. The Government's view is that, in significant respects, resolutions on this matter adopted by the General Assembly have been unrealistic. For this reason, Australia has not supported these resolutions and, since they are recommendatory only, has not been bound by them.
Commercial Pilot Examinations

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 October 1982 (Hansard, page 1844) Senator Townley asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister aware that commercial pilot examinations are held only three times a year and that it takes up to six weeks after such an examination for candidates to receive results from the Department. Whilst I realise that some people take these examinations purely out of a desire to obtain a supplementary licence, most people are wanting to become involved in flying for a livelihood and need the licences before they can do that. As the airlines have an upper limit for the age beyond which they will not accept applicants, the limited number of examinations and the slowness of the publication of the results limits a pilot's chance of being accepted by an airline. Will the Minister ascertain if commercial pilot licence examinations can be held more frequently? If not, why not? Can the marking of such examinations be speeded up?
The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The normal frequency of commercial pilot examinations is three times a year and results are notified approximately six weeks after the examinations as Senator Townley has pointed out. It is difficult to accept however, that this situation limits pilots' job prospects, particularly when compared to other professional qualifications, which are gained not more frequently than once per year.

Nevertheless, my Department has already commenced preparing new objective-type examinations for the commercial pilot licence as already are used for private licences. Although the involved Section of the Department is experiencing some difficulty in recruiting suitably qualified staff it is hoped to have this project completed and ready for introduction by the end of next year. These new examinations will lead to an increase in their frequency and a reduction in marking time. Because there is only a limited number of experienced examiners available to maintain the present system, it will not be possible to vary it during 1983.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 October 1982 (Hansard, page 1936) Senator Grimes asked the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General the following question, without notice:

On 27 September 1982, Counsel was provided with additional material for consideration. Final advice of counsel has not yet been received.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 October 1982 (Hansard, page 1936) Senator Kilgariff asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Construction, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it the intention of the Government to step up northern surveillance? Is a report correct that some aspects of aircraft surveillance are to cease in the north? Will the Minister table a comprehensive statement on overall northern surveillance?
The Minister for Transport and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Government upgraded arrangements for civil coastal surveillance in 1978 and decided at that time that a further review would be undertaken in 1981. That review, announced in December 1981, led to the Government deciding that further improvements to operational and management systems will be progressively introduced. Improvements include new funding and program budget arrangements and the specification of additional navigation, communications, and radar equipment for civilian charter aircraft performing coastal surveillance tasks under new contract arrangements. These measures are aimed at improving overall accountability and providing greater operational capability and increased margins of safety in the performance of coastal surveillance tasks.

The Standing Interdepartmental Committee On Civil Coastal Surveillance, by Government direction, is required to keep all elements of the program under continuous review. The Government is currently examining matters brought to its attention by the SIDC in recent weeks and will be reaching a decision shortly.
